TI: Multiethnic identity development and collective memory in Chinese/European-American adults.
IN: Secondo, Andrea Pusavat: U Denver, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.64(3-B),2003, pp. 1506.
AB: The multiethnic population is growing at an ever-increasing rate in the United States, however little is known about the developmental processes of these individuals. Most of the existing multiethnic research is not methodologically sound because of poor sampling and inappropriate measures. As a result, multiethnic identity research lacks a theoretical foundation and clear research findings. The goal of this qualitative study was to obtain meaningful information about participants' multiethnic identity development at a level that reflected their true ideas and experiences. Six Chinese/European American participants aged 19 through 42 were interviewed on three occasions in the areas of multiethnic life history, daily life, and meaning making. Participants' collective memories were also assessed to better understand their developmental processes. Several key themes emerged from the data. First, participants' multiethnic self-perceptions ranged on a continuum from internal to external self-perceptions. Second, participants employed three types of self-descriptions: they asserted specific ethnic identities, they used a multitude of terms to reflect their heritages, and they described various ways that they filled out racial/ethnic forms. Third, family members were reported as the most powerful influence on participants' multiethnic self-perceptions via family messages and collective memories. Fourth, multiethnic heritage informed participants' sense of selves, feelings of belonging, and interactions with others. Fifth, participants listed their families, friends, partners, communities, and cultures as the most influential factors on their multiethnic identity development. Sixth, participants' patterns of multiethnic identities were strongly associated with their patterns of memories. Seventh, participants reported that either their multiethnic heritage controlled their lives or they perceived themselves as controlling how their multiethnicity affected their lives. Finally, these individuals reported increasingly positive feelings about themselves as multiethnic people and they articulated that their multiple heritages provided them with a variety of experiences and qualities that they valued. The results of this study may be useful to multiethnic individuals, as well as the people in their lives such as family members, educators, and clinicians. These findings are significant because they provide specific information that may assist better navigation of multiethnic identity development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: multiethnic identity development, collective memory, Chinese/European-American adults, multiethnic identity development, multiethnic self-perceptions
MH:
*Ethnic Identity

*Self Perception
PO: Human. Adulthood (18 yrs & older).  Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs).  Thirties (30-39 yrs).  Middle Age (40-64 yrs)

TI: Disclosure, intimate partner violence, and workplace assistance.
IN: Hall, Iva L. Haynes: Texas Woman'S U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.64(3-B),2003, pp. 1177.
AB: The purpose of this study was to describe the rate of disclosure of intimate partner violence (IPV) and the associated type and extent of assistance received. The differences associated with factors, such as, demographics, severity of violence, level of danger, harassment, and occurrence of stalking, to disclosure of the IPV to the employer were examined, along with the relationship factors between the presence of a registered nurse or physician at the workplace, and the existence of an employee assistance program. The data were collected by interviewing women from a sample of 112 employed multiethnic women that was stratified into two groups, those who disclosed (n = 79, 70%) and those who did not disclose (n = 33, 30%). No statistically significant difference was found between the ages, education, ethnicity or income of the two groups in relation to their rate of disclosure. Although no statistical significance was found, it was clinically significant that the women in the disclosed group experienced more harassment by their abuser, were reprimanded more, and missed more work than the women of the did not disclose group. The disclosed and non disclosed groups were statistically similar in terms of their mean scores for threats, actual violence, stalking, danger, and worksite harassment. None of these factors influenced the rate of disclosure. Neither the presence of a doctor, nurse or EAP influenced the rate of disclosure. In response to the women's disclose, employers provided assistance including time off from work, advice to seek assistance, and emotional support. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: employee assistance program, intimate partner violence, disclosure
MH:
*Employee Assistance Programs

*Intimacy

*Intimate Partner Violence

TI: Outcome evaluation of the youth project: A school-based teen dating violence prevention program.
IN: Sanchez-Cesareo, Marizaida: Depaul U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(12-B), Jun 2003, pp. 6146.
AB: This dissertation presents the results of a summative (outcome) evaluation of a comprehensive school-based teen dating violence prevention program. The program was design from an ecological perspective to include four main components (workshops, groups, action project and individual counseling). Participants were 9th grade students at three urban, multiethnic Midwestern high schools. Two evaluation studies were conducted. The first study compared the effectiveness of a minimal treatment intervention (2 hours/2 day workshop) with those in a waiting-list control group. The second study compared the minimal treatment intervention with a full treatment (14-session group) intervention. A quasi-experimental design, including a pre-test, post-test, and follow up, was used. The evaluation was limited to two program components (workshop and 14-session group) and examined which intervention modality was most successful increasing participants' knowledge about teen dating violence, their egalitarian attitudes regarding the roles of men and women in society, their intent to use positive conflict solution strategies and their knowledge about community resources available to teens. Also the evaluation examined the influence that experience with teen dating violence had in the participants' ability to benefit from the program. Study one results indicated that there was no significant difference between the minimal treatment and the waiting-list control group on the outcome variables. Study two results indicated that there was no significant difference between the interventions. However, both the minimal treatment intervention and the full treatment intervention were successful in improving participants' knowledge regarding dating violence and community resources available for teens. This study found no relationship between history of teen dating violence perpetration and victimization and participants' scores on the outcome variables. Overall, results pointed out that, to impact all levels of the ecological model, teen dating violence interventions must be more comprehensive than a workshop or 14-session curriculum. Also, to provide services in multicultural and diverse environments with youth from different ethnic backgrounds and with different dating histories and experiences, it is imperative to understand the influence those characteristics have in the program's ability to influence participants' knowledge, attitudes and behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: teen dating violence, egalitarian attitudes, sex roles, conflict solution strategies
MH:
*Social Dating

*Violence

TI: Sense of safety: An exploration of a gay and lesbian community.
IN: Barry, Richard Eugene: City U New York, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(12-B), Jun 2003, pp. 6138.
AB: The role of gay and/or lesbian community was investigated. Using the rubrics of sense of community and community through place, in-depth interviews, participant observation, and a focus group were conducted to better understand community in the lives of 10 participants. The participants were four self-described lesbians and six self-described gay men ranging in age from 29 to 42. Their ethnicities were 7 white, 1 Filipino, 2 multiethnic (one Chippewa/Ojibwe, Sioux, French, and German, the other Haliwa-Siponi, African American, and Italian). Various themes emerged through the methodology, including the role of diaspora in gay and lesbian community, the importance of media to creating a sense of community, the roles of class, gender, and race in creating gay and lesbian community, the lack of family as a signifier for community, and the role of place in a sense of community. Primary among the themes uncovered was that of a Sense of Safety. This theme underlay each of the other themes. Unlike traditional conceptualizations of a sense of community, my participants each defined community through the potentiality of safety either in the physical locations of community or in the people intentionally chosen to comprise their communities. A primary position of safety within communities was not assumed. It had to be sought out or created. The importance of the role of a Sense of Safety in their conceptualizations of community even affected their interpretations of the events of September 11, 2001. The ability of a Sense of Safety to play an important conceptual role in other communities is also briefly discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: gay community, lesbian community, safety sense
MH:
*Communities

*Lesbianism

*Safety

TI: Factors that contribute to stress among Japanese-American and Caucasian-American family caregivers of frail elders.
IN: Mclaughlin, Linda Anngela: U Hawaii, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.63(11-A), May 2003, pp. 4094.
AB: Care for frail elderly adults in the U.S. has increasingly become the financial, physical and emotional responsibility of family members. Over twenty years of caregiving research has documented many factors that contribute to stress among caregivers. Due to the inherent stresses associated with informal caregiving, and an increase in multi-ethnic elders in the U.S., this study was designed to investigate factors that contribute to caregiving stress among Japanese-American and Caucasian-American caregivers of frail elders. The purpose of this study was to examine a model of factors associated with stress, and to compare the utility of this model in the prediction of stress among Japanese-American and Caucasian-American caregivers of frail elders in Hawaii. Specifically, this study examined the importance of (1) employment status, (2) time spent caregiving, (3) use of formal services, (4) functional ability, (5) social support, (6) health problems, and (7) attitude toward family care in explaining stress among caregivers. Stress was measured by two indicators, depression and life satisfaction. A correlational design was used to test the hypothesized relationships. Participants in this study were 98 Japanese-American and 86 Caucasian-American adult family caregivers who were caring for a frail elder at home. Participants were recruited from two caregiver support groups, two adult day care centers, and one home health care agency on Oahu. Multivariate analysis of variance revealed that there were significant differences between the Japanese-American and Caucasian-American samples with regard to the model of factors hypothesized to predict stress among caregivers. Simultaneous multiple regression analyses were used to test the hypothesized relationships between predictor and criterion variables. Decreased social support and more health problems of the caregiver were significant in the prediction of depression among Japanese caregivers; increased employment, decreased service use, and more health problems were significant in the prediction of depression among Caucasian caregivers. The variable "attitude toward family care" significantly predicted depression in both groups. Decreased time spent caregiving, increased social support, and stronger attitude toward family care were significant in the prediction of life satisfaction among Japanese caregivers. Only the variable "attitude toward family care" was significant in the prediction of life satisfaction among Caucasian caregivers. The results of this study are limited with regard to generalizability. The use of a convenience sample, the use of a correlational design (limiting causal inferences), and modifications made to the ATPLTC scale that measured "attitude toward family care," a scale not previously tested for psychometric properties or for use among multiethnic populations, limit the generalizability of these findings beyond the sample participants. In light of these limitations, future research could examine the continued use of the modified ATPLTC scale among multiethnic populations due to the promising results found in this study. "Attitude toward family care of elders" was the only variable that was significant with both samples, and with both indicators of stress. The importance of attitudes in determining behaviors associated with caregiving for frail elders among ethnically diverse caregivers may greatly assist social workers, gerontologists, and other health care professionals in providing culturally competent services and interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: family caregivers, frail elders, caregiving stress, employment status, social support, life satisfaction, depression, health problems, family care attitudes
MH:

TI: Parenting biracial and biethnic children.
IN: Breaux-Schropp, Anissa: Texas Woman'S U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.63(7-A), Jan 2003, pp. 2706.
AB: The purpose of this descriptive study is to explore the experiences as well as issues, concerns, and needs perceived by parents of biracial and biethnic children, specifically those of mixed Black and other heritage. Biological and adoptive parents of biracial and multiethnic children were surveyed and interviewed in this study which was guided by seven research questions. Participants for this research were acquired through an organization known as the Interracial Family and Social Alliance of North Texas (IFSA) and through convenience sampling. Major findings of this research indicate that parents of biracial and biethnic children believe that it is important that biracial children know all aspects of their dual or multiethnic heritages. These parents emphasize that it is important to keep an honest and open dialogue about race and ethnicity, physical differences, and history. Parents in this study further stress that schools and communities need to address the unique needs of multiethnic families and biracial/biethnic children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: parenting, biracial children, biethnic children

*Childrearing Practices

AB: The impact of increasing ethnic diversity of American cities is beginning to carry over to group work, particularly group work in schools. In organizing an ethnically diverse group, the selection of program becomes even more critical as a way of bringing individuals together while respecting their differences. This article examines a women's group held at an alternative high school in which the ten members came from five different countries. The purpose of this article is to explore the use of activities and program in the group as a means to explore differences and similarities of group members in a culturally sensitive way. TI: Throwing like a girl? Situating gender differences in physicality across game contexts. [References].
CQ: Evaldsson, Ann-Carita: Department of Communication Studies, Linkoping University, Linkoping, Sweden, 581 83, annev@tema.liu.se
IN: Evaldsson, Ann-Carita: Department of Communication Studies, Linkoping University, Linkoping, Sweden
SO: Childhood: A Global Journal of Child Research. Vol.10(4), Nov 2003, pp. 475-497.
AB: This study explores interaction in same-sex and cross-sex foursquare games, and, in particular, how throwing (and talk) are adjusted along with diverse configurations of players. The game was played among girls and boys with immigrant backgrounds (Syrian, Kurdish, Chilean) from low-income families in a multiethnic school setting in Sweden. The study investigates girls' physicality across various game contexts, finding that as the configuration of players shifts, the forms of bodily actions the girls invoke to construct social identities shift as well. The girls used slams--ways of throwing that require force and muscular strength, physical behaviour that is not conventionally seen as part of femininity. The same girls altered throwing (and language) style, 'throwing like a girl', to downplay physical skills with less skilled girls. In cross-sex games, the girls (and the boys) playfully mock challenged gender meanings such as boys' domination and girls' subordination. Overall, the findings underscore that studies of girls' (and boys') physicality should be grounded in detailed analyses of interaction in specific game contexts, with attention to cultural and institutional frameworks embedded in the games. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: gender differences, social identities, muscular strength, physical skills, femininity, foursquare games, physicality

SO: Medical Care. Vol.41(11), Nov 2003, pp. 1262-1276.
AB: Relatively little is known about the association between menopause and health-related quality of life (HRQL) across ethnic groups. The objective is to examine the association between HRQL and early perimenopause and ethnicity, adjusting for health, lifestyle, psychosocial, and sociodemographic factors. Questionnaires were administered to pre- and early perimenopausal women. We studied a cohort of 3302 black, Chinese, Hispanic, Japanese, and white women aged 42 to 52 years from the multisite Study of Women's Health Across the Nation (SWAN). We measured HRQL, menstrual regularity, and a variety of covariates. HRQL was assessed with 5 subscales from the Short Form-36; impaired functioning was defined as being in the 25% most impaired on a subscale. In unadjusted, but not adjusted, analyses, significantly more early perimenopausal women, as compared with premenopausal women, were classified as having impaired functioning on each of the 5 subscales. For 4 of the subscales, the effect of menopausal status was explained by menopause-related symptoms. Early perimenopause is not associated with impaired functioning when adjusted for symptoms. Significant ethnic differences in HRQL exist. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

SO: Public Health Nursing. Vol.20(6), Nov-Dec 2003, pp. No Pagination Specified.
AB: Focus groups provide an effective means of incorporating the perspectives of "hidden" populations in assessments of community health needs and assets. A series of focus groups was conducted with specifically targeted segments of a community to develop a comprehensive picture of community health. The authors describe the focus group process, major findings, and the use of focus group results in a highly multicultural community. Despite differences in age, length of residence, and ethnicity, the focus groups were remarkably similar in the issues raised. The majority of participants viewed the multicultural nature of the community as an asset but voiced some of the difficulties of living in a multiethnic and multilanguage environment. Similar areas of concern in the community arose from all of the focus groups, including housing and other environmental issues and problems of access to health care. Focus group findings have been used to initiate activity addressing identified community problems. Focus group participation had the added benefit of increasing community members' participation in other community endeavors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: community health, environmental issues, focus group, age differences, health care access, community assessment

SO: Psychiatric Quarterly. Vol.74(4), Win 2003, pp. 401-420.
AB: The mental health community was caught unaware after 9/11 with respect to treatment of survivors of terrorist attacks. Because this form of trauma was quite rare in the U.S., few trauma specialists had extensive experience, or taught regularly on this subject. Since the primary objective of terrorism is the creation of demoralization, fear, and uncertainty in the general population, a focus on mental health from therapeutic and public health perspectives is critically important to successful resolution of the crisis. Surveys after 9/11 showed unequivocally that symptomatology related to the attacks were found in hundreds of thousands of people, most of whom were not escapees or the families of the deceased. Soon after 9/11, our center formed a collaboration with other academic sites in Manhattan to rapidly increase capacity for providing state-of-the-art training and treatment for trauma-related psychiatric problems. Our experience suggests that evidence-based treatments such as Prolonged Exposure Therapy have proven successful in treating 9/11-related PTSD. However, special clinical issues have arisen, such as the influence of culture on clinical presentation and treatment expectations in a multiethnic community... (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

CQ: Raffaelli, Marcela: Dept of Psychology & Inst for Ethnic Studies, U Nebraska, 238 Burnett Hall, Lincoln, NE, US, 68588-0308, mraffaelli@unl.edu

SO: Developmental Psychology. Vol.39(6), Nov 2003, pp. 1036-1046.
AB: Precursors of adolescent sexual risk taking were examined in a multiethnic sample consisting of 443 children (51% girls) of National Longitudinal Survey of Youth participants. Respondents were 12-13 years old in 1994 and 16-17 in 1998. Controlling for demographic and contextual factors, self-regulation--but not risk proneness--was significantly (modestly) associated with overall sexual risk taking 4 years later. Analyses of individual sexual behaviors indicated that self-regulation may affect choices made after becoming sexually active (e.g., number of partners) rather than the initiation of sexual activity. Measures of parent and peer influence had independent effects on sexual risk taking but did not moderate the effects of self-regulation and risk proneness. Findings add to the growing literature on implications of self-regulation for individual development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: adolescent sexual risk taking, self regulation, attraction to risk, adolescent development, risk proneness, sexual behaviors, choices, peer pressure

TI: Outreach to Multiethnic, Multicultural, and Multilingual Women for Breast Cancer and Cervical Cancer Education and Screening: A Model Using Professional and Volunteer Staffing. [References].
CQ: Kiger, Holly: Health Services, Center for Healthy Aging, 2125 Arizona Ave, Santa Monica, CA, US, 90404
IN: Kiger, Holly: Center for Healthy Aging, Santa Monica, CA, US
SO: Family & Community Health: The Journal of Health Promotion & Maintenance. Vol.26(4), Oct-Dec 2003, pp. 307-318.
AB: Reaching low-income women from diverse ethnic and cultural communities for the purpose of breast and cervical cancer education and screening is a challenge. This article describes an approach used by Center for Healthy Aging in Santa Monica, California, to implement three projects aimed at Hispanic and African American women to encourage early intervention behaviors. Hispanic and African American volunteers and professional staff work together to establish trusting relationships, join forces with community leaders and develop collaborative approaches to achieve the goal of screening about 1,000 underserved women annually and providing education for an additional 5,000 women. Incorporated in the article are lessons learned about working with this population, the communities in which they live and the use of volunteers for these and other projects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: multiethnic communities, Hispanic women, African American women, cervical cancer, breast cancer, cancer screening

TI: Review of Racism, Gender Identities and Young Children: Social Relations in a Multi-Ethnic, Inner-City Primary School.
CQ: Raag, Tarja: Department of Psychology, Colby College, 5550 Mayflower Hill, Waterville, ME, US, 04901-8855
IN: Raag, Tarja: Department of Psychology, Colby College, Waterville, ME, US
SO: Archives of Sexual Behavior. Vol.32(4), Aug 2003, pp. 392-393.
AB: Reviews Connolly's volume, which chronicles the self reported experiences of a small group of preschool-aged children negotiating the complexities of identity development in a multiethnic, inner-city primary school in England. The reviewer discusses the author's highlighting of the children's social competencies by directly engaging the children in dialogue. In addition, the review claims the work illustrates both the complexity of children's developing identities and contradictory and fluid nature of racism and sexism and the multidirectional relationships between developing identities and discourses on race and gender in communities, cultures, politics, and history. The reviewer praises the book as an excellent resource for rethinking research approaches to studying children, reevaluating theories of children's experiences of racism, revising multicultural and antiracist programming in schools, and moving forward into new research inquiries. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: preschool-aged children, identity development, racism, gender identity, social relations, multiethnic schools, social competencies
MH:
*Gender Identity

*Psychosocial Development

TI: Patterns of sexual risk behaviors and psychiatric disorders in a community sample of young adults. [References].
AU:
Tubman, Jonathan G

Gil, Andres G

Wagner, Eric F

Artigues, Henry
CQ: Tubman, Jonathan G.: Community-Based Intervention Research Group, Florida International University, MARC Building-Suite 310, University Park Campus, Miami, US, 33199, jonathan.tubman@fiu.edu
IN:
Tubman, Jonathan G.: Florida International University, Community-Based Intervention Research Group, Miami, FL, US
Gil, Andres G.: Florida International University, Community-Based Intervention Research Group, Miami, FL, US
Wagner, Eric F.: Florida International University, Community-Based Intervention Research Group, Miami, FL, US
Artigues, Henry: Florida International University, Community-Based Intervention Research Group, Miami, FL, US
SO: Journal of Behavioral Medicine. Vol.26(5), Oct 2003, pp. 473-500.
AB: This cross-sectional study documents significant associations between patterns of sexual risk behaviors and psychiatric diagnoses in a multiethnic community sample of young adults (N = 1803) in South Florida. Self-report data regarding sexual behavior and psychiatric symptoms were collected in structured interviews in a follow-up of an earlier school-based study. Cluster analysis was used to group participants with regard to levels of sexual risk behaviors during the past year. Chi-square analysis and ANOVA identified significant associations between cluster membership and (a) lifetime and (b) past year diagnoses for affective disorders, conduct disorder, antisocial personality disorder, alcohol abuse/dependence, marijuana abuse/dependence, and other drug abuse/dependence. In addition, higher levels of sexual risk behaviors were associated with higher levels of cumulative lifetime psychiatric disorders. Implications for selected prevention of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) and the treatment of psychiatric disorders in young adulthood are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: sexual risk behaviors, psychiatric disorders, multiethnic community, young adults, sexually transmitted diseases, prevention implications

AB: There is now a body of research that has shown that the attitudes of nurses towards substance misuse in the mentally ill are generally suboptimal and this has an impact on the quality of nursing care provided. Despite this, to date there have been no published studies that have examined the attitudes of forensic nurses towards substance misusing forensic service users. Sixty-three multiethnic registered forensic psychiatric nurses based on an inpatient unit in outer London were surveyed using the Substance Abuse Attitude Survey (SAAS). This has five subscores: Treatment Intervention, Treatment Optimism, Permissiveness, Non-Moralism and Non-Stereotypes. Only Permissiveness scores were at an optimum level and equivalent to other community mental health workers. The Treatment Intervention and Treatment Optimism subscores were well below those of a multidisciplinary group of community mental health workers. Three other findings were of note. Firstly, women had higher Non-Moralism scores than men. Secondly, staff nurses had higher Non-Stereotypes scores than other grades. Finally, Black nurses had higher Treatment Optimism scores than non-Black colleagues. In conclusion, the attitudes of forensic nurses towards substance misuse in forensic clients are more suboptimal than other... AB: This article proposes a conceptual framework for addressing social contextual factors in cancer prevention interventions, and describes work that operationalizes this model in interventions for working class, multiethnic populations. The Harvard Cancer Prevention Program Project includes three studies: (1) an intervention study in 25 small businesses; (2) an intervention study in 10 health centers; and (3) a computer simulation modeling project that translates risk factor modifications into gains in life expectancy and number of cancers averted. The conceptual framework guiding this work articulates pathways by which social context may influence health behaviors, and is used to frame the interventions and guide evaluation design. Social contextual factors cut across multiple levels of influence, and include individual factors, interpersonal factors, organizational factors , and neighborhood/community factors. Social context is shaped by sociodemographic characteristics that impact day-to-day realities. By illuminating the pathways by which social contextual factors influence health behaviors, it will be possible to enhance the effectiveness of interventions aimed at reducing social inequalities in risk behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

SO: Ethnicity & Health. Vol.8(1), Feb 2003, pp. 41-61.
AB: This paper presents a detailed analysis of the complexities encountered in recruiting research informants who described themselves as African-Caribbean, Pakistani-Kashmiri and white English. Three methods of recruitment were used: (1) advertisements and articles in local media, (2) institutional contacts through local voluntary organizations and (3) interpersonal contacts, referrals and snowballing. We compare and contrast the experiences of ethnically matched interviewers who conducted research amongst the three aforementioned ethnic groups. Our findings suggest that local advertisements and media contact worked best for recruiting members of the white English community in our South English town. Interpersonal contacts were crucial in recruiting Pakistani-Kashmiri informants. Institutional contacts were the most useful way of accessing African-Caribbean individuals. We conclude that local ethnic identities and social networks produce qualitatively different responses to recruitment attempts in different communities. Such differences necessitate the employment of a range of recruitment methodologies and detailed formative research in a target community before commencing recruitment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Purpose: To examine ethnic variation in parenting characteristics and in associations among parenting characteristics and adolescent smoking, and to assess the strength of those associations separately by ethnic subgroup. Methods: Data were collected from a diverse sample (48.4% Hispanic/Latino, 22.9% Asian, 12.1% Non-Hispanic white, and 16.6% Multiethnic) of 1846 Southern California 6th-graders (mean age 11.3 years). Lifetime smoking and parenting characteristics (parental smoking status, adolescents' perceptions of parent-child communication, and parental monitoring) were assessed. Across ethnic groups, descriptive statistics for parenting and smoking variables were calculated and compared. Logistic regression analyses controlled for demographics (socioeconomic status, generation status, family structure, age, and gender) and interaction terms (parenting characteristics x ethnicity), and were also run separately by ethnicity. Results: Asian adolescents reported less parental monitoring than Latino/Hispanics and less parental communication than other ethnic subgroups. Odds ratios indicated parental monitoring (OR=.63; CI=.53-.74; p<.001) and parental communication (OR=.73; CI=.62-.86; p<.001) were protective whereas parental smoking... TI: "IS THIS SOME KIND OF SOAP OPERA?": A TALE OF TWO READERS ACROSS FOUR LITERATURE DISCUSSION CONTEXTS. [References].
AU:
Allen, JoBeth

Moller, Karla J

Stroup, Dorsey
CQ: Allen, JoBeth: U Georgia, 125 Aderhold, Athens, GA, US, 30602-7123, jobethal@coe.uga.edu
IN:

SO: Reading & Writing Quarterly: Overcoming Learning Difficulties. Vol.19(3), Jul-Sep 2003, pp. 225-251.
OL: Journal of Reading, Writing, & Learning Disabilities International
AB: Examined literature circles in a multiethnic 5th grade classroom, exploring student-led and teacher-led discussions. The social interactions of 2 5th grade females, who often struggled with reading, were investigated, focusing on their literature discussions across the 4 settings of: (1) teacher-directed whole-class discussion of teacher-selected literature; (2) student-led, self-selected heterogeneous group and literature; (3) student-led, self-selected homogeneous group and literature; and (4) teacher-selected book and homogeneous group with teacher-guided discussion. Documentation included observational notes and audio tapes in whole-class and small-group settings, written products, and informal interviews. Results show that, although child-directed literature discussions were rich, meaningful, and inclusive, they were also unproductive and even detrimental. The ability to engage in text-based discussions that affirmed reader competence developed with adult and peer support. When peer support was lacking, the teacher enabled Ss to adopt productive stances in literature discussions and interrupted destructive social practices. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: literature circles, elementary school classrooms, student-led discussion, teacher-led discussion, reading, small group discussion

TI: Notions of HIV and medication among multiethnic people living with HIV. [References].
CQ: Oggins, Jean: U Californa, Box 426856, San Francisco, CA, US, 94142
IN: Oggins, Jean: U California, San Francisco, CA, US
SO: Health & Social Work. Vol.28(1), Feb 2003, pp. 53-62.
AB: To help understand why people of ethnic minority groups tend to be less likely than European Americans to take medication for HIV, narratives from 62 multiethnic HIV-positive individuals (ages 16-53 yrs) were coded for mention of taking medication for HIV and reason for not doing so. Respondents were African American, Asian American, Haitian American, Latino American, European American and Native American. Respondents viewed HIV/AIDS and medication in terms of, other illnesses and drugs, including colds, cancer, and street drugs. Some recovering drug users expressed concern about ingesting synthetic medication or considered medical regimens as constraining as a drug addiction. Some in the sample also thought antiretroviral medications were toxic, especially when taken in combination. Others thought they should wait to take medication to prevent opportunistic infection until they felt ill. Implications for providers are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: The work is framed in the study of in-group bias as predictor variable of acculturation attitudes of native and immigrant populations. The aim of this research is to show a test for the measure of in-group and out-group bias in different ethnic groups (native Spanish people and North-Africans and Black-African people). Moreover, a study of psychometric properties of the test where are shown the results of reliability scores and validation evidences of measures (based on the relationship of in-group bias with another variables described in the psychosocial literature) it is reported. These results allow a conclusion that the developed test possesses psychometric properties adapted for multiethnic use. This test could be used to measure in-group bias in majority groups (native people's respect for North-African and Black-African out-groups) and in minority groups (North-African and Black-African people's respect for native out-group). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

SO: AIDS Patient Care and STDs. Vol.17(4), Apr 2003, pp. 187-197.
AB: Examined the sociodemographic and behavioral variables associated with quality of life (QOL) among multiethnic, economically disadvantaged patients with HIV/AIDS. A cross-sectional survey was conducted in a large inner-city HlV/AIDS clinic. Demographic characteristics, stage of disease, and behavioral variables were assessed, in addition to work-role functioning and overall health-related QOL. 385 of 617 patients (62.4%) consented to complete the questionnaire. Demographic composition of the sample was as follows: 78% male, 25% White, 44% Black, and 29% Hispanic. 45% of the participants were infected through men having sex with men (MSM), 35% through heterosexual contact, and 11% through injection drug use. Racial/ethnic minorities reported significantly poorer physical functioning and work-role functioning. Ss with higher nadir CD4 cell counts, MSM HIV exposure, and more education (beyond high school) reported better physical functioning and work-role functioning. Overall QOL and work-related functioning were significantly impaired in this population. The impaired functional status findings hold for every social, demographic, and behavioral subgroup examined. Findings suggest that the influence of social inequality persist even among a universally disadvantaged population. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Risk factors for the onset of eating disorders in adolescent girls: Results of the McKnight longitudinal risk factor study. [References].
SO: The American Journal of Psychiatry. Vol.160(2), Feb 2003, pp. 248-254.
AB: Examined the importance of potential risk factors for eating disorder onset in a large, multiethnic sample followed up for 3 yrs, with assessment instruments validated for the target population and a structured clinical interview used to make diagnoses. Ss were 1,103 girls initially assessed in grades 6-9 in school districts in Arizona and California. Each year, Ss completed the McKnight Risk Factor Survey, had body height and weight measured, and underwent a structured clinical interview. The McKnight Risk Factor Survey, a self-report instrument developed for this age group, includes questions related to risk factors for eating disorders. During follow-up, 32 girls (2.9%) developed a partial or full-syndrome eating disorder. At the Arizona site, there was a significant interaction between Hispanics and higher scores on a factor measuring thin body preoccupation and social pressure in predicting onset of eating disorders. An increase in negative life events also predicted onset of eating disorders in this sample. At the California site, only thin body preoccupation and social pressure predicted onset of eating disorders. A four-item screen derived from thin body preoccupation and social pressure had a sensitivity 0.72, a specificity of 0.80, and an efficacy of 0.79. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: risk factors, eating disorders, race & ethnic differences, adolescent girls, predictive value
MH:
*Eating Disorders

AB: Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) use is common in the United States, particularly among middle-aged women for symptoms commonly reported during perimenopause. The study examined the relationship between women's report of perimenopausal symptoms and the use of CAM and socioeconomic or cultural factors. Ss were White, African American, and Hispanic women (aged 30-65 yrs) who were taking part in the ENDOW (Ethnicity, Needs and Decision of Women) project. The project examined women's decision making about hysterectomies and menopausal issues with a focus on ethnic variations and cultural influences. The prevalence of CAM use was 33%; approximately 94% reported use of CAM therapies and 23% used CAM practitioners. Those who used CAM were younger and better educated; more often they reported pelvic pain and painful intercourse. The only demographic factor to predict use of alternative medicine was education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Clinician's guide to cultural psychiatry. [References].
IN: Tseng, Wen-Shing: U Hawaii, Dept of Psychiatry, Honolulu, HI, US
SO: (2003). Clinician's guide to cultural psychiatry. xviii, 493 pp. San Diego, CA, US: Academic Press; US.
AB: (from the cover) This book is a practical guide for clinicians working in multiethnic societies. The book begins with an introduction to the cultural dimensions of human behavior, stress, and illness, then moves on to elaborate on the impact of culture on psychopathology, clinical practice, and psychological therapies expanding on how to provide culturally competent care in various clinical settings and for different ethnic groups. It ends with an examination of unique social phenomena relevant to clinical work. There are more than 120 illustrations and nearly 30 case vignettes included to enhance the clinical applicability. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: cultural psychiatry, culture, ethnic groups, psychopathology, clinical practice

TI: Cardiovascular reactivity to stress predicts future blood pressure in adolescence. [References].
AU:
Mattews, Karen A

Salomon, Kristen

Brady, Sonya S

Allen, Michael T
CQ: Mattews, Karen A.: Dept of Psychiatry, 3811 O'Hara Street, Pittsburgh, PA, US, 15213, matthewska@msx.upmc.edu
IN:
Mattews, Karen A.: Dept of Psychiatry, U Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, US
Salomon, Kristen: Dept of Psychiatry, U Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, US
Brady, Sonya S.: Dept of Pscyhology, U Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, US
Allen, Michael T.: Dept of Education & Psychology, U Southern Mississippi, Long Beach, MS, US
SO: Psychosomatic Medicine. Vol.65(3), May-Jun 2003, pp. 410-415.
AB: Objective: This study evaluated the prospective relationship between cardiovascular reactivity to psychological stress and increases in resting blood pressure across a 3-year period among a multiethnic pediatric sample (N=149). Methods: Systolic and diastolic blood pressure; EKG heart rate, pre-ejection period, and mean successive difference of R to R intervals; and impedance-derived measures of cardiac output, stroke volume, and total peripheral resistance were collected during performance of four tasks that elicited different hemodynamic response patterns. Changes from baseline to each task were standardized and averaged to form eight composite scores. Analyses adjusted for time 1 baseline blood pressure and age, body mass index at baseline and change to follow-up, and duration of follow-up. Results: Rises in SBP over the follow-up period were independently predicted by SBP (beta=0.161, p=.009), DBP (beta=0.132, p=.02), and CO (beta=0.144, p=.02) composite measures of reactivity. Rises in DBP over the follow-up period were predicted by DBP (beta=0.292, p=.003, respectively), and MSD (beta=-0.176, p<.03) composite measures of reactivity. TPR reactivity was not related prospectively to blood pressure rises. Conclusions: This study adds to the pediatric literature... TI: Groupworkers in the making: A simulation for teaching social groupwork. [References].
IN: Mesbur, Ellen Sue: Ryerson Polytechnic U, School of Social Work, Toronto, ON, US
SO: Henry, Sue [Ed]; East, Jean F [Ed]; Schmitz, Cathryne L [Ed]. (2002). Social work with groups: Mining the gold.  (pp. 131-150). xvi, 208 pp. New York, NY, US: Haworth Press; US.
AB: (from the chapter) This chapter presents an example of the use of a simulated group, the Chaotic Teen Group Simulation. The simulation, consisting of 6 multiethnic teenagers, was brought into the fourth class of Ryerson Polytechnic University's one-semester Advanced Social Groupwork course for students in years 3 or 4 of their BSW program. Excerpts 1, 2, and 3 are followed by feedback to the student worker from the simulators, to demonstrate the possible learning from those on the receiving end of the practice. Incorporated into the analysis sections on the students' interventions is teaching input from the instructors present at the simulation, to show how course content may be incorporated into an experiential learning activity and how "coaching" the student workers may prepare them for their next steps. Incorporated also are constructive and supportive comments from peers in the class during the time-out periods, a third means of learning the applied theory of social groupwork. The fourth sphere of learning, personal learning on the part of student workers, is assumed to occur throughout the entire simulation, and in some spots is visible when the same student worker continues after a time-out. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: simulated group, Chaotic Teen Group Simulation, Advanced Social Groupwork course, feedback, analysis, experiential learning, personal learning, simulators, instructors, peers, social work students

TI: Preferences for psychosocial interventions among newly diagnosed cancer patients from a multiethnic population.
AU:
Cook Gotay, Carolyn

Lau, Akiko K
CQ: Cook Gotay, Carolyn: Cancer Research Ctr of Hawaii, U Hawaii, 126 Lauhala Street, Honolulu, HI, US, 96813, cgotay@crch.hawaii.edu
IN:
Cook Gotay, Carolyn: U Hawaii, Cancer Research Ctr of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, US
Lau, Akiko K.: U Hawaii, Cancer Research Ctr of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, US
SO: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology. Vol.20(4), 2002, pp. 23-37.
AB: This article addresses preferences for psychosocial interventions in newly diagnosed cancer patients in a multiethnic sample consisting of Americans of European, Filipino, Native Hawaiian, and Japanese ancestry. Patients who were diagnosed with cancer four to six months before the study were identified through consecutive registrations on the Hawai'i Tumor Registry. Data were collected through personal interviews using a standardized questionnaire. Among 194 patients who participated in the study, 162 (84%) reported experiencing cancer-related stress. Although few patients had participated in supportive interventions, there was considerable interest in these techniques. Most patients had received information about diagnosis and treatment, but only 10% had received information about psychological counseling. When preferences for supportive interventions were linked with demographic characteristics (e.g., gender, age, and ethnicity), the most consistent finding was higher levels of interest among Filipino patients. Additional research examining ethnic differences in preferences for psychosocial support is warranted. Because of the potential for greater use of behavioral therapies by patients, educating providers about the availability, efficacy, and patients' interest in such... (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: newly diagnosed cancer patients, psychosocial interventions, preferences, multiethnic population

*Health Care Utilization

Preferences

TI: Have cities ceased to function as "integration machines" for young people? [References].
IN: Heitmeyer, Wilhelm: Bielefeld U, Interdisciplinary Inst for Conflict & Violence Research, Bielefeld, Germany
SO: Tienda, Marta [Ed]; Wilson, William Julius [Ed]. (2002). Youth in cities: A cross-national perspective.  (pp. 87-112). xii, 288 pp. New York, NY, US: Cambridge University Press; US.
AB: (from the chapter) In contemporary German society, growing numbers of youth are resorting to criminality and violence because their exposure to urban social, occupational, and political disintegration involves various forms of social exclusion, destabilization of life contexts, and emotional rejection. In this chapter, I consider whether the city, long heralded as an "integration machine," can continue to produce social cohesion in the face of population diversification through immigration, coupled with poor economic performance and strained systems of social support. I describe the current residential segregation in Germany's multiethnic society and the creation of ethnic colonies. I review recent trends in social exclusion and violence among youth in German cities and propose strategies for dealing with the spatial concentration of disadvantaged youth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: cities, integration machines, disadvantaged youth, social exclusion, residential segregation, spatial concentration, contemporary German society, ethnic colonies, multiethnic society

TI: Providing accessible services to minority ethnic deaf people: Insights from a study in Alberta, Canada. [References].
IN:
Rodda, Michael: U Alberta, Dept of Educational Psychology, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Eleweke, C. Jonah: Ball State U, Dept of Special Education, Muncie, IN, US
SO: American Annals of the Deaf. Vol.147(5), Dec 2002, pp. 45-55.
AB: Evidence suggests that minority ethnic people in general and minority ethnic deaf people (MEDP) in particular face numerous formidable obstacles in their attempts to gain access to services in the community. Deaf people from minority ethnic groups who have no English and/or American Sign Language (ASL) skills have particular difficulty gaining access to services. The study therefore was concerned with identifying some of the special needs and difficulties of MEDP who are trying to gain access to services in multiethnic communities. Qualitative approaches were used in data gathering and analysis. The results indicated six areas of difficulty for MEDP in gaining access to services: (a) communication barriers, (b) a lack of recognition of the needs of MEDP, (c) inappropriate service delivery and a lack of information on available services, (d) insufficient cultural sensitivity on the part of service providers, (e) issues of user involvement, and (f) a lack of specific programs for MEDP. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: minority ethnic groups, accessible services, service delivery, minority ethnic deaf people, health care access, needs, difficulties, community services, health care services, Canada

TI: Identity formation of female students in a predominately female, multiethnic high school.
IN: Gewinner, Kathleen Yvette: U Houston, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.63(6-A), Jan 2002, pp. 2109.
AB: This study was designed to investigate further the process by which high achieving female students make meanings about class, ethnicity, and gender and develop self and social identities. The general assumptions reflected were grounded in the cultural studies tradition. Analysis and interpretation of data collected from participants depended on four areas of research and theory: feminist identity formation, critical pedagogy, critical epistemology and research methodology, and the critical social theory of Habermas (1981). The study utilized the identity formation model of Weir (1996) which places meaning-making in a social-linguistic context and emphasizes the role of mutual recognition in the process. Habermas's ontogenetic theory of identity formation, a component of Weir's model, is also central to the methodological approach of Carspecken (1996) used in this study. The internal colonization theory of Habermas is the basis of Wexler's (1992) model which examines the effects of systems imperatives on the individual identity formation of students and is used in the discussion of data analysis. A qualitative interview technique was employed in order to facilitate the uncovering of the underlying assumptions that structure meaning-making by students, and the process by which they negotiate expectations and limitations from both family and school. Through the interpretation of interview data, the study examined how four female students negotiated meanings about ethnicity, gender, and class within the context of a predominately female, ethnically diverse public school. Therefore, the study had two main goals. The first goal was to explore how students make meaning about their own identity. The second goal was to examine the school as a social site significant to the identity formation of female students. It was shown that students negotiated the expectations and limitations from both family and school and worked to integrate conflicting identities into a coherent sense of self. It was also shown that the school, as a social site, was significant to the identity formation of female students in that it provided the context for the challenges to and the renegotiations of meanings by students. Achievement ideology, which permeated school culture and influenced policy, was shown to serve as a link between economic and bureaucratic systems and identity formation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: identity formation, high school students, girls

*Gender Identity

*Human Females

Identity Formation

TI: Ethnic, racial, and cultural identity/self: An integrated theory of identity/self in relation to large scale social cleavages.
IN: Alipuria, Linda Line: The Claremont Graduate U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(1-B), Jul 2002, pp. 583.
AB: The purpose of this study was to test a theory of group-related identity/self that distinguishes the influence of the large scale social cleavages of ethnicity, race, and culture. Definitions of these factors are often confounded, and their unique psychological contributions difficult to interpret. Phinney's ethnic identity theory, Helms' racial identity theory, and Bandlamudi's view of the cultural self are discussed. Ethnic identity is defined in terms of belonging to the people of one's parental heritage(s). Racial identity for both Whites and non-Whites involves responding to racism-attributing character and ability in terms of phenotype. Cultural self refers to the individual's construction of personal meaning using cultural values, products, and behaviors integrated with one's own personality and temperament. Cultural influences may include parents' ethnic cultures and others. Seven multiethnic/multiracial/multicultural young adults (5 females, 2 males) in their 20s and early 30s were interviewed. Each had an immigrant Asian Indian father and an American born (one British), non-Indian mother. Results confirmed that discussions of ethnicity, race, and culture, as defined in this paper, could be differentiated. Subjects used different language and referred to different factors when addressing each. Ethnicity was discussed in terms of birthright and origins, and respondents could choose when and how to participate. Parents' approval was important as was acceptance by coethnics. Racial discussions related to appearance, and respondents referred to race as primarily a White/non-White issue involving politics of positionality; prejudice, experienced or observed; and fairness. Cultural self was discussed in terms of values, strengths, and ways of living. Influences of their parents' ethnic culture(s) or others were discussed in terms of essential self, who they really were. Group-related identity/self is fluid, complex, and incorporates multiple influences. It is situational, that is, it is experienced in relation to local and national social definitions and structures. This theory may improve dialogue on group-related identity/self, help to explain conflicting findings in research, and connect psychology to other scholarly writing on race, ethnicity and culture. Further study will determine whether this theory applies to all, as is asserted in this paper, not just persons with multiple heritages or immigrants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: large scale social cleavages, cultural influences, ethnicity, racial identity
MH:
*Social Identity

*Social Influences

*Sociocultural Factors

TI: What is aggressive? Is it justified? Attitudes among United States and foreign-born adolescents.
IN: Blackshear, John H.: Georgia State U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(12-B), Jun 2002, pp. 5948.
AB: This study examined attitudes of U.S.-born and foreign-born adolescents concerning aggressive behaviors and justified aggression. Prior to the study, focus groups were conducted during which adolescents discussed types of aggressive behavior, situations in which aggression is likely to occur, positive and negative outcomes of aggression, and circumstances in which aggression is justified. From these discussions, two surveys were constructed, the aggressiveness ratings survey and the justifiability survey. These surveys were used to assess adolescents' attitudes in this study. Ninety-eight ninth grade students of various social, cultural, and racial/ethnic backgrounds from a high school in Atlanta, Georgia, participated in this study. In addition to completing the aggressiveness and justifiability ratings surveys, participants completed demographic questionnaires on which they indicated their sex, race, birthplace, parents birthplace, immigrant status, and the type of community (rural, small city, suburban, and big city) they lived in longest. Univariate analyses of variance revealed that sex, immigrant status (marginally), and type of area lived in longest accounted for the most variability in aggressive behavior ratings for this sample. Specifically, females compared to males and those from big cites and both suburban and rural areas compared to those from small town rated acts as more aggressive. Analyses failed to produce significant effects for justifiability of aggression. Discussion focused on the implications of these findings as they relate to previous research, clinical implications, and considerations for future studies with this type of sample. In addition, there is discussion of emergent issues and considerations resulting from conducting this type of study with immigrant and multiethnic participants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: aggression, justifiability, ethnic differences, attitudes, adolescents

TI: Effects of ethnic identity status and autonomy expectations on coping strategy preferences of Asian Indian adolescents in the United States of America and their majority culture peers.
IN: Cherian, Sam: Wayne State U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(12-A), Jun 2002, pp. 4053.
AB: The purpose of this study was to investigate differences, if any, in ethnic identity status and autonomy expectations of male and female Asian Indian adolescents in the U.S.A. and their Caucasian peers, and effects of these variables on coping strategy preferences. Participants were adolescents (grades 9 through 12) from two high schools from the same school district that was located in a large mid-western metropolitan area of the United States. Ninety-four Asian Indian and 134 Caucasian students volunteered to fill out Multiethnic Identity Measure (MEIM), The Teen Timetable (behavioral autonomy), The Coping Strategy Indicator (problem solving, seeking social support, and avoidance coping), and a demographic questionnaire designed for this study. The Asian Indian students were either immigrant or first-generation and all of the parents of these students had been born outside of the United States. Few Caucasian students were foreign-born. The Asian Indian students self reported their grades as mostly As and some Bs, with the Caucasian students having a broader range of self-reported academic performance. Most students' socioeconomic statuses were either middle or upper middle class, with few students classified as lower middle class. Inferential statistics were used to test the five research hypotheses. As expected, Asian Indian adolescents endorsed higher levels of ethnic identity status. No support was found for age or gender-related differences in ethnic identity status. Interaction effects were not statistically significant. Asian Indian students endorsed later expectations for behavioral autonomy when compared to their Caucasian peers, suggesting a tendency for Asian Indian families to preserve aspects of their collectivist values in a society that was predominantly individualistic in orientation. Hypothesized differences in coping strategy preferences based on ethnicity, ethnic identity status, or autonomy expectations were not supported by the data. Adolescent girls tended to use more support seeking strategies than boys. Although the findings of this study did not provide strong support that ethnic identity status and behavioral autonomy affected coping styles, further research is needed to determine if students with diverse ethnic backgrounds differ in their approach to problem solving. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Multiethnic parish cooperation: An examination of the cooperative relationships among ethnic congregations of multiethnic Catholic parishes of the diocese of Orange California.
IN: Nguyen, Tung Ba: U La Verne, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(11-A), May 2002, pp. 3931.
AB: Purpose. This study intended to examine the status of cooperation among ethnic congregations of multiethnic Catholic parishes, to identify the factors influencing this cooperative alliance, and to explore the relationships between demographic, organizational, and psychological variables and the parishioners' cooperative attitude. Theoretical framework. Since cooperation in a multiethnic context is a complex social phenomenon, the theoretical framework of the study includes conceptual components from several branches of learning: cooperation theories, diversity management, social psychology, and contact hypothesis. Methodology. The researcher collected data from 396 parishioners of six multiethnic/multicongregational parishes of the diocese of Orange, California using his partially customized survey instrument, and analyzed them with both descriptive and inferential statistical techniques. Findings. The data analysis revealed that shared goals are the most significant predicator of the status of cooperation, and status inequality is an especially manifest issue among ethnic congregations. There is a positive correlation between the parishioners' cooperative attitude and their inter-ethnic contact. A positive relationship was also found between the parishioners' cooperation and both their parish identification and their ethnic congregation identification. In addition, there is a significant difference between parishioners of diverse positions within parish organization in displaying their inter-ethnic cooperation; however, no significant difference was found between parishioners from diverse ethnic groups. Implications and recommendations. The study results can take the theories of reference beyond their conventional contentions by suggesting a contextualization of social identification, the importance of ideological factor in diversity management, and the priority of affective dimension in social contact. Three specific recommendations regarding multiethnic ministry policy consisting of joint parish pastoral councils, fair resource reallocation, and diversity leadership development for priests and lay leaders were also proposed with the purpose of improving cooperative relationship among ethnic congregations. The study resulted in noteworthy findings, yet future research on the topic needs more creative designs and more advanced methodology to draw a clearer picture of the phenomenon. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: multiethnic parish cooperation, Catholics
MH:

TI: The measurement and consequences of interethnic ideology.
IN: Wolsko, Christopher Vladimir: U Colorado At Boulder, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(8-B), Feb 2002, pp. 3853.
AB: In contemporary U.S. society, arguments about the appropriate solutions for managing ethnic diversity and reducing prejudice have taken on many different forms, with many different ideals for society in mind. Utilizing survey data collected from a multiethnic sample of college students, the goals of the dissertation research were to measure endorsement various interethnic ideologies (or ideals for how an ethnically diverse society should optimally function), to determine what important variables predict endorsement of the ideologies, and to examine how these differing ideologies influence opinions about public policy. The research demonstrates that there are real differences between white and ethnic minority participants in group perceptions and in the construal of issues related to managing ethnic diversity. Relative to white participants, ethnic minority participants endorsed a multicultural ideology to a greater extent, saw greater cultural differences between ethnic groups, expressed more positive sentiments toward the ingroup, reported higher levels of Collective Self-Esteem, and were more likely to support prodiversity public policies. Also, the research demonstrates that those who adopt a multicultural ideology are able to positively value diversity-to see more differences between groups and to have more positive sentiments toward outgroups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Boys' masculinities in play: In dialogue with anti-violence teachers and students.
IN: Wang, Athena L. Y.: U British Columbia, Canada
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(8-A), Feb 2002, pp. 2724.
AB: Feminist and other scholars have begun to examine masculinity and boys' schooling, as well as the connection between masculinity and male violence. However, research that looks at anti-violence instructors' and their students' discussions about masculinity and male violence within the context of anti-violence education remains sparse. In addition, the limited work on boys' own views of masculinity has focused primarily on White boys' experiences with hegemonic masculinity. This latter research is also Australian, British, and American, with little in the Canadian context. The purpose of this study is to explore, through semi-structured interviews, the talk of a small multiethnic sample of anti-violence teachers, boys, and girls on masculinity and male violence within the context of their gender, culture, and "race." Twenty-six grade 10 students (12 male, 14 female) who completed a school-sponsored violence prevention program in two Canadian high schools and six (three male, three female) antiviolence instructors who taught the program were interviewed. All interviews were tape recorded and transcribed for analysis. Drawing on a feminist poststructuralist framework in my analysis, four main themes emerged. First, many boys played hegemonic masculinity in certain situations due to their perception that it was necessary, while engaging in non-oppressive masculinities in other situations. Second, girls not only reinforced, albeit sometimes unintentionally, boys' hegemonic masculinity talk and practices, but many also struggled with challenging a dominant image of manhood. Third, "race" and culture were found to play a significant role in considerations of masculinity. Fourth, everyone's talk revealed the connection between hegemonic masculinity and male violence. The findings from this study suggest that drawing on feminist poststructuralism in developing a framework for conceptualizing masculinity would serve as a useful tool in teaching anti-violence programs to diverse groups of boys (and girls). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: masculinity, male violence, gender differences, cross cultural differences, racial differences

TI: Ethnic pride, biculturalism, and drug use norms of urban American Indian adolescents. [References].
AU:
Kulis, Stephen

Napoli, Maria

Marsiglia, Flavio Francisco
IN:
Kulis, Stephen: Arizona State U, Dept of Sociology, Tempe, AZ, US
Napoli, Maria: Arizona State U, School of Social Work, Tempe, AZ, US
Marsiglia, Flavio Francisco: Arizona State U, School of Social Work, Tempe, AZ, US
SO: Social Work Research. Vol.26(2), Jun 2002, pp. 101-112.
AB: This study examined how strength of ethnic identity, multiethnic identity, and other indicators of biculturalism relate to the drug use norms of urban American Indian middle school students. The article distinguishes categories of norms that may affect drug use. Regression analysis of self-reports by 434 American Indian seventh graders (aged 11-15 yrs) attending middle schools in a large southwestern US city indicates that students who had a more intense sense of ethnic pride adhered more strongly to certain antidrug norms than those who did not. Whereas American Indian students with better grades in school held consistently stronger antidrug norms, there were few differences by gender, socioeconomic status, or age. These results have implications in social work practice for better understanding and strengthening the protective aspects of American Indian culture in drug prevention efforts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Preventing early adolescent substance use: A family-centered strategy for the public middle school. [References].

SO: Prevention Science. Vol.3(3), Sep 2002, pp. 191-201.
AB: The Adolescent Transitions Program (ATP) promotes student adjustment and reduces risk within a public school setting, focusing primarily on parenting practices using a tiered, multilevel prevention strategy. A description is given of the program, levels of engagement, and intervention effects. Within each school, multiethnic students (N = 672; sixth graders; 52% male) and their families were randomly assigned at the individual level to a control condition or the ATP intervention. Analyses focus on the longitudinal effects of the ATP intervention on self-reported substance use through middle school and the 1st year of high school (Grades 6, 7, 8, and 9). Levels of engagement in the selected and indicated interventions were somewhat less than expected. Despite relatively low levels of engagement, the intervention reduced initiation of substance use in both at-risk and typically developing students. These findings are discussed with respect to lessons learned about parent engagement, optimizing strategies for schoolwide implementation, and the promise of embedding family interventions within the public school ecology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Learning, life history, and productivity: Children's lives in the Okavango Delta, Botswana. [References].
CQ: Bock, John: California State U, Dept of Anthropology, Fullerton, CA, US, 92834-6846, jbock@fullerton.edu
IN: Bock, John: California State U, Dept of Anthropology, Fullerton, CA, US
SO: Human Nature. Vol.13(2), 2002, pp. 161-197.
AB: Investigated influences of environment, parenting, demography, and economy on the activities of children in Botswana, and their roles in family and society. Subjects comprised 10 children (aged 3-8 yrs), 15 youth (aged 9-18 yrs), 11 adults (aged 19-45 yrs), and 8 older adults (aged 45+ yrs) residing in a multiethnic community in the Okavango Delta, Botswana. Collected data included behavioral observation, experimental test data concerning ability to do productive tasks, and household demographic and economic data. Results show that development of adult competency in specific tasks entailed a step-like relationship between growth- and experience-based forms of embodied capital in the ontogeny of ability acquisition. There was a trade-off between the acquisition of experience-based embodied capital in the form of skills and knowledge, and immediate productivity among children. Time allocation to these alternatives was primarily determined by short- and long-term costs and benefits to parents of investment in children's embodied capital. Availability of laborers and overall labor requirements of the household were both major determinants of investment in alternate forms of embodied capital and resulting variation in children's time allocation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Personality change over 40 years of adulthood: Hierarchical linear modeling analyses of two longitudinal samples. [References].
AU:
Helson, Ravenna

Jones, Constance

Kwan, Virginia S. Y
CQ: Helson, Ravenna: Inst of Personality & Social Research, 4243 Tolman Hall, MC 5050, Berkeley, CA, US, 94720-5050, helson@socrates.berkeley.edu
IN:
Helson, Ravenna: U California, Inst of Personality & Social Research, Berkeley, CA, US
Jones, Constance: California State U, Dept of Psychology, Fresno, CA, US
Kwan, Virginia S. Y.: U California, Inst of Personality & Social Research, Berkeley, CA, US
SO: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.83(3), Sep 2002, pp. 752-766.
AB: Normative personality change over 40 years was shown in 2 longitudinal cohorts with hierarchical linear modeling of California Psychological Inventory data obtained at multiple times between ages 21-75. Although themes of change and the paucity of differences attributable to gender and cohort largely supported findings of multiethnic cross-sectional samples, the authors also found much quadratic change and much individual variability. The form of quadratic change supported predictions about the influence of period of life and social climate as factors in change over the adult years: Scores on Dominance and Independence peaked in the middle age of both cohorts, and scores on Responsibility were lowest during peak years of the culture of individualism. The idea that personality change is most pronounced before age 30 and then reaches a plateau received no support. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: personality change, individual variability, normative personality, longitudinal samples

TI: The process of cultural competence in the delivery of health care services: A model of care. [References].
IN: Campinha-Bacote, Josepha: Transcultural C.A.R.E., Cincinnati, OH, US
SO: Journal of Transcultural Nursing. Vol.13(3), Jul 2002, pp. 181-184.
AB: Notes that several models of service care delivery have emerged to meet the challenges of providing health care to our growing multiethnic world. This article presents the author's model of cultural competence in health care delivery: The Process of Cultural Competence in the Delivery of Health-care Services. This model views cultural competence as the ongoing process in which the health care provider continuously strives to achieve the ability to effectively work within the cultural context of the client (individual, family, community). This ongoing process involves the integration of cultural awareness, cultural knowledge, cultural skill, cultural encounters, and cultural desire. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: health care delivery, cultural competence, model of care

TI: Pathways from family economic conditions to adolescents' distress: Supportive parenting, stressors outside the family and deviant peers. [References].
AU:
Barrera, Manuel Jr.

Prelow, Hazel M

Dumka, Larry E

Gonzales, Nancy A

Knight, George P

Michaels, Marcia L

Roosa, Mark W

Tein, Jenn Yun
CQ: Barrera, Manuel, Jr.: Arizona State U, Psychology Dept, Box 871104, Tempe, AZ, US, 85287-1104, Manuel.Barrera@asu.edu
IN:
Barrera, Manuel: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
Prelow, Hazel M.: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
Dumka, Larry E.: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
Gonzales, Nancy A.: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
Knight, George P.: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
Michaels, Marcia L.: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
Roosa, Mark W.: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
Tein, Jenn Yun: Arizona State U, Tempe, AZ, US
SO: Journal of Community Psychology. Vol.30(2), Mar 2002, pp. 135-152.
AB: Economic hardship is a stressor that affects large numbers of children and their families. This study estimated a model that included pathways linking economic conditions to the internalizing and externalizing symptoms of a multiethnic sample of urban adolescents. Similar to other prominent models, this model included parental distress and parenting as key constructs, but the expanded ecological model also included stressors outside the family and adolescents' associations with deviant peers as possible explanatory factors. Data from 300 adolescents and their parents were consistent with a model that showed linkages between economic conditions, parental depressive symptoms, supportive parenting, and internalizing symptoms. Stressors outside the family were associated with deviant peer affiliations which, in turn, predicted internalizing and externalizing symptoms. The implications of these findings for understanding economic conditions' influence on adolescents' mental health are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: economic hardship, adolescents, families, distress, parenting stressors, deviant peers
