TI: Ethnicity and ethnically "mixed" identity in Belize: A study of primary school-age children.
IN: Haug, Sarah Woodbury: Pennsylvania State U, Anthropology Dept, PA, US
SO: Anthropology & Education Quarterly. Vol.29(1), Mar 1998, pp. 44-67.
OL: Council on Anthropology and Education Newsletter, Council on Anthropology and Education Quarterly
AB: This article focuses on the ethnic identity of children in Belize. Belizean nationalism, as taught in the primary schools, is both pan-ethnic and multiethnic. However, because the increasingly widespread practice of ethnic mixing is unacknowledged, there is a discrepancy between what is taught in school and the daily life of children.The overt intent is to recognize and celebrate difference; however, the result has been to silence children's voices. Children, primarily between ages 7 and 11, and teachers were interviewed concerning ethnic identity over 2 school years. Tests, drawings, and papers in which notions of ethnicity were a part were collected. Classes were observed everyday. Teachers reported that 68 out of 230 were of mixed ethnicity. In day-to-day circumstances of school, teachers did not label children by more than 1 ethnic group. 58 out of 68 of the ethnically mixed Ss were interviewed. The results are (1) 10 Ss identified themselves as 2 ethnic groups, (2) 5 Ss said they were mixed without specifying an ethnic group, (3) 39 Ss chose a single ethnic label, and (4) 4 remaining Ss said "I don't know." No clear pattern emerged that could predict what ethnic identity a child of mixed ethnicity would choose. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ethnic identity, ethnically mixed children, Belize
MH: *Ethnic Identity

TI: Of Kwanzaa, Cinco de Mayo, and whispering: The need for intercultural education.

SO: Anthropology & Education Quarterly. Vol.28(4), Dec 1997, pp. 574-592.
OL: Council on Anthropology and Education Newsletter, Council on Anthropology and Education Quarterly
AB: Multicultural education aims to improve understanding among students of different ethnic groups, but it can lessen intergroup conflict only if it is implemented systematically. In multiethnic school settings, the relationships among students of different "minority" groups are problematic; conflicts need to be both understood and addressed if multicultural education is to succeed. In one inner-city California high school, the celebration of Kwanzaa leads to exclusion and isolation, and the speaking of Spanish in the classroom sparks conflict and resentments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Ethnic identity development of internationally adopted children and adolescents: Implications for family therapists.
IN: Friedlander, Myrna L.: State U New York, Dept of Educational & Counseling Psychology, Albany, NY, US
SO: Journal of Marital and Family Therapy. Vol.25(1), Jan 1999, pp. 43-60.
OL: Journal of Marriage and Family Counseling
PU: American Assn for Marriage & Family Therapy; US
OC: American Association of Marriage and Family Counselors, US; Blackwell Publishing, United Kingdom; Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd., United Kingdom
AB: The life story of the internationally adopted child tends to be an emotional one. How the story is told and retold in the family can have lasting consequences for the child's adjustment and well-being. In telling the story, parents are faced with a unique challenge: To what extent is it desirable to encourage their children, who already struggle with identity issues related to adoption, to identify with their cultures of origin? Therapists working on these issues with multiethnic adoptive families can find little guidance in the family systems literature. To fill this gap, the present article reviews the literature on racial/ethnic identity development and the available research on ethnic identification, self-esteem, and the psychological adjustment of cross-ethnically adopted children and adolescents. Implications for practice include developmental considerations, identifying children and families at risk, and recommendations for those in need of intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: racial/ethnic identity development & self-esteem & psychological adjustment, cross-ethnically adopted children & adolescents, implications for family therapy

*Emotional Adjustment

*Family Therapy

*Interracial Adoption

*Self Esteem

Adopted Children

Psychosocial Development

TI: Learning about bilingual, multicultural organizing.
AU:
Heskin, Allan D

Heffner, Robert A
IN: Heskin, Allan D.: U California, Graduate School of Architecture & Urban Planning, Los Angeles, US
SO: Journal of Applied Behavioral Science. Vol.23(4), 1987, pp. 525-541.
AB: Proposes that for organizing to succeed in bilingual, multicultural environments, 3 roles (organizer, interpreter, and multicultural mediator) must be filled. It is considered difficult and unwise to have the functions of all 3 roles filled by the same person, as this can lead to conflicts of interest and a concentration of power in one person that can threaten democratic processes and lead to gatekeeping. The case of the organization of a federation of 5 housing cooperatives in a multiethnic district of Los Angeles is presented to examine how residents and the cooperatives' leadership grappled with the organization problems and learned to solve them through recognizing the importance of the organizers, interpreters, and multicultural mediators and the need for keeping these roles separate. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Food insecurity is the limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate and safe foods, or limited or uncertain ability to acquire acceptable foods in socially acceptable ways. This study uses fixed response and textual data obtained through in-depth interviews with adults 70 years and older from a multiethnic population in rural North Carolina to examine the incidence of food insecurity and how older adults experience food insecurity and maintain food security. The authors interviewed 145 elders up to five times over the course of one year. Responses to standard food insecurity questions indicate that only 12% of older adults experience food insecurity. However, analysis of textual data reveals common themes concerning food insecurity that suggest that these questions may underestimate the number of rural elders who are food insecure and not tap the potential vulnerability of others who are dependent on precarious nutritional self-management strategies to meet their needs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Intercultural marriage and family: Beyond the racial divide. [References].
IN: McFadden, John: U South Carolina, Dept of Educational Psychology, Columbia, SC, US
SO: The Family Journal. Vol.9(1), Jan 2001, pp. 39-42.
AB: Discusses family therapy issues relevant to multiracial and multiethnic marriages and families. Though multiracial marriages are more common in the US than ever before, many multiracial children are faced with discrimination from all races, leaving them to feel like outsiders. It behooves interracial couples to recognize at an early stage in their relationship that offspring from their marriage will not only be racially mixed but also will be required to adjust to being identified as an "other." Interracial couples are confronted with finding ways to capture and maintain a sense of empowerment and cultural dignity. Counseling professionals have a responsibility to prepare individuals to live and work cross-culturally; counselors need to avoid the stereotyping that accompanies many intercultural marriages and families. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: The assessment of ethnic identity in a diverse urban youth population. [References].
AU:
Yancey, Antronette K

Aneshensel, Carol S

Driscoll, Anne K
IN: Yancey, Antronette K.: U California, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO: Journal of Black Psychology. Vol.27(2), May 2001, pp. 190-208.
AB: Examined the assessment of ethnic identity in a multiethnic, probability sample of 847 urban adolescents using the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM). The concept of ethnic identity captures the incorporation of ethnicity into self-perception, providing a pivotal link to the social psychological consequences of minority status. A more generalizable psychometric examination of an instrument used extensively in research on African American youth to capture this phenomenon is warranted. This investigation sought to identify revisions of the MEIM that would render it more useful for interethnic and intraethnic comparisons, utilizing a sample more heterogeneous and representative than those of prior studies. Item and exploratory factor analyses indicate that 10 of 14 items can be combined into a short form (MEIM-S) that measures aspects of this phenomenon that are comparable across ethnic groups, and identify two factors. In general, Whites score significantly lower than African Americans, Asian Americans, and Latinos, whose scores tend to be similar to one another consistent with the literature on interethnic variation in the salience of ethnic identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Ethnic identity among monoracial and multiracial early adolescents.
AU:
Spencer, Michael S

Icard, Larry D

Harachi, Tracy W

Catalano, Richard F

Oxford, Monica
IN: Spencer, Michael S.: U Michigan, School of Social Work, Ctr on Poverty, Risk, & Mental Health, Ann Arbor, MI, US
SO: The Journal of Early Adolescence. Vol.20(4), Nov 2000, pp. 365-387.
AB: Examined a measure of ethnic identity, the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM; J. S. Phinney, 1992), with a sample of 2,184 11-15 yr olds who self-identified with a single race (monoracial, n = 1,812) or with 2 or more racial or ethnic groups (multiracial, n = 372). The psychometric properties and mean differences on the MEIM for White, monoracial minority, and multiracial early adolescents were investigated. Principal components and multigroup confirmatory factor analysis were used to explore and confirm the factor structure of the MEIM items. Two factors were identified: (1) identification and (2) exploration. Identification was represented by items that reflect a sense of belonging and pride in an individual's ethnic group. Exploration was represented by items that characterize a search for ethnic group identity and participation in ethnic practices. Results show reliabilities for the 2 subscales were alpha = .84 for identification and alpha = .76 for exploration. Also, the results indicate that most individuals from monoracial minority groups and multiracial subgroups scored similarly on overall ethnic identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Motivation and learning environment differences between resilient and nonresilient Latino middle school students.
AU:
Waxman, Hersholt C

Huang, Shwu-yong L

Padron, Yolanda N
IN: Waxman, Hersholt C.: U Houston, Coll of Education, TX, US
SO: Hispanic Journal of Behavioral Sciences. Vol.19(2), May 1997, pp. 137-155.
AB: This study tries to address the problems of Latino students by drawing on two distinct and emerging theoretical frameworks: (a) educationally resilient students and (b) classroom learning environments. The authors compared the motivation and learning environment of 60 resilient and 60 nonresilient Latino middle school students from a multiethnic metropolitan city located in the south central region of the United States. The multivariate analysis and univariate post hoc tests revealed that resilient students had significantly higher perceptions of involvement, satisfaction, academic self-concept, and achievement motivation than nonresilient students. The discriminant function analysis revealed that the variables of academic aspirations, involvement, academic self-concept, expectations for high school graduation, not being held back in school, and satisfaction were related most highly to the overall discriminant function. Results are discussed in relation to previous work on educational resilience and to implications for improving the education of students at risk of failure. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
ID: academic motivation & aspiration & classroom learning environment in mathematics & psychosocial factors & demographic characteristics, resilient vs nonresilient Latino middle school students

TI: Theoretical antecedents to HIV risk perception.
AU:
Brown, Emma J

Outlaw, Freida H

Simpson, Edith M
IN: Brown, Emma J.: U Central Florida, School of Nursing, Orlando, FL, US
SO: Journal of the American Psychiatric Nurses Association. Vol.6(6), Dec 2000, pp. 177-182.
OC: Mosby Publishing Company, US; Sage Publications, US
AB: Examined HIV risk perceptions of 2 discordant samples and theorized about possible antecedents to their HIV risk perception. The multiethnic samples consisted of 286 female college students (aged 18-21 yrs) and 101 female HIV seronegative injecting drug users (aged 18-45 yrs). Secondary analysis of 2 data sets was conducted for this comparative descriptive study. The results show that approximately 90% of college students and 60.4% of injecting drug users appraised their HIV risk as nil or small. Injecting drug users were 3.1 times more likely than college students to perceive some risk of HIV infection and 28.8 times more likely to perceive a large or great risk. Both samples minimized their HIV risk. It is concluded that HIV risk perception appears to be based on cognitive antecedents in addition to risky HIV-related sexual and drug-use behavior. It is theorized that both samples used the cognitive coping strategies of denial, distancing, and downward comparison to minimize their HIV risk perception. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: HIV risk perceptions & theoretical antecedents, female college students vs injecting drug users

TI: Can diversity and community coexist in higher education? The case of Heritage College.
IN: Ross, Kathleen Anne: Heritage Coll, WA, US
SO: American Behavioral Scientist. Vol.42(6), Mar 1999, pp. 1024-1040.
AB: A college president reviews the efforts of one small multiethnic 4-year college to improve intergroup relations in light of research concerning ethnic stereotypes. Research shows that positive intergroup contacts must have certain characteristics in order to reduce stereotypes and negative intergroup relations. Heritage College was founded in 1982 in a rural, poor multiethnic county of Washington State that includes the Yakama Indian reservation. After describing the negative stereotypes that exist between Native Americans, Mexican Americans, and Euro-Americans in the service area of the college, the author describes five approaches that are used at the college to reduce negative stereotypes and to build community: a strong mission and vision statement; consistent, conscious, official portrayal of positive images of all groups; the use of "stories" as a major communication mechanism; development of problem-solving techniques; and consistent campus work on the skills of intercultural communications. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: approaches to reduce negative stereotypes & build community at multiethnic 4 yr college, Native American & Mexican American & Euro-American college students

AB: Examines how differential ethnic, territorial, and state identities were realigned in Latvia during and after the collapse of the Soviet Union. It is argued that ethnic nominalism, the ascription of ethnopolitical identity to whole groups, is a misleading notion. The example of Latvia suggests that identity embraces multiple dimensions and that the pertinence of identity is strongly contextual. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: A note on ethnicity in humor and art therapy.
SO: Art Therapy. Vol.11(3), 1994, pp. 214-215.
AB: Presents examples of the value of humor in an art therapy group with Black and Hispanic psychiatric inpatients in the discharge phase of treatment. Meetings were held every week, and every other week the topic was humor. The examples were of a 27-yr-old Black female dually diagnosed with schizophrenia and polysubstance abuse, a 49-yr-old Black man, and 20-yr-old Black man. The spontaneous examples of ethnic humor told during therapy depicted the patients' struggle to establish his/her own identity and be confirmed as a worthwhile and separate person. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Transcultural responses to aesthetic and therapeutic experience: An ethological approach.
SO: Art Therapy. Vol.11(3), 1994, pp. 194-199.
AB: Suggests that ethological techniques of observation can provide artists, critics, and clinicians with a tool for discerning aspects of psyche. The author describes observations of the group dynamics and culturally diverse responses of multiethnic people interacting with an installation sculpture by J. Dubuffet in the garden of the Kroller-Muller Rijksmuseum in the Netherlands. The sculpture modulates levels of stimulation, suspends rules of perception, and dissolves familiar approaches to structure; the sculpture invites random exploration and enables visitors to exercise their own capacities for play, ritual, and associations that maximize personal responses. The sculpture's value applies to the realm of therapeutic discourse. Examples of the use of interactive designs for prompting aesthetic and therapeutic responses in art therapy with clients from varying racial and SES backgrounds are presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Clinicians' definitions of ethnically sensitive therapy. [References].
AU:
Zayas, Luis H

Torres, Luis R

Malcolm, Joan

DesRosiers, Fabiana S
IN: Zayas, Luis H.: Fordham U, Graduate School of Social Service, Tarrytown, NY, US
SO: Professional Psychology: Research and Practice. Vol.27(1), Feb 1996, pp. 78-82.
AB: A survey of 150 nonminority psychologists and social workers who provide clinical services in multiethnic urban institutional settings was conducted to explore how they define ethnically sensitive therapy. Underlying the investigation was the assumption that how clinicians define ethnically sensitive therapy reflects their attitudes and influences the efforts they make to operationalize their definition in therapy. Results show that clinicians' definitions fall along a continuum with four overlapping dimensions that emphasize (a) being aware of the existence of differences, (b) having knowledge of the client's culture, (c) distinguishing between culture and pathology in assessment, and (d) taking culture into account in therapy. The dimensions may reflect a developmental process in how clinicians arrive at conceptualizations of ethnically sensitive therapy that influence their behaviors in the treatment encounter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

TI: Valuing human diversity: Counseling multiracial and multiethnic children. [References].
IN: Looby, Eugenie Joan: Mississippi State U, Coll of Education, MS, US
SO: Sandhu, Daya Singh [Ed]. (2001). Elementary school counseling in the new millennium.  (pp. 193-207). xxv, 296 pp. Alexandria, VA, US: American Counseling Association; US.
AB: (from the chapter) Addresses the needs of multiracial children. The author defines and clarifies terms and explains racial identity classification of multiracial children. The history of interracial families in the US, the "one drop rule," and demographic trends are discussed. Prevailing myths are examined and advantages and disadvantages of a multiracial status are discussed. Literature on identity development of multiracial children and models of multiracial identity development are presented. Community imperatives to promote healthy identity development of multiracial children are delineated. Included are those by school counselors and other helping professionals, parents, and school (including activities and curriculum), and educational personnel. TI: Elementary school counseling in the new millennium.
IN: Sandhu, Daya Singh: U Louisville, Dept of Educational & Counseling Psychology, KY, US
SO: (2001). Elementary school counseling in the new millennium. xxv, 296 pp. Alexandria, VA, US: American Counseling Association; US.
AB: (from the cover) Examines primary issues that affect elementary school-age children. The book addresses the social and cultural complexities that influence children's behavior and describes what can be done to help them succeed in a rapidly changing world. The authors present counseling program strategies, which are designed both to meet the special needs of K-6 students and to maximize their potential by promoting personal growth, self-determination, and self-respectibility. Topics discussed include creative problem solving, play therapy and use of the creative arts in counseling, parental collaboration, trauma counseling, resiliency and coping strategies, the concerns of multiethnic and multiracial children, sexual orientation, spirituality, and bullying. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: A micro-level analysis of developmental, parenting, and family milieu variables that differentiate stress-resilient and stress-affected children. [References].
AU:
Kilmer, Ryan P

Cowen, Emory L

Wyman, Peter A
CQ: Kilmer, Ryan P.: U North Carolina at Charlotte, Dept of Psychology, 9201 University City Boulevard, Charlotte, NC, US, 28223-0001, rpkilmer@email.uncc.edu
IN:
Kilmer, Ryan P.: U Rochester, Rochester, NY, US
Cowen, Emory L.: U Rochester, Rochester, NY, US
Wyman, Peter A.: U Rochester, Rochester, NY, US
SO: Journal of Community Psychology. Vol.29(4), Jul 2001, pp. 391-416.
AB: Used microanalysis to identify active, discriminating components of global parent interview variables previously shown to differentiate stress-resilient (SR) and stress-affected (SA) outcomes in independent samples (4th-6th and 2nd-3rd grade) of 306 multiethnic, highly stressed, urban children. The in-depth interview assessed caregiving environment and early child development. On item-level t tests for the pooled sample, 36 of 144 items differentiated the groups. Discriminant function analysis identified a cluster of 9 sensitive items that correctly classified 81.7% of children as SR or SA. Factor analysis of the 36 items identified a 4-factor solution: Child Adjustment, Early Temperament, Parent-Child Relationship, and Developmental Milestones; SR parents exceeded SAs on each. Structurally comparable analyses using only Sample 2 and including the second interview's new measures, replicated and extended findings from the pooled sample. Overall, study findings enhance understanding of resilience and testify to the merit of using a microanalytic approach in this research area. Implications for streamlining existing measures and for future research directions are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: stress, resilience, parenting, caregiving environment, family, early childhood development
MH:
*Childrearing Practices

*Early Childhood Development

*Stress

SO: American Journal of Public Health. Vol.91(9), Sep 2001, pp. 1435-1442.
AB: Examined the association between psychological distress and menopause among African-American, White, Chinese, Hispanic, and Japanese females. 10,374 females (aged 40-55 yrs) completed surveys concerning: (1) menstrual regularity in the previous year; (2) psychosocial factors; (3) health; (4) somatic-psychological symptoms; and (5) psychological distress, which was defined as feeling tense, depressed, and irritable in the previous 2 wks. Ss were classified as experiencing natural premenopause, perimenopause, or postmenopause. Results show that rates of psychological distress were highest in early perimenopause Ss and lowest in premenopause and postmenopause Ss. In comparison with premenopausal Ss, early perimenopausal Ss were at a greater risk of distress, even after controlling for vasomotor and sleep symptoms. Odds of distress were significantly higher for Whites than for the other Ss. It is concluded that psychological distress is associated with irregular menses in midlife. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: The many faces of self: Ego and ethnic identity. [References].
CQ: Branch, Curtis W., 70 Anderson Street, Suite 1F, Hackensack, NJ, US, 07601, cwb@columbia.edu
IN: Branch, Curtis W.: Columbia U, Coll of Physicians & Surgeons, NY, US
SO: The Journal of Genetic Psychology: Research and Theory on Human Development. Vol.162(4), Dec 2001, pp. 412-429.
OL: The Pedagogical Seminary, The Pedagogical Seminary and Journal of Genetic Psychology
AB: Examined how adolescents come to develop a sense of ethnic identity. The author examined ethnic identity development as a process that occurs simultaneously with the development of ego identity and attitudes toward groups other than one's own. A multiethnic sample of 297 adolescents and young adults (aged 13-26 yrs) completed the Extended Objective Measure of Ego Identity Scale Revision 2, the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure, and the Other Group Orientation Scale. An Age x Ethnic Group x Gender experimental design was used to determine whether these factors contributed differently to ethnic identity and ego identity. Analyses showed significant differences in the level of ethnic identity development among the ethnic groups. More pronounced age differences were found at the lower levels of ego identity development than at the more advanced levels. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ethnic identity development, ego identity development, the self
MH:
*Ego Identity

*Ethnic Identity

SO: CJNR: Canadian Journal of Nursing Research. Vol.33(3), Dec 2001, pp. 31-46.
AB: Examined mothers' perceptions of breastfeeding information and support received from hospital- and community-based health professionals. 108 first-time breastfeeding mothers (aged 17-42 yrs) residing within a multiethnic Canadian community completed questionnaires 3 wks postpartum concerning impressions of breastfeeding support received from hospitals and community health services, the degree to which recommended practices in support of breastfeeding were followed during their hospital stay, and perceptions of the types and sources of breastfeeding information. Results show that approximately two-thirds of subjects (Ss) were born outside of Canada. Immigrant Ss were more likely to report that their breastfeeding infant was given supplemental water or formula during their hospital stay and that they were provided with formula samples upon discharge. Immigrant Ss were more likely to receive breastfeeding help by community-care staff. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: mother perceptions, breastfeeding information, support, hospital personnel, community health professionals

*Breast Feeding

*Health Knowledge

TI: Multiethnic parentage: A potentially valuable resource in the quest for social cohesion. [References].
IN: Barnes, Diane: U New South Wales, School of Social Work, Sydney, NSW, Australia
SO: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work: Innovation in Theory, Research & Practice. Vol.10(3), 2001, pp. 31-48.
AB: Studied the personal ethnic identity of 13 18-33 yr old people of multi-cultural/ethnic/racial parentage living in Australia, and examined connections between their identity resolution and social relationships. Results of semi-structured interviews are discussed in terms of the search for an ethnic identity, sources of influence on ethnic identity, and orientation to the ethnicity of others. From the findings, hypotheses are formulated concerning the relationship between identity resolution and ease of bridging ethnic divides in social contexts. Implications of the findings for social work practice and the challenge of enhancing social cohesion are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: personal ethnic identity, multiethnic parentage, multiracial parentage, identity resolution, social influences, ethnic attitudes

TI: Racial and ethic inequality in homeownership and housing equity. [References].
CQ: Flippen, Chenoa A.: Duke U, Ctr for Demographic Studies, 2117 Campus Drive, Durham, NC, US, 27708-0408, chenoa@cds.duke.edu
IN: Flippen, Chenoa A.: Duke U, Durham, NC, US
SO: The Sociological Quarterly. Vol.42(2), Spr 2001, pp. 121-149.
AB: Wealth inequality, particularly in housing, has received increased attention in recent years for its importance to racial and ethnic stratification. Yet, while we know a fair amount about Black-White wealth inequality, many questions remain regarding sources of Hispanic asset inequality. This article addresses this gap by examining racial and ethnic inequality in homeownership and housing equity among the preretirement population (aged 51-61 yrs) in the US. Results support a stratification perspective of inequality for both Blacks and Hispanics; even after accounting for numerous life-cycle, resource, and social-psychological considerations, Blacks and Hispanics continue to lag significantly behind Whites in housing wealth. While Hispanics initially appear better off than Blacks with respect to housing, this is largely a function of their more favorable family structure. Important differences between blacks and Hispanics in the main contributors to housing inequality highlight the need to take a more multiethnic perspective on wealth stratification. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: The effects of a prepracticum educational module on self-efficacy, self-esteem, anxiety, and performance.
IN: Cara, Elizabeth D.: The Fielding Inst., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(2-B), Aug 2001, pp. 1069.
AB: The effect of a prepracticum educational module based on information from cross-theoretical, developmental models of supervision was evaluated by measuring beginning practicum students': (a) self-efficacy immediately after the education; (b) anxiety and self-esteem prior to, midway during, and at the end of the practicum; and (c) performance at the end of the practicum. The sample consisted of 92 occupational therapy undergraduate students whose ages ranged from 21-52. Thirty-six percent identified themselves as Hispanic, Asian, Filipino, Asian-Indian, African-American, or multiethnic. Literature was reviewed concerning education, clinical training, self-efficacy, and developmental models of supervision. The educational module consisting of education and self-management strategies regarding trainees' hypothesized developmental cognitive and affective stages was given to 48 students 3 weeks prior to the practicum experience. It was hypothesized that when compared with a similar control group, the experimental group would receive: (a) lower scores in anxiety at the middle and ending periods of the practicum, as measured by the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) (Spielberger, 1983); (b) higher scores in self-esteem at the middle and ending periods of the practicum as measured by the Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventory (SEI) (Coopersmith, 1981); and (c) higher scores in performance at the end of the practicum, as measured by the Occupational Therapy Final practicum. Competency Evaluation (FPCE) (San Jose State University). In addition, prepracticum strength of self-efficacy was hypothesized to predict lower anxiety and higher practicum performance. Analysis of variance and multiple regression were used to analyze the data. The results did not support the main hypotheses; there were no significant group differences in self-esteem, anxiety, self-efficacy, or performance. Both groups showed nonsignificant trends toward increasing self-esteem and decreasing anxiety during the practicum. Self-esteem was inversely, significantly related to state and trait anxiety prior to and at the ending periods of the practicum. Self-efficacy was inversely, significantly related to trait anxiety prior to, at the middle, and ending periods, but was inversely, significantly related to state anxiety only at the end of the practicum. Implications are presented regarding the relationship of self-esteem, anxiety, and self-efficacy in beginning practicum students. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: prepracticum educational module, self efficacy, self esteem, anxiety, performance

TI: An examination of television and real life experience as sources of children's race schemas.
IN: Mancuso, Allegra Concetta: U California, Los Angeles, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(2-A), Aug 2001, pp. 461.
AB: This study investigated fourth-, fifth-, and sixth-graders' schemas about African Americans and how those schemas might have been affected by their experience viewing African Americans portrayed on television and by their level of cross-race interaction in real life. A total of 66 White boys and girls from mostly-White and racially and ethnically mixed, middle-class, Catholic schools completed questionnaires, chose among photographs via computer, and took pail in an interview. Children's television viewing frequency, television familiarity, perceived reality of general television, perceived reality of African Americans on television, schematicity, schemas for African Americans in real life or on television, and level of cross-race interaction were assessed. Results showed that children thought about African Americans on television and in real life in ways that were different from the ways in which social scientists and television critics have thought about them. Children's schemas for African Americans were composed primarily of character traits and of comparisons of African Americans to others or to themselves, and were less tv-like than was expected. Children spoke about African Americans in mostly positive ways, and even when their descriptions included stereotypes or attitudes that were negative, they also often included ideas that were "redeeming." There was little support for the idea that children's schemas for African Americans on television and for African Americans in real life would be different from each other. There was little support for the notion that level of cross-race experience, amount of high- and regular-quality television viewing, and perceived realism of television and of African Americans on television would be associated with the stereotypedness of children's schemas for African Americans. There was no support for the notion that children for whom race was an important dimension in decision making had more developed schemas than children for whom race was not an important dimension in decision making. That this study was conducted in the highly multiethnic, multiracial city of Los Angeles might have influenced the results. It would be important to study further the effects of television's limited range of and mostly stereotyped portrayals of African Americans on children's schemas, perhaps in a location which is less ethnically and racially mixed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: television, real life cross race interaction, race schemas, children

TI: Culture and epistemology: An investigation of different patterns in epistemological beliefs across cultures.
IN: Tasaki, Katsuya: U Hawaii, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(2-A), Aug 2001, pp. 463.
AB: The purpose of this study is to develop a causal model to investigate the effects of culturally conditioned self-construals and higher education on epistemological beliefs. In recent years, a reasonable number of studies have documented substantive relationships between students' epistemological beliefs and learning. The underlying assumption in epistemological belief studies is that individuals with more sophisticated epistemological beliefs may have different learning and problem solving behaviors from those with less sophisticated beliefs. While the influence of epistemological beliefs on learning behaviors has been identified, few studies have explored cultural variability in epistemological beliefs. Using independent and interdependent self-construals (Markus & Kitayama, 1991) as cultural indicators and a five-factor epistemic model delineated by Schommer (1990), this study examined how culturally conditioned self-construals affected epistemological beliefs. A multiethnic sample of 692 undergraduate and graduate students in the United States participated in this study. Through a series of confirmatory factor analyses, the originally hypothesized five-factor model was reduced to a four-factor model. A structural equation model subsequently identified that all of the four epistemological belief factors are significantly and positively affected by "educational level," and are significantly and negatively influenced by "interdependent self-construal." "Independent self-construal" was observed to have significant and positive effects on epistemological factors, "certainty of knowledge" and "omniscient authority." These results suggest that the particular kinds of epistemological beliefs valued in American schools may be biased in favor of students with Western cultural backgrounds and against students with non-Western cultural backgrounds such as East Asian Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: cross cultural differences, epistemological beliefs, self construal
MH:
*Cross Cultural Differences

*Epistemology

*Self Perception
PO: Human. Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
JN: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences

TI: The Metisse model: Multiethnic womens' identity development and romantic relationships.
IN: Swanson, Angela Marie Jette: U Utah, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(9-B), Mar 2001, pp. 5032.
AB: The purpose of this qualitative study was to understand participant experiences with romantic relationships and identity development in order to create a theory that will contribute to the scarce literature concerning multiethnic women. Two general questions guiding the study included: (1) How do multiethnic women experience romantic relationships and the process of partner selection? and (2) how have race/ethnicity and identity development affected their romantic relationships and the choices they make concerning partner selection? Twelve multiethnic women participated in this study. Participants were diverse with regard to age, race, ethnicity, income level, education, and religious affiliation. Each woman participated in an in-depth, semistructured interview, as well as a shorter followup interview for purposes of clarification and confirmation. Six participants attended an optional focus group that lasted approximately 3 hours, and 5 participants provided documentary evidence such as letters, journals, and pictures. Data were analyzed using the grounded-theory method developed by Glaser and Strauss (1967). Results yielded the Metisse Model. The overarching theme that emerged from the data was Incongruent Internal and External Perceptions. Participants described their experiences with dissonant perceptions related to identity and romantic relationships. Incongruent perceptions affected all stages of ethnic identity development and experiences in romantic relationships. Within the overarching theme of Incongruent Internal and External Perceptions, two main categories emerged: Stages in the Process of Identity Development and Romantic Relationships in a Developmental Context. An affirmative, developmental model emerged and included 5 stages of multiethnic identity development: External Focus, Marginality, Exploration, Misperceived, and Internal Sense of Self. As participants experienced changes in their ethnic identity, they also experienced changes in their romantic relationships. Along with romantic relationship experiences that paralleled stages in ethnic identity development, participants reported a desire for their romantic partners to see them as they saw themselves, complex multiethnic women. Some participants also expressed a desire to be with partners who provided clues to others that allowed greater congruence between internal and external perceptions. However, participants agreed that partners who provided understanding and acceptance of their multiethnic heritages were more important than partners who allowed increased congruence. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: identity development, romantic relationships, multiethnicity, ethnic differences, women

TI: Toward an understanding of marathon-induced fatigue and, the phenomenological motives and meanings of perseverance under duress.
IN: Manuel, Mark Allen: Carlos Albizu U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4383.
AB: This study utilized the qualitative research design to better understand the phenomonological experiences of marathon induced exhaustion, motives for perseverance during exhaustion, personal goal variations, and idiosyncratic insights generated by the marathon experience. A heterogeneous multiethnic sample of 40 adult marathoners was interviewed with a seven item questionnaire. Subject responses were organized into Novice, Basic, Advanced, Champion, and National levels of marathon expertise in an effort to illuminate intra sample variations in the data. General themes related to marathon experiences, motives, and meanings among the five groups were generated and intragroup comparisons were discussed. The hypothesis that subjects would confirm interactive physical, emotional, and mental elements of fatigue during the marathon was validated. The hypothesis that over 50% of subjects would report personal experience or familiarity with "The Wall" as a discrete phenomenon within the marathon experience was also confirmed. The hypothesis that initial motives which impelled marathon training and participation would change during the course of the race was not confirmed. Instead, results indicated that underlying motives primarily related to mastery, competition, and social recognition remained operational. What changed under multidimensional duress were personal goals. Typically, various levels of perceived fatigue caused competitors to lower their personal goals as measured in finishing time, place, or percentile rank. The hypothesis that some competitors would encounter debilitating fatigue so intense that their motivation was to simply "survive" the marathon was also confirmed. Finally, the hypothesis that the marathon could be conceptualized as an arena which allows man to struggle with various changing levels of physical, psychological, and interpersonal needs was also confirmed by relating motives and experiences of marathoners to Maslow's theory of motivation. In summary, this effort provides a significant contribution to the field of sport psychology by providing qualitative insights regarding the intragroup variations of marathon experiences, motives, and meanings as a function of five levels of marathon expertise. (Abstract shortened by UMI.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: marathon, fatigue, perseverance, motives, personal goals, insights
MH:
*Fatigue

*Goals

*Persistence

*Walking

JN: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering

TI: Perceived parent support and ethnic identity related to the psychological adjustment of monoethnic and multiethnic Mexican-American/Spanish and White-American/Anglo adolescents.
IN: Corral, Carla Victoria: U California, Santa Barbara, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4396.
AB: The prevalence rate of mental disorders among children and adolescents is estimated to be at least 12% (Dougherty, Saxe, Cross, & Silverman, 1987; U.S. Congress, Office of Technology Assessment, 1991). With the hope of facilitating successful program development and reducing the number of adolescents who experience emotional and behavioral dysfunction, an increasing number of researchers have examined the risk and protective factors related to adolescent development and adjustment. In line with such research, this study examined two factors, perceived parent support and homogeneity of adolescent and perceived parent ethnic identification, and their association with adolescent psychological adjustment. The data used for this study were obtained as part of a longitudinal investigation conducted by the Tri-Ethnic Center. In 1995 and 1996, data were collected from high school students attending school districts in the southwestern U.S., one in an urban city (population = 500,000) and the other in a mid-sized city (population = 100,000). A total of 75 Mexican-American/Spanish students, 114 White-American/Anglo students, and 27 Multiethnic Mexican-American/Spanish and White-American/Anglo students aged 15 to 18 were included in this study. Findings indicated that perceived parent support was associated with the following psychological adjustment measures: Depression, Anger, Blame, Global Self-Esteem, and Social Self-Esteem. Adolescents who reported low perceived parent support indicated more depression than adolescents who reported medium low, medium high, or high perceived parent support. The same pattern was evident for the psychological adjustment scales measuring anger and blame. Other group differences were found in reports of feelings of anger and blame. Adolescents who indicated medium high perceived parent support reported more anger than adolescents who perceived high levels of parent support. Adolescents who reported medium low perceived parent support indicated more blame than adolescents who reported high perceived parent support. With respect to global self-esteem and social self-esteem, adolescents who perceived low parent support indicated lower global self-esteem and lower social self-esteem than adolescents who perceived medium low, medium high, or high parent support. In a secondary analysis, it was found that males reported more anxiety than did females. Implications for future research and practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: perceived parent support, ethnic identity, psychological adjustment, monoethnicity, multiethnicity, Mexican American Spanish adolescents, White American Anglo adolescents
MH:
*Emotional Adjustment

TI: Family narrative interactions involving girls with ADHD and typically developing school age girls.
IN: Asher, Holly Eva: U California, Berkeley, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(7-B), Jan 2001, pp. 3828.
AB: Personal storytelling within families was examined as a socializing practice in a multiethnic sample of families with school-age girls both with and without ADHD. Chief goals were to examine whether aspects of family narrative could distinguish ADHD from comparison girls and whether family narrative interactions could predict social competence generally, and in ADHD and comparison girls separately. Additionally, it was sought to link narrative process with developmental outcome to contribute to the validity of the Family Narrative Consortium's (FNC) assessment tool (Fiese et al., 1999). Three aspects of family Narrative Interaction were examined (Style, Coordination, and Confirmation) and peer social preference. Family narratives were videotaped for both positive and negative retellings of past events. Peer sociometric variables were obtained during a naturalistic research summer camp program. ADHD families were found to qualitatively differ from comparison families in Style and Coordination, At the individual, co-narrator level, both mothers and fathers of ADHD girls were significantly less likely to Confirm their child's contributions than were mothers and fathers in the comparison group. ADHD girls were not significantly more likely than comparison girls to disconfirm their parent's narrative contributions, but borderline significance was achieved. Overall, findings were more salient in the retelling of a negative event. This pattern held even when co-varying for the child's verbal skill. Of particular interest was the finding of a significant two-way interaction between group and type of narrative (positive vs. negative) for maternal Confirmation. When faced with the challenge of retelling a negative event, mothers of ADHD girls evidenced greater disconfirmation than they had in the retelling of a positive narrative, while mothers of comparison girls were as confirming as they had been in the positive narrative. Although not statistically significant, similar patterns were evident in paternal Confirmation and child Confirmation. Family narrative variables of Coordination and Confirmation were also found to significantly relate to peer social preference, particularly for girls with ADHD. Relationships revealed between family Narrative Interaction and developmental outcome contributed to the validity of the FNCs narrative assessment tool. Results are discussed with regards to socialization theory and emotional regulation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: storytelling, social competence, girls, ADHD, family narrative interactions
MH:

TI: Communal and national identity in a multiethnic state: A comparison of three perspectives. [References].
IN: Sidanius, Jim: U California, Dept of Psychology, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO: Ashmore, Richard D [Ed]; Jussim, Lee [Ed]; Wilder, David [Ed]. (2001). Social identity, intergroup conflict, and conflict reduction.  (pp. 101-129). xii, 270 pp. New York, NY, US: Oxford University Press; US.
AB: (from the chapter) Recognizes that few nations are homogeneous and, as migration increases, ethnic diversity creates more opportunities for conflict within them along ethnic, racial, religious and linguistic divides (hereafter referred to collectively as "communal" differences). Thus, this chapter seeks a better understanding of the manner in which people are able to negotiate loyalty to their ethnic particularisms while adopting or retaining civic culture and loyalty demanded by the nation-state, and examines the relationship between ethnic and national identities within the US. The authors note that the ethos of American society treats communal conflict as aberrant, largely idiosyncratic individual choices. They argue that communal conflict is a manifestation of a systematic tendency for: (1) groups to form social identities around communal differences, (2) there to be an inverse relationship between the strength of communal and common identities, and (3) both material and symbolic differences between groups to become occasions for communal conflict in the US. The thesis underlying the analysis is that social diversity shapes social identities that provide material and symbolic reasons for communal conflict, and conflict is an unavoidable, systematic by-product of social diversity itself. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: multiethnic states, social diversity, national identity, ethnic identity, racial identity, communal conflict, patriotism

TI: Social identity, intergroup conflict, and conflict reduction.
AU:
Ashmore, Richard D [Ed]

Jussim, Lee [Ed]

Wilder, David [Ed]
IN: Ashmore, Richard D.: Rutgers U, Dept of Psychology, Piscataway, NJ, US
SO: (2001). Social identity, intergroup conflict, and conflict reduction. xii, 270 pp. New York, NY, US: Oxford University Press; US.
AB: (from the cover) Asks how are group-based identities related to intergroup conflict? When and how do ethnic, religious, and national identities lead to oppression, violence, rebellion, mass murder, and genocide? How do intergroup conflicts change people's identities? How might social identity be harnessed in the service of reducing conflict between groups? To address these questions, social and behavioral scientists invited to present their perspectives at the Third Rutgers Symposium on Self and Social Identity, held April 1999, crafted their presentations into the chapters of this book. These chapters offer a sophisticated and detailed interdisciplinary analysis of the most fundamental issues involved in understanding social identity and conflict between groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: group based identity, intergroup conflict, ethnic identity, religion, national identity
MH:
*Conflict

*Group Structure

*Intergroup Dynamics

TI: Partner interactions are associated with reduced blood pressure in the natural environment: Ambulatory monitoring evidence from a healthy, multiethnic adult sample. [References].
AU:
Gump, Brooks B

Polk, Deborah E

Kamarck, Thomas W

Shiffman, Saul M
IN: Gump, Brooks B.: SUNY Oswego, Dept of Psychology, Oswego, NY, US
SO: Psychosomatic Medicine. Vol.63(3), May-Jun 2001, pp. 423-433.
AB: Examined the effects of partner interactions on ambulatory blood pressure in a sample of 120 healthy adults (aged 23-50 yrs) who were monitored over a 6-day period. After each blood pressure measurement, participants rated characteristics of ongoing social interactions, along with emotional activation, physical activity, talking, posture, and other covariates, with computer-assisted self-report assessments Using multilevel modeling, the authors showed that blood pressure was significantly lower during social interactions with one's partner relative to social interactions with any other person and relative to periods of not interacting. Interactions with partners also were characterized by significantly less talking and emotional activation and more intimacy and perceived emotional support; however, these differences did not mediate the partner effect on blood pressure. In addition, the relative benefits of interacting with a partner were not moderated by relationship quality, gender, or race. The effects of social situations on ambulatory blood pressure may represent one pathway through which social relationships affect cardiovascular health. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: partner interactions, social relationships, blood pressure, cardiovascular system

*Blood Pressure

*Social Interaction

TI: The lived experience of battered women. [References].
AU:
Taylor, Wendy K

Magnussen, Lois

Amundson, Mary Jane
IN: Taylor, Wendy K.: U Hong Kong, Dept of Nursing Studies, Hong Kong, China
SO: Violence Against Women. Vol.7(5), May 2001, pp. 563-585.
AB: In this phenomenological study, 12 battered women (aged 28-45 yrs) from a multiethnic population in Hawaii provided descriptions of their lived experiences. P. Colaizzi's method was used to identify three major theme clusters that emerged from the data, reflecting how the women organized their stories: (a) painting the whole picture, (b) describing the violence, and 3) living with the consequences. Each major theme was further broken down into subthemes that described how it felt to live in an abusive situation. In reviewing the impact of culture, there were more similarities than differences among cultures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Garifuna children's language shame: Ethnic stereotypes, national affiliation, and transnational immigration as factors in language choice in southern Belize.
IN: Bonner, Donna M.: Ctr for Research & Study, Maryknoll, NY, US
SO: Language in Society. Vol.30(1), Jan 2001, pp. 81-96.
AB: Explores the effects of ethnic stereotypes, demographic shifts, and nationalism on language choice in the town of Dangriga, Belize. Dangriga was founded during the 19th century by members of an ethnic minority of West African and Native American heritage, known as the Garinagu or Garifuna. Today, it is a multilingual and multiethnic town populated primarily by Garinagu, Belizean Creoles, and both native-born and foreign-born Spanish speakers. In this context, language choice is in part a question of affiliation with a variety of ethnic and national identities. This article examines the manner in which ethnic and national stereotypes and images, as well as current demographic shifts in the Belizean population, affect language choice in multilingual contexts. Particular attention is paid to the position of young Garinagu vis-oa-vis the Garifuna language and Belizean English Creole. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: multilingualism, code choice, status, solidarity, endangered languages, language, political economy, Creole, Garifuna, Spanish, Belize, nationalism, ethnic stereotypes, demographic shifts
MH:
*Choice Behavior

*Language

*Multilingualism

*Racial and Ethnic Attitudes

*Stereotyped Attitudes

Economy

Politics
PO: Human. Childhood (birth-12 yrs)

TI: ClassWide Peer Tutoring Learning Management System: Applications with elementary-level English language learners. [References].
AU:

Terry, Barbara J
IN: Greenwood, Charles R.: U Kansas, Juniper Gardens Children's Project, KS, US
SO: Remedial and Special Education. Vol.22(1), Jan-Feb 2001, pp. 34-47.
AB: For the past 18 yrs, the authors have engaged in a program of research designed to improve the literacy of poor culturally and linguistically diverse students and English language learners (ELL) in urban elementary schools. Intervention research has addressed the issue of what works best, how it can be applied and sustained schoolwide, and how computer and information management technology can improve quality and reduce teachers' work loads. The net product of this research is the ClassWide Peer Tutoring Learning Management System (CWPT-LMS). In this article, the authors report on use of the CWPT-LMS in the literacy instruction of elementary-level ELL. Five ELL teachers and 117 students (1st-5th graders) in a multiracial/multiethnic urban elementary school, including students with disabilities, participated in the study. Results indicated that ELL made considerable progress in mastering the curriculum over periods ranging from 15 to 21 wks of school across teachers, teachers implemented CWPT to high standards of fidelity, students' and teachers' satisfaction with the CWPT program was high, and consultation improved program implementation and student outcomes of all but 1 classroom. Implications of these findings are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ClassWide Peer Tutoring Learning Management System, literacy, culturally diverse 1st-5th grade English language learners

AB: Examines community-based efforts to prevent tobacco use among adolescents in multiethnic communities, and compares and contrasts them to efforts conducted in schools. A review was conducted of effective school-based prevention efforts including the Surgeon General's research reports describing broader based community approaches. By reducing illegal sales, making it physically more difficult to purchase and consume tobacco, promoting nonuse and increasing the price of cigarettes via other policy changes, and using aggressive media spots to complement these community changes, we can shift this focus back to the industry and allied political and economic interests. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Cross-cultural differences in coping with sadness. [References].
IN: VanderVoort, Debra J.: U Hawaii, Dept of Psychology, Social Sciences Div, Hilo, HI, US
SO: Current Psychology: A Journal for Diverse Perspectives on Diverse Psychological Issues. Vol.20(2), Sum 2001, pp. 147-153.
AB: The current study investigated cross-cultural differences in ways of coping with sadness in a multicultural sample of 140 undergraduate students (aged 18-54 yrs). Ss completed the Ways of Coping Questionnaire (Folkman & Lazarus, 1988) and ethno-culture was divided into Asian, Caucasian, and Multiethnic categories. ANOVA analyses revealed that Asians and Caucasians are less likely to use confrontive and positive reappraisal coping strategies in dealing with sadness than multicultural individuals. Asians are also less likely to use distancing coping strategies than multicultural individuals. Clinical implications of the results are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Abuse Assessment Screen-Disability (AAS-D): Measuring frequency, type, and perpetrator of abuse toward women with physical disabilities. [References].
AU:
McFarlane, Judith

Hughes, Rosemary B

Nosek, Maraget

Groff, Janet Y

Swedlend, Nancy

Mullen, Patricia Dolan
CQ: McFarlane, Judith: Texas Women's U, 1130 M.D. Anderson Boulevard, Houston, TX, US, 77030
IN: McFarlane, Judith: Texas Women's U, Houston, TX, US
SO: Journal of Women's Health & Gender-Based Medicine. Vol.10(9), Nov 2001, pp. 861-866.
AB: Assessed the abuse of women with physical disabilities, using the Abuse Assessment Screen-Disability in direct clinical assessment. The 4-question interview questionnaire was presented to a multiethnic sample of 511 18-64 yr old women at public and private specialty clinics, to determine the frequency, type, and perpetrator of abuse. Results show the instrument detected a 9.8% prevalence of abuse during the previous 12 mo. Using 2 standard physical and sexual assault questions, 7.8% of the women reported abuse. The 2 disability-related questions detected an additional 2.0% of the women as abused. Women defining themselves as other than Black, White, or Hispanic (i.e., Asian, mixed ethnic background) were more likely to report physical or sexual abuse or both, whereas disability-related abuse was reported almost exclusively by White women. The perpetrator of physical or sexual abuse was most likely to be an intimate partner. Disability-related abuse was attributed equally to an intimate partner, a care provider, or a health professional. It is concluded that both traditional abuse-focused questions and disability-specific questions are required to detect abuse toward women with physical disabilities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Characteristics of vegetarian adolescents in a multiethnic urban population. [References].
AU:
Perry, Cheryl L

McGuire, Maureen T

Neumark-Sztainer, Dianne

Story, Mary
IN: Perry, Cheryl L.: U Minnesota, School of Public Health, Div of Epidemiology, Minneapolis, MN, US
SO: Journal of Adolescent Health. Vol.29(6), Dec 2001, pp. 406-416.
AB: Examined the prevalence of adolescent vegetarianism in a multiethnic, urban population, and its correlates with demographic, personal, weight-related, and behavioral factors. 4,746 middle and high school students (aged 11-18 yrs) residing in the Twin Cities area of Minnesota completed questionnaires concerning vegetarianism and food, weight, and health behaviors. Additional collected data included height and weight measurements. Results show that 5.8% of Ss were vegetarians. Vegetarian Ss were more likely than nonvegetarians to be female, not black, weight- and body-conscious, dissatisfied with their bodies, and involved in a variety of healthy and unhealthy weight control behaviors. Vegetarian Ss more often reported having been told by a physician that they had an eating disorder and were more likely to have contemplated and attempted suicide. Vegetarian males were found to be an especially high risk group for unhealthy weight control practices. Few ethnic group differences among vegetarians were noted. Adolescents who did not eat chicken and fish were at lower risk than those who also ate chicken and fish. It is concluded that adolescent vegetarians are at greater risk than others for involvement in unhealthy and extreme weight control behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AU:

IN: Evans, William P.: U Nevada, Human Development & Family Studies, Reno, NV, US
SO: Journal of Interpersonal Violence. Vol.16(12), Dec 2001, pp. 1330-1348.
AB: Investigated the relationship between peer-related violence and suicide risk among youth. 913 8th grade students (aged 12-15 yrs) residing in 3 states in the US region with the highest rates of adolescent suicide completed surveys assessing suicide risk, perpetration behaviors, victimization, witnessing violence, and perpetration/victimization groupings. Results show high percentages of suicide risk, with about 60% of Ss reporting some depression or suicide ideation and 22.6% of Ss classified as high risk. Higher levels of reported suicide risk were prominent among multiethnic, urban, and female Ss. Male and female Ss who perpetrated violence by initiating fights, threatening to use weapons, and using weapons to assault others were more likely to be classified in the high-risk suicide group than those who did not. Victims and those witnessing violence did not significantly differ overall. Those who were neither perpetrators nor victims were overrepresented in the low suicide risk classification, whereas Ss who were victims only, and those who were perpetrators and victims, were underrepresented in this classification. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: peer violence, suicide risks, junior high school students, perpetration behavior, victimization, violence witnessing

AU:
Ceballo, Rosario

Dahl, Trayci A

Aretakis, Maria T

Ramirez, Cynthia
CQ: Ceballo, Rosario: Department of Psychology, University of Michigan, 525 East University, Ann Arbor, MI, US, 48109

SO: Journal of Marriage and Family. Vol.63(4), Nov 2001, pp. 927-940.
OL: Journal of Marriage and the Family, Living, Marriage and Family Living
PU: National Council on Family Relations; US
AB: Examined the psychological impact of children's exposure to violence and the influence of mothers' knowledge about their children's encounters with violence. The sample consisted of a poor, multiethnic sample of 104 4th- or 5th-grade children and their mothers (mean age 36 yrs). Children in this sample were exposed to rather high levels of community violence, and on the whole, mothers greatly underestimated their children's exposure to violence and feelings of psychological distress. Hierarchical regression analyses indicated that children's exposure to violence was associated with greater psychological distress. These findings suggest that the detrimental effects of community violence are present for all children, irrespective of their racial background. Further, greater mother-child agreement about children's exposure to violence was related to better psychological functioning. The implications of these results for effective parenting strategies and community-based interventions are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: community violence, parenting, psychological well-being, vicarious victimization, violence exposure, emotional distress, maternal knowledge level

TI: Interparental conflict, children's social cognitions, and child aggression: A test of a mediational model. [References].
AU:
Marcus, Nicole Eldridge

Lindahl, Kristin M

Malik, Neena M
IN: Marcus, Nicole Eldridge: U Miami, Dept of Psychology, Coral Gables, FL, US
SO: Journal of Family Psychology. Vol.15(2), Jun 2001, pp. 315-333.
OC: Sage Periodicals Press; Sage Publications, US
AB: Although correlations between interparental conflict and child maladjustment are well-established, the processes connecting these 2 phenomena are less understood. The present study tested whether an aggressogenic cognitive style mediates the relationship between interparental conflict and child aggression. A multiethnic sample of 115 families with a child between the ages of 7 and 13 years participated. Questionnaires were used to assess parents' and children's perceptions of interparental conflict, children's social problem-solving strategies and beliefs about aggression, and parent and teacher reports of child aggression. Support was found for the mediating effect of aggressogenic cognitions on children's school aggression but not on children's aggression at home. Implications for understanding the associations among interparental conflict, children's social cognitions, and child aggression in different environmental contexts are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

TI: Inferences about responsibility and values: Implication for academic motivation.
IN: Graham, Sandra: U California, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO: Salili, Farideh [Ed]; Chiu, Chi-yue [Ed]; Hong, Ying-yi [Ed]. (2001). Student motivation: The culture and context of learning.  (pp. 31-59). xxiv, 364 pp. Dordrecht, Netherlands: Kluwer Academic Publishers; Netherlands.
AB: (from the chapter) Examines achievement patterns of ethnic minority youth from a motivational perspective. The focus of the research is motivational processes in African American youth, although the author has broadened the perspective to include multiethnic samples who share some of the same motivational beliefs and school achievement patterns as their African American counterparts. In the present studies, participants were asked to nominate the classmates whom they most admired, respected, and wanted to be like, and whom they felt fit the the descriptions of trying hard and getting good grades, not trying hard and receiving poor grades, and following or not following school rules. Study 1 included about 300 African American 6th, 7th, and 8th graders from predominantly black schools. Study 2 included about 400 African American, Latino, and white 6th, 7th, and 8th graders from an ethnically diverse middle school. To get a developmental perspective on achievement valuing, Study 3 included 2nd-4th graders. Findings indicate that it would be inaccurate to conclude that ethnic minority students as a group devalue effort. Second, there are complex Ethnicity X Gender X Age interactions, particularly for adolescent minority males. Third, these findings have useful implications for intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Substance use diagnoses within a community sample of adults: Distinction, comorbidity, and progression over time. [References].
AU:
Newcomb, Michael D

Galaif, Elisha R

Locke, Thomas F
IN: Newcomb, Michael D.: U Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO: Professional Psychology: Research and Practice. Vol.32(3), Jun 2001, pp. 239-247.
AB: Practicing psychologists conceptualize, assess, and treat clients who use substances in different ways. Using longitudinal data from a multiethnic community sample of 470 adults, the authors examine patterns of abuse and dependence on alcohol, marijuana, and cocaine. Men were significantly more abusive, dependent, and polysubstance dependent on all drugs than women. A large percentage of drug abusers, and over 1/3 with drug dependence, remitted without formal treatment. However, early severe problems with cocaine increased later alcohol problems. Traditional disease progression and drug use acquisition models are not supported. Psychologists should incorporate the natural course of substance use into treatment and prevention efforts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Group therapy with multiethnic minorities. [References].
IN: Matsukawa, Leslie Ann: U Hawaii Dept of Psychiatry, John A. Burns School of Medicine, Honolulu, HI, US
SO: Tseng, Wen-Shing [Ed]; Streltzer, Jon [Ed]. (2001). Culture and psychotherapy: A guide to clinical practice.  (pp. 243-261). xv, 298 pp. Arlington, VA, US: American Psychiatric Publishing, Inc.; US.
AB: (from the chapter) Cultural factors influence how a person relates to others and, therefore, interactions with members of a group and with the leader of the group. In a multiethnic society, it is natural for therapy groups to be composed of members with widely varying backgrounds and widely varying values, beliefs, and attitudes. Thus, conducting culturally relevant and effective group therapy with multiethnic members is an exciting clinical challenge to the contemporary group therapist. This chapter considers the cultural values that influence group dynamics: mutuality vs. individualism, social role and hierarchy, and ethnic identity. Issues specific to multiethnic psychotherapy groups include symbolism and nonverbal communication, cultural transference, cultural countertransference, and ethnic prejudice. Several modifications of technique that have been found to be helpful in multiethnic, interpersonal group psychotherapy are suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Culture and psychotherapy: A guide to clinical practice.
IN: Tseng, Wen-Shing: U Hawaii, John A. Burns School of Medicine, Dept of Psychiatry, Honolulu, HI, US
SO: (2001). Culture and psychotherapy: A guide to clinical practice. xv, 298 pp. Arlington, VA, US: American Psychiatric Publishing, Inc.; US.
AB: (from the cover) Discusses the incorporation of culture into therapy in a practical and immediately useful way. Illustrated by numerous case studies that demonstrate issues, techniques, and recommendations, this volume focuses not on specific race or ethnicity, but instead on culture. Topics include Native American spiritual beliefs, folk healing, ethnic transference during therapy, the psychological aspects of giving and receiving medication, the severe trauma of Southeast Asian refugees, the ongoing cultural issues in psychotherapy with African, Asian, and Hispanic Americans, marital counseling for intercultural couples, and group therapy with multiethnic members. The relevance of cultural diversity will only grow stronger in the coming years as our definition of community expands to embrace global issues that are offered in this balanced combination of clinical guidance and conceptual discussion for all types of mental health professionals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Coping with ethnic stereotypes in the academic domain: Perceived injustice and psychological disengagement. [References].
AU:
Schmader, Toni

Major, Brenda

Gramzow, Richard H
IN: Schmader, Toni: U Arizona, Dept of Psychology, Tucson, AZ, US
SO: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.57(1), Spr 2001, pp. 93-111.
AB: Describes 2 distinct processes that theoretically can produce psychological disengagement of self-esteem from academic performance: devaluing academic success and discounting the validity of academic outcomes. Previous research findings concerning ethnic differences in these processes of psychological disengagement are then discussed. The authors also present the results of a multiethnic study, involving 184 African Americans, 270 Latinos, and 222 European Americans (controls), in which they examined perceived ethnic injustice and academic performance as an antecedent of psychological disengagement processes among negatively stereotyped ethnic-minority college students. Specifically, the results indicate that African Americans' beliefs about ethnic justice (but not academic performance) predict greater discounting and devaluing. Further, Latinos' beliefs about ethnic injustice are associated with greater discounting, whereas poorer academic performance is associated with increased devaluing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Reviews literature concerning clinical studies of pain in African Americans and Whites. The biopsychosocial model of pain maintains that the experience of pain is sculpted by interactions among biological, psychological, and social factors, the very factors that comprise ethnicity. Studies show greater sensitivity to experimental pain stimuli among African-Americans compared to Whites. Clinical studies of acute and persistent pain show higher levels among African-American patients compared to Whites. Ethnic factors influence how pain is appraised and responded to emotionally and behaviorally. It is concluded that clinical outcome studies involving multiethnic samples should probe for group differences in pain-related variables at baseline and in responses to treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

SO: Journal of Anxiety Disorders. Vol.15(6), Nov-Dec 2001, pp. 511-533.
AB: Investigated the validity of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) in predicting Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-III-Revised (DSM-III-R) anxiety disorders based on the Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DISC, Version 2.3) and using Asian/Pacific Islander adolescents. Archived data from the Hawaiian High Schools Health Survey were utilized in this study. An overall prevalence rate of 9.19% for generalized anxiety disorder, overanxious disorder, or social phobia was consistent with past studies. As hypothesized, STAI negatively worded items were better predictors than positively stated items. The STAI State mean was a better predictor of concurrent DISC anxiety disorders as compared to STAI State Factors 1 or 2. In contrast, the STAI Trait Factor 2 (negatively worded) composite was the best predictor for nonconcurrent DISC anxiety disorders as compared to STAI Trait Factor 1 or the overall STAI Trait subscale. Satisfactory predictive-validity values were obtained when using the STAI State mean and Trait Factor 2 composite. Implications of these findings are discussed, including using the STAI as a screening measure for ethnically diverse adolescents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
