TI: Multiethnic comparison of adolescent major depression based on the DSM-IV criteria in a U.S.-Japan study. [References].
AU:
Doi, Yuriko

Roberts, Robert E

Takeuchi, Kazuo

Suzuki, Shousuke
CQ: Doi, Yuriko: Department of Epidemiology, National Institute of Public Health, 4-6-1 Shirokanedai, Minato-ku, Tokyo, Japan, 108-8638, yuriko@iph.go.jp
IN: Doi, Yuriko: National Inst of Public Health, Dept of Epidemiology, Tokyo, Japan
SO: Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry. Vol.40(11), Nov 2001, pp. 1308-1315.
OL: Journal of the American Academy of Child Psychiatry
AB: Compared the prevalence rates of major depression based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-IV (DSM-IV) criteria with data from a multiethnic sample of adolescents drawn from a US-Japan study and investigated the relation of adolescent major depression to ethnicity. 2,046 adolescents (Anglo-Americans, African-Americans, Mexican-Americans, and Japanese) aged 12-15 yrs were studied in 1994. The DSM Scale for Depression, a self-administered checklist developed from the Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children questions on major depression, was used to estimate the prevalence of DSM-IV major depression. The overall prevalence rates of major depression without/with impairment were 9.6% and 4.3% for Anglo-American, 13.4% and 6.1% for African-American, 16.9% and 9.0% for Mexican-American, and 5.6% and 1.3% for Japanese adolescents. The significant association between adolescent major depression and ethnicity disappeared after sociodemographic adjustments. Only fathers' educational attainment and family financial status remained significant. These findings imply ethnicity does not have a significant impact on the risk of adolescent major depression after sociodemographic adjustments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Landmark essays on basic writing.
IN: Halasek, Kay: Ohio State U, Columbus, OH, US
SO: (2001). Landmark essays on basic writing. xxix, 257 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
AB: (from the introduction) The essays selected for this volume speak directly to those kinds of debilitating assumptions that place not only basic writing students but also teachers of basic writing and the discipline itself on the margins of educational, economic, and political localities of influence. The collection is designed to present readers with previously published essays that together depict the fundamental and shifting theoretical, methodological, and pedagogical assumptions of basic writing instruction over the past two decades. Arranged roughly chronologically, the essays examine such issues as defining basic writers, the phenomenology of error, cognitivism and writing instruction, the social construction of remediation, and the politics of basic writing pedagogy in a postmodern world. That is, they collectively speak to what we perceive as some of the most enduring and important debates in the field of basic writing. At the same time they collectively illustrate that neither the basic writing classroom nor recent scholarship need be intellectually marginalized locations. By including in the collection primarily essays published between 1987 and 1997, the editors bring together essays that historicize the preceding decades of scholarship and also anticipate the future of the field. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: writing skills, writing instruction
MH:

TI: The Family Coding System: Studying the relation between marital conflict and family interaction. [References].
IN: Gordis, Elana B.: U California, Dept of Psychology, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO: Kerig, Patricia K [Ed]; Lindahl, Kristin M [Ed]. (2001). Family observational coding systems: Resources for systemic research.  (pp. 111-125). xviii, 301 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
AB: (from the chapter) We developed the Family Coding System (G. Margolin and E. B. Gordis, 1992) as part of a larger project examining the effects of marital conflict on children. We developed this system to capture triadic family interactions involving mother, father, and child during a discussion about a behavior of the child's that is of concern to the parents and about which the parents experience some disagreement with each other. The task thus has the potential to evoke two types of conflict, that between parents and between parents and child. The discussion occurs while the family eats a snack, simulating a family meal. We have used the task and coding system with a multiethnic sample of two-parent families with male and female children aged 9-13 yrs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: Family Coding System for examining effect of marital conflict on parent-child-parent triadic interactions & relations & child behavior problems, 9-13 yr olds & their parents

TI: The System for Coding Interactions and Family Functioning. [References].
AU:
Lindahl, Kristin M

Malik, Neena M
IN: Lindahl, Kristin M.: U Miami, Dept of Psychology, Coral Gables, FL, US
SO: Kerig, Patricia K [Ed]; Lindahl, Kristin M [Ed]. (2001). Family observational coding systems: Resources for systemic research.  (pp. 77-91). xviii, 301 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
AB: (from the chapter) The purpose of the System for Coding Interactions and Family Functioning (SCIFF) is to behaviorally assess family functioning across multiple ethnic groups, integrating both family systems and social learning perspectives. Originally developed for a multiethnic study of externalizing behaviors in school-age boys, the SCIFF assesses universal aspects of family functioning and is applicable with a wide range of populations. It has been found to be reliable with one- and two-parent families, as well as with a variety of ethnic groups, including Euro-American, Hispanic-American, and African-American families. The SCIFF was designed to code family problem discussions but also has been used successfully to code family play interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: utility & construction & cross-cultural assessment using the System for Coding Interactions & Family Functioning for coding observation of family interaction

TI: The consequences of national inequality in Israel.
CQ: Hajjar, Lisa: Morehouse College, 830 Westview Drive, SW, Atlanta, GA, US, 30314-3773, lhajjar@morehouse.edu
IN: Hajjar, Lisa: Department of Sociology, Morehouse College, Atlanta, GA, US
SO: Peace and Conflict: Journal of Peace Psychology. Vol.6(1), Mar 2000, pp. 83-84.
OC: Educational Publishing Foundation, US; Taylor & Francis, United Kingdom
AB: Reviews the book, Palestinian Citizens in an Ethnic Jewish State: Identities in Conflict by Nadim M. Rouhana (1997). This book demonstrates that Israel is an exemplary case for studying the contradictions of ethnic power and democracy. In addition to contributing to scholarship on Israel, Rouhana redresses a lacuna in social identity theory: the social psychology of collective identity of ethnic groups in multiethnic states. The rift between Jews and Palestinians in Israel is also evident in discrepant interpretations of local and regional events and developments relating to the conflict. Rouhana provides a fascinating discussion of this rift through his analysis of Jews' and Palestinians' responses to actual and hypothetical scenarios. Rouhana tends to minimize the myriad differences in collective identities among Palestinians. Dealing with such complications would have enriched this book. Nevertheless, Rouhana's study merits the attention of anyone interested in the social psychology of collective identity and of everyone seeking a better understanding of Israel. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Adolescents in Multiethnic Schools: Turning Borders Into Boundaries. [References].
CQ: Varenne, Herve: Programs in Anthropology and Education, Department of International and Transcultural Studies, Teachers College, Columbia University, 525 West 120th Street, P.O. Box 19, New York, NY, US, 10027, hhv1@columbia.edu
IN: Varenne, Herve: Programs in Anthropology and Education, Department of International and Transcultural Studies, Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, NY, US
SO: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.45(1), Feb,  2000
AB: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 2000, Vol 45(1), 43-45. The reviewer notes that this book (see record 1997-36901-000) is based on a study of 55 adolescents in four desegregated high schools in two urban school districts in California. The research was designed (a) theoretically, to highlight the adolescents' views as these can be verbalized to researchers; (b) rhetorically, to report these views through summarized narratives; and (c) methodologically, to ensure that the greatest amount of variability within the sample was attained. The potential value of the book, and its originality, lies in the drawing of the six personal management types derived from the dual emphases on qualities and strategies. The reviewer concludes that teachers and others interested in schools, particularly those being trained, should find this book most profitable in that it provides an accessible account of matters they will surely encounter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Prevalence and characteristics of childhood sexual abuse in multiethnic female college students. [References].
AU:
Kenny, Maureen C

McEachern, Adriana Garcia
IN: Kenny, Maureen C.: Florida International U, Community Health Counseling Program, Miami, FL, US
SO: Journal of Child Sexual Abuse: Research, Treatment, & Program Innovations for Victims, Survivors, & Offenders. Vol.9(2), 2000, pp. 57-70.
AB: A survey of 164 college women (aged 19-57 yrs) revealed that 18% recalled some instance of childhood sexual abuse. These women were from a variety of ethnic, cultural, and economic backgrounds. The majority of the women were abused by nonfamily members (neighbors, acquaintances, friends of the family), but strangers were the identified perpetrators in 21% of the cases. In the intrafamilial sexual abuse cases, the perpetrator was most commonly a cousin. The majority of the sexual abuse consisted of fondling of the victim by the perpetrator (67%), with the second most reported experience being the exposure of the perpetrator to the victim (30%). There were differences in the economic backgrounds of the abused women when compared to the nonabused women, with the present findings differing from past research examining family of origin income level and sexual abuse. The importance of these findings is discussed as well as directions for future research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

TI: Using scenarios to construct models of identity in multiethnic settings. [References].
AU:
Caulkins, D. Douglas

Trosset, Carol

Painter, Anna R

Good, Meredith R
IN: Caulkins, D. Douglas: Grinnell Coll, Grinnell, IA, US
SO: Field Methods. Vol.12(4), Nov 2000, pp. 267-281.
AB: Proposes a method of testing and refining inferred cultural models of identity in cognitive and psychological anthropology text analysis. It is noted that the task of inferring cultural models from lengthy texts or transcripts of intensive interviews is highly dependent on the representativeness of the sample of consultants, the researcher's command of the language, and his or her ability to detect themes through iterative analysis. Use of scenarios and systematic interviewing is recommended to verify and refine those inferred themes, schema, or cultural models. Scenarios are defined as brief narratives derived from observed or reported events. A set of scenarios can be used to elicit judgments concerning key themes of inferred cultural models. This technique is illustrated with a battery of 21 scenarios used, along with consensus analysis, to describe identity profiles for samples from Wales, Scotland, and Northeast England. Scenarios can be used to document claimed identity (what we are like) and attributed identity (what group X is like) and to discover similarities and differences across ethnic or national group boundaries. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Development of reading skill: The impact of home literacy. [Dutch]. [References].
AU:
Leseman, Paul P

de Jong, Peter F
IN: Leseman, Paul P.: U Amsterdam, Faculteit der Maatschappij en Gedragswetenschappen, Amsterdam, Netherlands
SO: Pedagogische Studien. Vol.77(5-6), 2000, pp. 290-306.
AB: Conducted a longitudinal study of the average long-term effects of informal literacy education at home on the development of reading skill, especially reading comprehension, in a socioeconomically varied and multiethnic sample in the Netherlands. The parents of 64 4-9 yr old preschool and school-age children were interviewed, and parent-child interactions were assessed 3 times. Oral language comprehension was measured at age 4 yrs in the 1st yr of kindergarten (1st grade in Dutch primary schools) and again at age 7 yrs in 3rd grade. Technical reading and reading comprehension were assessed at ages 7 yrs and 9 yrs in Grades 3 and 5. Reading activity, play activity, and problem-solving activity in the family were assessed. The results indicate that home literacy education had average long-term effects (probably mediated by earlier oral language development) on reading comprehension but only short-term effects on technical reading. The findings show that Ss' primary schools were more effective in teaching technical reading than in teaching reading comprehension. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Ethnic identity and definitions of success among African American men: An ecological examination.
IN: Zaff, Jonathan Frederick: U Georgia, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(6-B), Jan 2000, pp. 3310.
AB: The goal of the present study was to take a grounded theory approach in examining the ethnic identity development and definitions of success among African American men. It was hoped that a clearer vision of how African American men define success and the content of African American men's ethnic identity would be revealed. An ecological developmental perspective was used to achieve these goals. A sample of nine men completed ethnic identity and racism questionnaires and then participated in extensive semi-structured interviews. Two types of ethnic identities emerged from the study, ethnic solidarity and multiethnic solidarity. Both types involved a strong pride in the African American community, but the ethnic solidarity group placed the livelihood of that community over the livelihood of society as a whole. The multiethnic solidarity group, meanwhile, accepted all groups, regardless of ethnicity, and did not place the survival of one group over another. Success appeared to coincide with ethnic identity type, with individualistic goals coinciding with multiethinic solidarity and more communalistic goals coinciding with ethnic solidarity. An ecological model was formed from the data, which took into account how the various layers of society can influence ethnic identity development and how a person defines success. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ethnic identity development, African Americans, men, success
MH:
*Achievement

*Blacks

*Ethnic Identity

*Human Males
PO: Human. Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
JN: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering

TI: The relationship between gender, ethnicity, and social support in the adolescent population: Establishing norms for the Student Social Support Scale.
IN: Brown, Kerry A.: Loyola U Chicago, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(4-B), Oct 2000, pp. 2192.
AB: The central purpose of this dissertation was to address both methodological and conceptual issues regarding the assessment of adolescents' perceptions of social support. Specifically, the present study established norms for the adolescent population for the Student Social Support Scale (SSSS; Nolten, 1994). The SSSS has proven to be a sound instrument in measuring children's perceptions of social support, with high levels of reliability and validity. The SSSS measures emotional, informational, appraisal, and instrumental forms of support provided by parents, teachers, close friends, and classmates. Additionally, an exploration of possible ethnic and gender differences was conducted. The research participants of this study consisted of a multiethnic sample of 191 ninth-, tenth-, eleventh-, and twelfth-grade students from four high schools (public and private) in the Chicagoland area. Overall, the preliminary analyses suggested that the SSSS is a valid and reliable measure of perceived social support with a multiethnic sample of adolescents. The results indicate that females consistently reported higher levels of perceived social support across the Total Scale, and Classmate and Close Friend subscales. Conversely, the male subjects consistently reported higher average levels of perceived support on the Parent and Teacher subscales. However, the only statistically significant result was that females perceived higher levels of social support from their Close Friends. With regard to the factor structure of the SSSS (Nolten, 1994), the exploratory factor analysis suggested a four-factor solution (parent, teacher, close friend, classmate). However, the confirmatory factor analysis was unable to confirm such a model. Additionally, the role of ethnicity in social support was inconclusive. That is, statistically, ethnic differences were observed between the five ethnic groups (Caucasian, Latino, African-American, Mixed Ethnicity, and Asian) on the Parent and Teacher subscales. However, due to the fact that the ethnic groups were of unequal size, post hoc analyses, to determine which specific groups differed on these subscales, could not be utilized. Further, Classmate support ratings consistently accounted for a significant proportion of the variance in self-image, social, academic, and total self-concept ratings. Finally, additional analyses indicated that there was not a statistically significant difference between the respondents' age/grade and how they perceived social support from the various sources. Limitations and implications of this study are discussed in the final chapter of this dissertation, and recommendations for social support researchers are provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: validity & reliability of Student Social Support Scale, measure of emotional & informational & instrumental forms of social support, 9th-12th graders
MH:
*Rating Scales

*Social Support

*Test Reliability

*Test Validity

High School Students

TI: Identification of risk factors for aggression, fighting behavior, and weapon-carrying among junior high school youth.
IN: James, Aimee Suzanne: U Houston, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(12-B), Jun 2000, pp. 6422.
AB: Aggression and violence in and around schools are increasing concerns for American adolescents and the public. In light of recent concern over school safety and the prevalence of violence and victimization among youth, it is important to identify risk factors for aggression and violent behaviors in students. Among these concerns are the prevalences of physical fighting and weapon-carrying among young adolescents. Aggressive behavior is positively correlated to problem behaviors such as alcohol use, drug use, and risky sexual behavior. This study investigated fighting, weapon-carrying, and aggressive tendencies in a cross-sectional sample of multiethnic middle school students. The aim of this study was to build a predictive model of risk factors for engaging in aggressive and violent behaviors as well as to estimate the prevalence of such behavior in a middle-school sample. Descriptive analyses estimated that the 30-day prevalence of physical fighting was nearly 30%, and was significantly higher for boys than for girls. Carrying a weapon to school was rare in this sample (less than 1%). Logistic regression analyses indicated that the risk factors associated with weapon carrying and physical fighting were different. For example, acts of vandalism were associated with higher odds of carrying a weapon to school but not fighting. These aggressive acts were positively correlated with self-reports of substance use and delinquency; and, when all of the risk behaviors were examined together in a confirmatory factor analysis, a single-factor model fit the data best. This study supports the generally held concept that many risk behaviors are positively associated with each other. Further, it indicates that aggressive acts are present in the schools and of such frequency as to be of concern. However, the binomial logistic models suggest that, while they are highly associated, there appear to be important differences between fighting and weapon carrying behaviors. A longitudinal study is proposed to examine issues of causality and further distinguish the sets of behaviors. Implications for prevention are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: aggression & fighting behavior & weapon-carrying, junior high school youth
MH:
*Aggressive Behavior

*High School Students

*Weapons
PO: Human. Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
JN: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering

TI: Attachment as a predictor of self-monitoring and sexual behavior.
IN: Dieterich, Susan Ellen: U Southern California, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.60(12-A), Jun 2000, pp. 4330.
AB: Snyder (1974) first described self-monitoring (SM) as a person's motivation to after his or her self-presentation to fit perceived social requirements. The social behavior of those high in self-monitoring seems to be guided by situational factors, whereas that of those low in self-monitoring seems to be guided by their internal states. This study examined whether (a) participants' SM level would be predicted from their adult attachment style (Collins & Read, 1990) and whether (b) participants' SM level would predict their levels of reactance, dating confidence, and specific sexual behaviors. Participants were a multiethnic, community sample of adolescents and young adults (mean age = 17.4). For the entire group of participants, the adult attachment dimension of Close predicted SM level. When the data were separated by gender, however, this relationships was found to be true only for men; whereas for women, Anxious attachment predicted SM levels, but in a negative direction. That is, mates who are able to feel close to others bad higher SM scores and females. who have lower Anxiety scores tended to score higher in SM. SM level predicted reported frequency of sexual intercourse per month. However, SM did not predict dating confidence, number of steady relationships, number of sexual partners, or age at first intercourse. Women scored higher than men in SM, which is contrary to the findings of previous researchers. Consistent with previous research, though, men reported having had more sexual partners, more steady relationships, and having been younger at first intercourse. Different patterns between-variable relationships were observed according to ethnic group. For African-American participants, age and ability to feel they could depend on others were predictors of SM style. For this group, HSM predicted higher dating confidence and higher frequency of sex per month. For the Euro-American group, higher SM predicted higher reactance. For the Latino group, which comprised the majority of the participants in this study, lower Anxiety scores predicted a higher SM style. For this group too, higher SM predicted higher reactance and higher dating confidence. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: attachment style, self-monitoring & reactance & dating confidence & sexual behavior, adolescents & young adults (mean age 17.4 yrs)
MH:
*Attachment Behavior

*Psychological Reactance

*Psychosexual Behavior

*Self Confidence

*Self Monitoring (Personality)

TI: Building better relationships workshop: An intervention fostering identity formation and interpersonal development in middle adolescents.
IN: Lorente, Carolyn Cass: Florida International U., US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(11-B), May 2000, pp. 5812.
AB: The aim of this study was to further knowledge development concerning the formation of a sense of identity and intimacy. This study drew on the growing recognition by many researchers in the psychosocial development field of the need to target interventions at the interface of the development of identity and intimacy. The specific aim of the study was to address the question of whether it would be possible to develop intervention procedures for fostering identity and intimacy exploration and development. Using both qualitative and quantitative measurements, the results appeared to clearly support an affirmative answer to this question. A total of sixty-three middle adolescent students from an urban, public high school participated in this study. Twenty-nine participants in the treatment group and 34 participants in the comparison group were pre- and post tested on measures of identity and intimacy. Participants in this study consisted of multiethnic, urban youth that presented themselves for relationship counseling. Repeated measures analysis of variance's (RMANOVA's), used to evaluate the impact of the intervention on the quantitative measures of identity and intimacy exploration, clearly supported the efficacy of the intervention. In addition, the findings also provided tentative support for the view that the increase in exploration that results from entering a period of active exploration is associated with a "loosening" of commitment. Finally, the findings of this study also contributed to the empirical knowledge-base about procedures for intervening with respect to the process of intimacy development. More specifically, both the qualitative and quantitative findings of this study began to shed some light on the potential impact of exploration for interpersonal insight as that as a process for fostering intimacy development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: efficacy of intervention fostering identity formation & intimacy development, middle adolescents
MH:
*Identity Formation

*Interpersonal Interaction

*Intimacy

*Self Concept
PO: Human. Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
JN: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering

TI: A microanalysis of developmental, parenting, and family milieu variables that differentiate stress-resilient and stress-affected children.
IN: Kilmer, Ryan Patrick: U Rochester, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(10-B), Apr 2000, pp. 5227.
AB: The study microanalyzed global developmental, parenting, and family milieu variables previously shown to differentiate stress-resilient (SR) and stress-affected (SA) outcomes in a multiethnic, highly stressed, urban school sample. Its fine-grained approach sought to: (a) identify "active" items from global scales that optimally differentiated groups; and (b) recombine these items into factors that sensitively and parsimoniously predicted SR status. The study used two independent samples of highly stressed, inner city families: Sample 1, with 131 4th-6 th graders and their parents; and Sample 2, with 122 2nd-3rd graders and their parents. Interviews were conducted With each child's primary caregiver to assess caregiving environment and early child development. Analyses were conducted in two stages using: (a) the pooled Study 1 and 2 samples, and (b) only Sample 2, including relevant new Study 2 measures. Because the Study 2 interview included more measures, this latter step served both to replicate, and extend, the pooled analyses. In the pooled sample, t-tests showed that 36 of 144 items differentiated SRs and SAs and met inclusion criteria for subsequent analyses. Discriminant function analysis (DFA) identified a cluster of nine sensitive items that correctly classified 81.7% of children as SR or SA. A factor analysis of the 36 items identified a 4-factor solution: Child Adjustment, Early Temperament, Parent-Child Relationship, and Developmental Milestones. MANOVA-ANOVA analyses significantly favored SR over SA parents on all four factors. In Study 2, 57 of 146 items tested differentiated the groups. A DFA identified a set of five predictors that optimally differentiated the groups, correctly classifying 81.4% of children. Factor analysis of the 57 sensitive items identified a 6-factor solution: Caregiving Attitudes, Parent-Child Relationship, Parent Well-Being, Child Adjustment, Developmental Milestones, and Early Temperament . The Caregiving Attitudes and Parent Well-Being factors reflected items unique to the Study 2 interview. MANOVA-ANOVA analyses showed significant group differences favoring SR over SA parents on all six factors. Overall, study findings enhance understanding of child resilience and testify to the merit of using microanalytic approaches in resilience research. Implications for streamlining existing measures and for future research directions are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: developmental & parenting & family milieu variables, stress-resilient vs stress-affected 2nd-3rd vs 4th-6th graders & their parents
MH:
*Home Environment

*Parent Child Relations

*Resilience (Psychological)

*Stress Reactions

Age Differences

TI: Risk factors for recidivism among DWI offenders entering screening: A 4-year follow-up.
IN: C'De Baca, Janet: U New Mexico, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(8-B), Feb 2000, pp. 4208.
AB: Nationwide, the private and public cost of DWI in terms of lives lost, property damage, medical care dollars, lost work time, and increased insurance premiums has been substantial. The aims of this study are to characterize a study sample (N = 1496) of multiethnic convicted DWI offenders for comparison with other reports, and to determine the extent to which information gathered at screening is useful in predicting DWI recidivism, crashes and citations in a 4-year follow-up. Profile analysis was used to determine if Alcohol Use Inventory (AUI) and Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2) profiles differed among the racial/ethnic, gender, type of offender, and recidivism groups. A model was developed using logistic regression to determine which variables best discriminate between first-time offenders (FTOs) and multiple offenders at baseline (MOBs). A second model using logistic regression was developed to predict DWI recidivism from information gathered at screening. Results from the logistic regression were used in a probability formula to develop a table of predicted probability of recidivism. A model was developed using multiple regression to determine which variables best predict crashes and citations. The drinking drivers in this study were very similar in demographics to other DWI populations that have been described, though there were differences among the groups in terms of AUI and MMPI-2 profiles. The logistic regression to discriminate between FTOs and MOBs revealed that MOBs were more likely to be males, with less education, higher arrest BACs, and high scores on the receptive-awareness and MAC scales of the MMPI-2. Significant predictors of DWI recidivism were gender, age, arrest BACs, prior DWIs, and the MAC and receptive-awareness scales from the MMPI-2. Probability tables based on endorsement of low and high risk factors indicate that, as the number of risk factors endorsed increases, so does the probability of reoffending. For example, individuals with 1 risk factor have an 11% probability of reoffending, while those with 5 risk factors have a 53% probability of reoffending. The best predictors of involvement in a crash were age and high scores on the antisocial practices scale from the MMPI-2. The best predictors of future citations were age, gender, marital status, racial/ethnic group, prior citations, MAC score of the MMPI-2, and compliance with treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: risk factors for recidivism, drunk-driving offenders entering screening, 4 yr follow-up
MH:
*Driving Under the Influence

*Recidivism

*Screening
PO: Human.  Male.  Female. Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
JN: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering

TI: Parent reports of child behavior problems in young Sami children: A cross-cultural comparison.
AU:
Javo, C

Heyerdahl, S

Ronning, J. A
IN: Javo, C.: U Tromsoe, Dept of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Tromsoe, Norway
SO: European Child & Adolescent Psychiatry. Vol.9(3), Sep 2000, pp. 202-211.
AB: In a general population study of 4-year-olds, using the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL), parent reports of child behavior problems were compared in samples of 67 monoethnic Sami, 52 multiethnic Sami/Norwegian, and 63 monoethnic Norwegian children from the Sami core area in northern Norway. Mean CBCL total problem scores were low for all three groups. No significant differences across ethnic groups were found for the Total Problems scale and the Internalizing and Externalizing scales, nor for the syndrome scales, except for the Withdrawn scale, the Sami/Norwegian sample showing the highest scores. However, signicant ethnicity x gender interactions emerged, indicating that the effect of ethnicity was different for boys versus girls. Sami mothers reported the highest and the Norwegian mothers the lowest scores for girls, whereas the opposite pattern was found for boys. Correlations between mothers' and fathers' reports were generally low. Differences in mean scale scores between 122 pairs of parents were found for boys but not for girls, mothers scoring higher than fathers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: maternal vs paternal reports of behavior problems, Norwegian vs Sami vs Sami/Norwegian 4 yr olds

TI: Telling tales in school: Youth culture and conflict narratives.
AU:
Morrill, Calvin

Yalda, Christine

Adelman, Madelaine

Musheno, Michael

Bejarano, Cindy
IN: Morrill, Calvin: U Arizona, Dept of Sociology, Tucson, AZ, US
SO: Law & Society Review. Vol.34(3), 2000, pp. 521-565.
AB: Analyzed experiential stories of youth culture and peer conflict written by 316 9th graders at a multiethnic low income urban (US) high school. Students in English classes were asked to write in narrative form about interpersonal conflict with another student. Analysis was conducted for 267 narratives, and identified 4 story types, each marked by a different narrative style: action tales, expressive tales, moral tales and rational tales. These types are discussed as representing bases of everyday conflict, decision making, conflict handling, physical violence and the role of adults in youth conflict. Most of the students' narratives were action tales. The authors propose 3 alternative explanations for this pattern, based on class code, moral development, and political/institutional resistance perspectives. Theoretical and policy implications for youth-centered conflict intervention are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: analysis of experiential narrative stories of youth culture & peer conflict, 9th graders

TI: Family conflict and children's internalizing and externalizing behavior: Protective factors.
AU:
Formoso, Diana

Gonzales, Nancy A

Aiken, Leona S
IN: Formoso, Diana: Arizona State U, Dept of Psychology, Tempe, AZ, US
SO: American Journal of Community Psychology. Vol.28(2), Apr 2000, pp. 175-199.
OC: Plenum Publishing Corp., US; Springer, Germany
AB: The current investigation examined whether the positive association of family conflict to adolescent depression and conduct problems is attenuated by maternal, paternal, and peer attachment, and maternal and paternal monitoring, within a low-income, multiethnic sample of 284 10-16 yr olds. Parental attachment and monitoring moderated the link from family conflict to conduct problems but not depression; the relationships among family conflict, the hypothesized protective factors, and conduct problems were further modified by adolescent gender but not ethnicity. In general, higher levels of the hypothesized protective factors attenuated the relationship between family conflict and conduct problems for girls but exacerbated this relationship for boys. These findings suggest that, in general, parental attachment and monitoring served as protective factors for girls while serving as additional risk factors for boys in conflictual families. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

IN: Guttman, Nurit: Tel Aviv U, Dept of Communication, Tel Aviv, Israel
SO: Social Science & Medicine. Vol.50(10), May 2000, pp. 1457-1473.
AB: Drawing from structured interviews with 154 mothers (aged 16-42 yrs) from an urban low-income multiethnic population in the United States, a typology of mothers' feelings about their infant feeding method was developed. Findings indicate that regardless of their feeding method, mothers tended to attribute higher health benefits to breastfeeding and perceived community norms as pro-breastfeeding. They differed in their rating and perceptions of logistics and the extent to which benefits mattered in their infant-feeding decision. Contradictions associated with the practice of breastfeeding even among mothers who breastfed, were reflected in their perceptions of social disapproval of breastfeeding in public, reports of ridicule by friends, lack of support from some health providers, and difficulties associated with working. A typology of mothers' emotional states resulting from such contradictions summarizes the findings and underscores how some mothers who did not, but would have liked to breastfeed, may be subjected to feelings of guilt and deprivation. Implications for educational interventions are to amplify prenatal infant feeding consultations and address ways to overcome logistical and apprehension barriers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: views concerning infant feeding method, 16-42 yr old low-income mothers who practiced formula vs breastfeeding
MH:
*Breast Feeding

*Childrearing Attitudes

*Eating Behavior

TI: Discrimination distress during adolescence.
AU:
Fisher, Celia B

Wallace, Scyatta A

Fenton, Rose E
IN: Fisher, Celia B.: Fordham U Ctr for Ethics Education, Dept of Psychology, Bronx, NY, US
SO: Journal of Youth and Adolescence. Vol.29(6), Dec 2000, pp. 679-695.
AB: Examined the extent to which adolescents from different ethnic backgrounds experience distress in response to perceived instances of racial discrimination. In addition, the relationship of discrimination-based distress to parental messages about race relationships and self-esteem was explored. The Adolescent Discrimination Distress Index along with measures of caregiver racial bias preparation and self-esteem was administered to 177 13-19 yr olds of different ethnic and racial backgrounds. Youth from all ethnic backgrounds reported distress associated with instances of perceived racial prejudice encountered in educational contexts. Instances of institutional discrimination in stores and by police were higher for older youth and particularly for African American and Hispanic teenagers. Encounters with peer discrimination were reported most frequently by Asian youth. Reports of racial bias preparation were associated with distress in response to institutional and educational discrimination and self-esteem scores were negatively correlated with distress caused by educational and peer discrimination. The importance of research on discrimination distress to understanding adolescent development in multiethnic ecologies is discussed here. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: racial discrimination distress & parental racial bias & self-esteem, 13-19 yr olds of different ethnic & racial backgrounds
MH:
*Distress

*Race and Ethnic Discrimination

*Racial and Ethnic Attitudes

TI: Self-efficacy and HIV-related risk behaviors among multiethnic adolescents. [References].
IN: Faryna, Ellen L.: Sonoma Developmental Ctr, Eldridge, CA, US
SO: Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology. Vol.6(1), Feb 2000, pp. 42-56.
AB: Investigated the self-efficacy and risk behaviors related to HIV, the comparative predictiveness of self-efficacy and knowledge, attitudes and beliefs regarding sexual activity and substance use, and possible risk profiles for HIV among adolescents. 427 high school students (aged 12-20 yrs) and attending family life education classes completed a self-administered questionnaire. Ethnic representation included African American, Chinese, Filipino, other Asian/Pacific Islander, Latino, and European American. Over half of this sample of teens were sexually active by the age of 14, with sexually active teens and substance-abusing teens scoring higher on HIV knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding HIV-related behaviors. Ethnicity consistently appeared more significant in predicting these risk behaviors than gender, self-efficacy, and knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs. The predominance of ethnicity as the predictor for these HIV risk behaviors indicates that theoretical models for behavior change must include a dimension of culture, diversity, and ethnic identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ethnicity, attitudes & beliefs & self-efficacy regarding sexual activity & substance use & risk behaviors related to HIV, 12-20 yr old Black & Chinese & Filipino & Asian & Latino & White students

AB: Examined the influence of family adversity and support on levels of psychiatric symptomatology in Hawaiian and non-Hawaiian adolescents. 4,164 students from 5 high schools in Hawaii completed a survey during the 1992-1993 school year about their family environment and mental health. Logistic regression analyses were performed and responses for Hawaiians and non-Hawaiians were compared. Hawaiian adolescents experienced significantly more adversity than their non-Hawaiian counterparts. The cumulative effect of family adversity had a greater effect on psychiatric symptomatology than any single indicator. Family support reduced the risk for internalizing symptoms, particularly for Hawaiian adolescents. The influence of family support was less clear for externalizing symptoms, increasing the risk for some adolescents and decreasing the risk for others. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: family environment, psychiatric symptomatology, Hawaiian vs non-Hawaiian high school students

AB: Examined the influence of sociodemographic variables on the frequency and intensity of alcohol use among a nationally representative sample of Black, Hispanic, and White adolescents who had participated in the 1991 National Household Survey on Drug Abuse (US Department of Health and Human Services, 1993). The sample consisted of 8,756 US adolescents aged 12 to 18 yrs. The authors found that (1) approximately 19% of the respondents had used alcohol in the last 30 days; (2) among the respondents who had used alcohol, 21% had consumed 1 or more drinks per drinking episode; and (3) there were important similarities as well as important differences in variables that promoted alcohol use among Black, Hispanic, and White adolescents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: sociodemographics, frequency & intensity of alcohol use, Black vs Hispanic vs White 12-18 yr olds

TI: Ethnic identity, gay identity, sexual sensation seeking and HIV risk taking among multiethnic men who have sex with men.
IN: Lye Chng, Chwee: U North Texas, Dept of Kinesiology, Health Promotion & Regulation, Denton, TX, US
SO: AIDS Education and Prevention. Vol.12(4), Aug 2000, pp. 326-339.
AB: Examined ethnic identity, as measured by the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure; gay identity, as measured by the adapted Homosexual Identity Questionnaire; sexual sensation seeking (SSS), as measured by the Sexual Sensation Seeking Scale; and HIV risk taking, as measured by the HIV Risk-taking Behavior Scale among 302 multiethnic (Black, Latino, Asian/Pacific Islander, and White) gay males. Data were collected from gay bars, bathhouses, community events and programs targeting gay men of color, and male participants of the National Minority AIDS Council Conference of AIDS in Dallas, 1998. More than half of the sample reported at least 1 incident of unprotected anal sex in the past month. Logistic regression analysis identified SSS; not having a defined gay identity; being in a sexually exclusive relationship; and, for those born overseas, length of stay in the US as significant predictors of unprotected anal sex among the sample. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ethnic & gay identity & sexual sensation seeking & HIV risk taking, Black vs Hispanic vs Asian vs White gay males

AB: Examined the determinants of interethnic friendship patterns with the majority group and co-ethnic friendship ties. The analysis was based on a specially constructed data set from 3 separate sources (n = 2,310 18-65 yr olds). The analysis indicates that (1) participation in ethnic business tended to substantially lower chances of developing friendship with the majority group; (2) individual SES characteristics strongly affected co-ethnic friendship; (3) previous experiences of friendship with the majority group were related to the level of friendship ties with the majority group; and (4) neighborhood qualities did not relate to friendship choices of minority groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: determinants of interethnic friendship patterns with majority group & co-ethnic friendship ties, 18-65 yr old members of ethnic groups

AU:
Perczek, Ruben

IN: Perczek, Ruben: U Miami, Dept of Psychology, Coral Gables, FL, US
SO: Journal of Personality Assessment. Vol.74(1), Feb 2000, pp. 63-87.
OL: Journal of Projective Techniques & Personality Assessment
AB: Research on stress and its influence on health and well-being has flourished for several decades, examining as predictors such psychosocial variables as personality and coping. This work now often targets multiethnic samples. Because many potential participants lack facility in English, a need exists for translations of measures into other languages. The authors translated 6 instruments into Spanish and studied their characteristics. Of these, 3 were measures of personality qualities: the Life Orientation Test-Revised ( M. F. Scheier et al, 1994), the Behavioral Inhibition/Behavioral Activation Scales (C. S. Carver & T. L. White, 1994), and the Measure of Body Apperception (C. S. Carver et al, 1998). The others were the Brief COPE (Carver, 1997), the Center for Epidemiological Studies-Depression Scale (Radloff, 1977), and an abbreviated version of the Profile of Mood States (D. McNair et al, 1971). Ss for experiments 1 and 2 included a total of 290 bilingual college students (aged 17-37 yrs). Correlations between English and Spanish versions in bilingual samples were all above .72, except for the COPE's Behavioral Disengagement scale. Correlations among measures in a sample of 60 Hispanic early-stage breast cancer patients (aged 27-81 yrs) were similar across languages. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: coping & mood & personality, Spanish translations of Life Orientation Test-Revised & Behavioral Inhibition/Behavioral Activation Scales & Measure of Body Apperception & other measures, bilingual Ss,
MH:
*Breast Neoplasms

*Coping Behavior

*Emotional States

*Foreign Language Translation

TI: 5-a-Day Power Plus: Process evaluation of a multicomponent elementary school program to increase fruit and vegetable consumption.
AU:
Story, Mary

Mays, Rita Warren

Bishop, Donald B

Perry, Cheryl L

Taylor, Gretchen

Smyth, Mary

Gray, Clifton
IN: Story, Mary: School of Public Health, Div of Epidemiology, Minneapolis, MN, US
SO: Health Education & Behavior. Vol.27(2), Apr 2000, pp. 187-200.
OL: Health Education Monographs, Health Education Quarterly
AB: This article describes the 5-a-Day Power Plus program, which targeted multiethnic 4th- and 5th-grade students in 10 intervention and 10 control urban elementary schools in St Paul, Minnesota, to increase fruit and vegetable consumption. The intervention included behavioral curricula in classrooms, parental involvement, school food service changes, and food industry support. Process evaluation was conducted by using surveys and classroom and lunchroom observations to assess the characteristics of teachers and food service staff, the degree the intervention was implemented as intended, and external forces that may have affected the program results. Results showed high levels of participation, dose, and fidelity for all of the intervention components, with the exception of parental involvement. The process evaluation findings help explain why the increase in fruit and vegetable consumption occurred mostly at school lunch and not at home. It is suggested that future intervention research should focus on creating new and potent strategies for parental involvement and for increasing the appeal and availability of vegetables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: process evaluation of 5-a-Day Power Plus school-based nutrition education program, fruit & vegetable consumption, urban multiethnic 4th & 5th graders

TI: Victim impact panels: Who is sentenced to attend? Does attendance affect recidivism of first-time DWI offenders? [References].
AU:
C'de Baca, Janet

Lapham, Sandra C

Paine, Susan

Skipper, Betty J
IN: C'de Baca, Janet: Behavioral Health Research Ctr of the Southwest, Albuquerque, NM, US
SO: Alcoholism: Clinical and Experimental Research. Vol.24(9), Sep 2000, pp. 1420-1426.
AB: Victim Impact Panels (VIPs) have been implemented widely in the US by judges as a deterrent to drinking and driving, but there is little evidence of their utility in preventing recidivism. The objectives of this study were to examine judges' referral patterns to the VIPs among a multiethnic population of convicted 1st-time driving while impaired (DWI) offenders and to compare 5-yr recidivism rates of those mandated and not mandated to attend the VIP. Study participants included 5,238 convicted 1st-time DWI offenders (aged 16-30+ yrs) who were referred to a screening program and who completed a personal interview with a counselor between 1989 and 1995. Results showed that female judges were more likely than male judges to refer offenders to a VIP, and referral patterns varied by offender characteristics (sex, education, blood alcohol concentration, race/ethnicity, and marital status). The VIP referral did not increase rearrest rates but lowered them marginally to not at all. This study should be followed up with a randomized design to control for referral patterns and to further define the impact of mandating offenders to the VIP. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: judge referral patterns to & recidivism rates for those mandated vs not mandated to attend victim impact panels & offender characteristics, 1st-time DWI offenders aged 16-30+ yrs, 5-yr study

*Court Referrals

*Driving Under the Influence

*Recidivism

TI: Multiethnic children portrayed in children's picture books.
AU:
Cole, Erin Michelle

Valentine, Deborah P
IN: Cole, Erin Michelle: U Wyoming, Dept of Social Work, Laramie, WY, US
SO: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal. Vol.17(4), Aug 2000, pp. 305-317.
AB: Briefly reviews the literature on the development of racial identity in children with a special focus on the development of racial identity in pre-school multiethnic children. A review of the impact of picture books is also presented. 22 picture books portraying multiethnic children and their families are identified and evaluated in the areas of bias, story line, and self-concept. All 22 picture books met the 3 criteria for portraying multiethnic children in a non-biased manner and are recommended by the authors for use by parents of, and professionals working with, preschool children. Relevance for social work practice with children and families is discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

*Books

TI: Cigarette smoking in multicultural, urban high school students.
AU:
Holowaty, Philippa

Feldman, Linda

Harvey, Bart

Shortt, Linda
IN: Holowaty, Philippa: Toronto Public Health, Toronto, ON, Canada
SO: Journal of Adolescent Health. Vol.27(4), Oct 2000, pp. 281-288.
AB: Profiled patterns of cigarette use among a multiethnic population of high school students and identified important factors associated with cigarette use by ethnicity in order to plan effective health promotion strategies. 1,236 high school students (grades 9-13) from three urban high schools completed a self administered lifestyle questionnaire. Results found that students who identified themselves as Canadian were significantly more likely to be current smokers than students reporting other ethnicities. There was no apparent increase in smoking rates for immigrants after two or more years in Canada. Current drinking, sexual activity, and especially friends, smoking was most strongly associated with current smoking for most ethnic groups, although the relative importance of these variables was not identical for all groups. It is concluded that prevention programs may benefit from a focus on the influence of peer smoking and on the grouping of lifestyle factors associated with smoking for students of all ethnic groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ethnicity &lifestyle risk factors, cigarette smoking, urban high school students
MH:
*Racial and Ethnic Differences

*Risk Factors

*Tobacco Smoking
PO: Human.  Male.  Female. Adolescence (13-17 yrs).  Adulthood (18 yrs & older).  Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs)

TI: Psychosocial determinants of the onset and escalation of smoking: Cross-sectional and prospective findings in multiethnic middle school samples.
AU:
Carvajal, Scott C

Wiatrek, Dawn E

Evans, Richard I

Knee, C. Raymond

Nash, Susan G
IN: Carvajal, Scott C.: Education, Training, Research Assoc, Santa Cruz, CA, US
SO: Journal of Adolescent Health. Vol.27(4), Oct 2000, pp. 255-265.
AB: Investigated a broad range of social influence-related and global determinants of smoking to aid in the design of comprehensive multiethnic interventions by testing the most important factors of initiation and escalation of smoking across various subgroups. 2,546 cross-sectional and 736 cohort samples of multiethnic middle school students (aged 11-15 yrs) were surveyed through self-report questionnaires. The questionnaires included information on demographics, risk factors, and smoking behavior and were administered in class. Results found that those lower in self-esteem and higher in social assertiveness appeared to be most at risk for the onset of smoking, whereas those low in optimism seemed to be the most at risk for the escalation of smoking. Attitudes, friends' norms, parents' norms, perceived behavioral control, and perceived prevalence were consistent predictors of all smoking status outcomes. It is concluded that the behavioral-specific determinants of smoking appear to be important predictors of smoking status outcomes in all demographic subgroups, while the relationships of the global determinants were more dependent on the smoking outcome variable and subgroup examined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: social-influence related & global determinants, initiation & escalation of smoking, 11-15 yr old multiethnic middle school students

TI: La psicologia al fin del siglo.
SO: (1999). La psicologia al fin del siglo. 422 pp. Caracas, Venezuela: Sociedad Interamericana de Psicologia; Venezuela.
AB: (from the publicity materials) This book contains the full texts of 23 keynote address presented at the 27th Interamerican Congress of Psychology by professionals from North American, Central America, South America, and the United Kingdom. These addresses represent various areas of psychology (clinical, psychoanalysis, cognitive, community, criminology, critical, cultural, cultural, developmental, health, psychological evaluation and measurement, industrial/organizational, neuropsychology, political, social, urban). The addresses deal with diverse topics within these areas such as eating disorders, alternative therapies, culture and cognition, child development, intelligence, new theoretical and methodological approaches, problems of aging adults, couple relationships, unemployment, sexual risk prevention, AIDS, conflict resolution, and urban life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: topics in psychology at end of 20th century

TI: Applying cognitive-affective processing system (CAPS) theory to cultural differences in social behavior. [References].
AU:
Mendoza-Denton, Rodolfo

Shoda, Yuichi

Ayduk, Ozlem

Mischel, Walter
IN: Mendoza-Denton, Rodolfo: Columbia U, Psychology Dept, New York, NY, US
SO: Lonner, Walter J [Ed]; Dinnel, Dale L [Ed]; Forgays, Deborah K [Ed]; Hayes, Susanna A [Ed]. (1999). Merging past, present, and future in cross-cultural psychology: Selected papers from the Fourteenth International Congress of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology.  (pp. 205-217). 531 pp. Lisse, Netherlands: Swets & Zeitlinger Publishers; Netherlands.
AB: (from the chapter) Proposed a network theory in which members of a culture or group engage in similar behavior to the extent that particular situations activate a shared network of cognitive-affective mediating units (e.g., constructs, values, beliefs, goals, expectancies) within the group members. A study was conducted approximately a year following the conclusion of the O. J. Simpson criminal trial in which 113 Ss (aged 14-49 yrs) were asked to describe their reactions to the verdict. Ss wrote their responses in a free-form essay format, to enable the authors to detect the kinds of cognitions and affects that Ss spontaneously generated, as well as to examine the relations among cognitive-affective units (CAUs). Specifically, the authors investigated (1) the accessibility of a set of cognitive-affective mediating units, (2) the inter-connections between these units, and (3) the relationships between the accessible units and the people's agreement/disagreement with the verdict. The results show that in contrast to widely shared assumptions at the time, content analyses revealed that Ss' race did not have a direct effect on their reactions. Instead, differences in the accessibility of cognitive-affective units and their subsequent activation pathways characterized respondents' reactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: cultural & racial differences in social behavior for O. J. Simpson criminal trial verdict, multiethnic 14-49 yr olds, application of cognitive-affective processing system theory

*Adjudication

*Cognitive Processes

*Emotions

*Racial and Ethnic Differences

TI: Urban families and adolescent mental health.
AU:
Stern, Susan B

Smith, Carolyn A

Joon Jang, Sung
IN: Stern, Susan B.: Boston U, School of Social Work, Family Therapy Certificate Program, Boston, MA, US
SO: Social Work Research. Vol.23(1), Mar 1999, pp. 15-27.
AB: Investigated the effects of social and economic disadvantage on parent distress, family processes, and adolescent mental health in a longitudinal, multiethnic sample of 800 urban adolescents and parents. Interviews were conducted on parents and teenagers in eighth and ninth grade. The findings support the hypothesis that poverty, life stressors, and isolation affect parent mood and disrupt family processes, which, in turn, are linked to adolescent externalizing and internalizing problems. The findings illustrate the importance of integrating an understanding of family processes and context in assessment and intervention directed at adolescent mental health problems. Implications of these findings for social work intervention with urban youths and families is also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Disclosing complementary and alternative medicine use in the medical encounter: A qualitative study in women with breast cancer.
AU:
Adler, Shelley R

Fosket, Jennifer R
IN: Adler, Shelley R.: U California, Dept of Epidemiology & Biostatistics, Div of Medical Anthropology, San Francisco, CA, US
SO: The Journal of Family Practice. Vol.48(6), Jun 1999, pp. 453-458.
AB: Attempted to understand the reasons for nondisclosure in the use of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) in a 5-year prospective cohort study consisting of 4 interview cycles. The multiethnic, population-based sample consisted of 86 San Francisco residents with recently diagnosed breast cancer (87% response rate). Ss were 35-49 and 60-74 yrs of age. Findings were determined using qualitative analysis of transcribed interviews. At initial contact, 72% of the participants were using at least 1 CAM therapy for breast cancer. Six months later, 65% of participants were using CAM. Of the women being treated by an alternative practitioner, 54% disclosed their CAM use to their physicians. Conversely, 94% discussed details of their biomedical treatments with their alternative practitioner. Reasons for not disclosing CAM use included anticipating the physician's disinterest, negative response or unwillingness or inability to contribute useful information; the perception that the CAM therapies used were irrelevant to the biomedical treatment course; and the patients' views regarding the appropriate coordination of disparate healing strategies. Specific suggestions for discussing CAM use with patients are presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: reasons for nondisclosure of complementary & alternative medicine use in medical encounter, 35-49 yr old vs 60-74 yr old females with breast cancer, 5 yr study

*Age Differences

TI: Values in the best-selling children's books in the United States, 1990-1997.
IN: Ruumet, Marika: U San Francisco, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.60(6-A), Dec 1999, pp. 2031.
AB: In the multiethnic society of the United States, the best-selling children's literature is not multicultural. Since there are values embedded in the text and illustrations of the books, children's literature teaches cultural values and exposes children to a perspective of the world. The purpose of this study was to explore the best-selling books for children and young adults in the United States from 1990 to 1997 in the categories of picture books and fiction. This study analyzed the values that are embedded in the language and themes of the books. The books that were chosen were based on predetermined criteria. The researcher used critical analysis to explore the language and the meanings of the text and relied upon the content of the text to suggest the themes for analysis. The study identifies four emerging themes that are analyzed: (1) Children need to feel in control of their lives-to be despondently independent; (2) True friendship and love is unconditional; (3) People feel more comfortable when others are like them which means differences are not tolerated; and (4) With every challenge there may not be a resolution, but there is hope in the future. The results of this study show that best-selling books for children and young adults reflect prosocial behaviors in the context of the mainstream culture in the United States. These behaviors might be considered antisocial in other cultures, such as how to confront obstacles or the value of individualism. Quantity of books sold is not synonymous with quality of books sold. Since adults are gatekeepers in some or all of the writing, publishing, and purchasing activities, the best-selling books expose children to the cultural values of the gatekeepers and result in an experience that may be based on an ethnocentric value system. Best-selling children's literature reflects who we are as a society. Through conscious decision-making in book buying, the purchaser can influence the quality of literature so that children will develop a multicultural perspective of the society in which they live. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: values in best-selling children's books, 1990-97
MH:
*Books

*Literature

*Reading

*Values

TI: Preschool quality and classroom variables: Are teacher-to-child ratio, group size, and ethnic diversity predictive of quality?
IN: Sticksel, Scott Allen: Fuller Theological Seminary, School Of Psychology, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(4-B), Oct 1999, pp. 1889.
AB: The relationship of classroom-related variables to level of quality preschool for 4-year-olds in a multiethnic Southern California city was examined. The Early Childhood Environmental Rating Scale (ECERS; Harms & Clifford, 1980) was used to evaluate the quality of 26 preschool centers. Variables previously demonstrated to be good predictors of quality in nationwide studies were tested, including teacher to child ratio and group size. A novel variable, ethnic diversity, also was tested. Results did not support the hypotheses that smaller group size, higher teacher-to-child ratio, and greater ethnic diversity would be correlated with high quality centers. However, results did suggest that greater ethnic diversity was significantly negatively correlated with high quality in the 4-year-old classrooms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Violence exposure and child mental health: An examination of direct effects and protective factors.
IN: Friedman, Ruth Jennifer: Arizona State U, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(3-B), Sep 1999, pp. 1300.
AB: This study aimed to evaluate the relation between exposure to violence and child mental health outcomes and to explore the impact of dispositional and ecological moderators. This study builds upon the existing research by using assessments from multiple reporters, examining the influence of potential moderators, and focusing on young children. Drawing from a multiethnic, predominantly lower-income, metropolitan area, researchers conducted interviews with 95 children from grades K-2, their primary caregiver, and teachers. Structural equation modeling demonstrated that greater violence exposure was associated with more internalizing symptomatology, as reported by the youth and the teachers. Though violence exposure was not directly related to parent reports of child internalizing and externalizing symptoms regression analyses testing interactive effects revealed violence exposure was related to parental reports of child internalizing and externalizing behavior in a limited manner. Modeling analyses found little evidence of a relation between exposure and academic ability. Finally, a series of regressions found some evidence for the protective influence of competence, family cohesion, and family warmth for children exposed to violence. Results support the need for developing empirically-based early intervention programs aimed at minimizing the effects of chronic violence exposure. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: violence exposure, mental health, kindergarteners-2nd graders & their primary caregiver & teachers
MH:
*Childhood Development

*Environmental Stress

*Mental Health

*Protective Factors

*Violence

TI: Comparison of Japanese-American, African-American, Hispanic, and white student self-assessments with assessments by multiethnic counselors.
IN: Kania, Scott Stephen: Kent State U, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(2-B), Aug 1999, pp. 0832.
AB: The purposes of this ex-post field design were to achieve the following: (a) to ascertain the effects of ethnic dissimilarity in the assessment of Japanese/Japanese American, African/African American, Hispanic, and white undergraduate and graduate university students, (b) to ascertain the differences in their presenting concerns, (c) to ascertain the discrepancy between how counselors assess the students and how students assess themselves, (d) to ascertain if there is a greater discrepancy when white counselors assess one minority group, as compared to another, (e) to investigate the numbers of presenting concerns as a function of counselor and client factors, and (f) to ascertain the most prevalent presenting concerns of each minority group. Subjects were 405 undergraduate and graduate students at an ethnically diverse Pacific Western university in the United States. Intake questionnaires comparing student and counselor assessments of 38 presenting concerns were analyzed. Data were analyzed utilizing Cohen's Kappa's, two-sample t tests, and ANOVA'a. Results indicated that there was an overall bias for counselors to "under-pathologize" all types of concerns, and that this bias was strongest for academic and career concerns. Both Hispanic and Japanese/Japanese American undergraduate students present with significantly more academic than personal concerns. Results also indicated that white counselors "over-pathologized" all students compared to all other ethnic minority counselors. The investigator concludes that white counselors operate from primarily an intra-psychic frame of reference, while minority counselors utilize a cultural frame of reference. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: assessments of presenting concerns, Japanese- vs African- vs Hispanic-American vs white undergraduate & graduate students vs multiethnic counselors
MH:
*Counselor Attitudes

*Psychological Assessment

*Racial and Ethnic Differences

*Self Evaluation
PO: Human. Adulthood (18 yrs & older).  Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs)
JN: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering

TI: Racial and ethnic socialization among college students: A multi-ethnic family ecology approach.
IN: Mcneil, James Derek: Northwestern U, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.59(12-A), Jun 1999, pp. 4370.
AB: Within a family ecology framework, this multiethnic survey study of 506 college students investigated: (1) the nature of both ethnic and racial socialization among African American, Latino, Asian and European American youth, (2) the prevalence of ethnic and racial socialization across these ethnic groups and (3) the predictive power of selected social and familial factors in the race related socialization of African American youth. Qualitative and quantitative analyses showed clear differences in ethnic versus racial socialization. Analysis of open-ended items revealed clear differences in the content of both intragroup "ethnic" messages and intergroup "racial" messages across the four groups. Parental socialization of ethnic messages about intragroup issues was more prevalent than racial messages for African American, Latino and Asian American students. African American and white students more often reported receiving racial socialization messages about intergroup coping than either Latino or Asian students. The familial ecology, as measured by distal to proximal factors, had only a modest relationship to race related socialization among the African American sample. Implications from this study are drawn for future theory and research as well as family-centered intervention among African American and other ethnic and racial groups in an increasingly diverse multiethnic social ecology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: racial & ethnic socialization, Asian vs European American vs African American vs Latino college students

*Racial and Ethnic Differences

*Socialization
PO: Human. Adulthood (18 yrs & older).  Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs)

TI: Social readjustment and ischemic stroke: Lack of an association in a multiethnic population.
AU:
Abel, Gregory A

Chen, Xun

Boden-Albala, Bernadette

Sacco, Ralph L
IN: Abel, Gregory A.: Columbia U, Coll of Physicians & Surgeons, Dept of Neurology, New York, NY, US
SO: Neuroepidemiology. Vol.18(1), Jan-Feb 1999, pp. 22-31.
AB: Stressful life events and ongoing stressful illness, 2 factors collectively termed "social readjustment" and which may precipitate stroke, were evaluated in an in-office study, using an urban, multiethnic sample of 655 ischemic stroke patients (mean age 69.8 yrs): 55.4% were women, 51% Hispanic, 28.4% Black, and 19.1% White. 1,087 age-, gender-, and race/ethnicity-matched control Ss were also assessed. Social readjustment was measured using the Geriatric Social Readjustment Rating Scale (GSRRS). Conditional logistic regression was used to analyze the GSRRS and its quartiles as well as stressful events subgroups, adjusting for education, hypertension, cardiac disease, diabetes, and number of weekly visits as a measure of socialization. GSRRS scores ranged from 0 to 812; the mean score was 205.5 for patients and 206.2 for controls. No association was found in age, gender or race-ethnic subgroups, or when analyzing negative events, severely threatening events, or ongoing stressful illnesses separately. While this study does not preclude social readjustment as a stroke risk factor, it suggests that the one-time assessment often done in the medical office setting has little relevance for stroke prevention planning. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: age & gender & race/ethnic variables & social readjustment, first ischemic stroke patients (mean age 69.8 yrs)

Translation and back-translation procedures were used to obtain appropriate meanings for the SF-36 survey questions and to ensure face, functional, and conceptual equivalence. 52 Mandarin-speaking Ss (aged 64-87 yrs) participated. OL: Preventative Medicine: An International Journal Devoted to Practice & Theory
AB: Evaluated the relationships between age, health status, access to care, and breast and cervical cancer screening among multiethnic elderly and nonelderly women. A structured telephone survey of a quota sample of 1,420 New York City women (aged 18-74 yrs) from 4 Hispanic groups (Columbian, Dominican, Puerto Rican, Ecuadorian) and 3 black groups (US, Caribbean, and Haitian) was performed. Outcome measures included "ever" and "recent" self-reported use of mammography, clinical breast examination (CBE), and Pap smears. Logistic regression models assessed the predictors of screening use. Having a regular source of care significantly predicted all screening use for both elderly and nonelderly, controlling for ethnicity, sociodemographics, health status, access to care, proportion of life in the US, and cancer attitudes. Elderly women (>65 yrs) were significantly less likely to have ever had and to have recently had Pap smears than younger women, controlling for the other variables; being elderly also tended to be an independent predictor of ever and recent mammography and CBE use. There was a trend for health status to act differently in predicting Pap smear use for the two age groups. For younger women, being in poor health increased the odds of Pap smear screening, while for elderly women, being in good health increased the odds of screening. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: age & health status & access to care & breast & cervical cancer screening, 18-74 yr old Hispanic & Black females

TI: Psychosocial and demographic correlates of television viewing.
AU:
Williams, Carl D

Sallis, James F

Calfas, Karen J

Burke, Randy
IN: Williams, Carl D.: Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State U, Dept of Psychology, Blacksburg, VA, US
SO: American Journal of Health Promotion. Vol.13(4), Mar-Apr 1999, pp. 207-214.
PU: American Journal of Health Promotion; US
AB: Explored associations between psychosocial determinants of physical activity and amount of television viewing. A secondary aim of the study was to replicate previously reported demographic relationships to television viewing suing a multiethnic and moderate size sample. 321 female and 255 male college seniors (mean age 24.5 yrs) completed surveys assessing average television viewing practices and physical activity. Results show the variables explaining a significant amount of variance after controlling for ethnicity and employment status in females were barriers to physical activity, body image dissatisfaction, and processes of change. The entire model for females captured 16% of the variance. The significant variables in the male model were quality of life, and grade point average. The full model account for 15% of the variance, with nondemographic variables accounting for 5% of the variance in television viewing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Blanchette, Patricia L
IN: Purcell, Don: Hawaiian Life Ctr, Honolulu, HI, US

AB: A retrospective study was undertaken to explore ethnic variability in suicide rates for the elderly population (65-69, 70-79, 80-89, and 90+ yr olds). Data were gathered via a review of the coroner's reports for completed elder suicides for Honolulu County from 1987 through 1992 inclusive. Results show a mean age for suicide completers of 75 yrs, with the highest incidence of completion in the 80+ yr old age group. The predominant method of suicide completion was hanging, followed by jumping, using firearms, and poisoning. There were significant gender and ethnic differences in method of suicide completion. Almost half of the sample saw a healthcare provider in the 6 mo before their death. Comparisons with other elder suicide studies are presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Hergenroeder, Albert C

Sangi-Haghpeykar, Haleh

Taylor, Wendell
IN: Hergenroeder, Albert C.: Texas Childrens Hosp, Clinical Care Ctr, Houston, TX, US
