TI: Community life: African Americans in multiethnic residential areas.
AU:
Hutchinson, Janis Faye

Rodriguez, Nestor

Hagan, Jacqueline
IN: Hutchinson, Janis Faye: U Houston, Dept of Anthropology, Houston, TX, US
SO: Journal of Black Studies. Vol.27(2), Nov 1996, pp. 201-223.
AB: Examined the behavior of African Americans in multiethnic settings, and the cognitive processes linked to these behaviors, within the framework of identity theory. Data was taken from a larger ethnographic study of intergroup relations between long-term residents and Latino new immigrants in 3 Houston neighborhoods; length of residence, spatial distribution, and sociocultural conditions were assessed. Strong ethnic commitment was shown to act as a buffer against an insecure or unfamiliar environment. In all 3 communities, social distance reflected powerful African American ethnic identity, which, with its internalized stereotypes, prevented creation of shared community identity in multiethnic settings. Long tenure and spatial proximity of ethnic groups did not alter the impact of ethnic identity on community identity. A high degree of tolerance and an absence of open conflict among ethnic groups was observed in all 3 communities; the authors suggest that the physical presence of an ethnically diverse environment produced social adaptations to reduce conflict. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

SO: (1996). Multicultural counseling in a divided and traumatized society: The meaning of childhood and adolescence in South Africa. xiv, 186 pp. Westport, CT, US: Greenwood Press/Greenwood Publishing Group; US.
AB: (from the preface) The purpose of this book is to provide students, teachers and professionals with a conceptual and applied resource for working with culturally diverse groups. Using South Africa as a case example, the book focuses on the worldwide challenge to the helping professions to contribute toward creating harmony in multiethnic societies. . . . South Africa today, with the drafting of a new constitution that will enfranchise all its citizens, is negotiating and moving toward a greater degree of multiethnic harmony. Nonetheless, because the scars of apartheid will remain for a long time, the present text describes childhood and adolescence in a society that has been severely divided and traumatized by institutionalized racism. This book describes current counseling and educational issues in South Africa and a myriad of disorders that are the effects of structural inequality. TI: Citizen empowerment through community economic development in a multiethnic neighbourhood.
IN: Papineau, Danielle: Universite De Montreal, Canada
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(6-B), Dec 1996, pp. 4038.
AB: Community psychologists have recently been concerned with developing the theoretical underpinnings of their field. The concept of empowerment has been proposed as a phenomenon of interest to community psychologists and has since become an important focus within this branch of psychology. As detailed in the first chapter of the dissertation, a small number of studies have aimed to advance empowerment theory by defining and explicating its essential components, and by determining which ecological factors sustain its development. The present research also focused on contributing to the theory of empowerment. Accordingly, an operational definition of empowerment with four components was developed as a basis for action research. These components include the following: A perception of self-efficacy and competence; the acquisition of knowledge, skills and access to resources; the development of a critical consciousness; participation in concerted action. The dissertation includes three studies. First, a pilot study documenting the early outcome of a community economic development (CED) intermediary organization initiated by a cross-cultural coalition of grass-roots groups. The organization was created in response to the economic needs of target groups including immigrants and refugees, single parents, the young unemployed and persons receiving social assistance. A qualitative methodology was used to explore the psychosocial impact of participation in the organization. The forty-two participants' responses were analyzed inductively to extract themes connected with the operational definition of empowerment as outlined above, and with four ecological dimensions that have been found to promote empowerment. The themes brought up by participants were detailed. Study results were used to outline the organization's impact and in program planning with stakeholder groups. The second study outlines the design, implementation and utilization of results process of a participatory eva (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: citizen empowerment through community economic development in multiethnic neighborhood, human Ss

TI: Student evaluations of teachers, student ratings of teacher behaviors, and their relationship to student achievement: A cross-ethnic comparison.
IN: Holmes, Trudy Ann Marie: Andrews U, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(9-A), Mar 1996, pp. 3471.
AB: Problem. This study was conducted to determine (1) whether student evaluations of teachers and ratings of teacher behaviors are related to the ethnicity of the students, (2) the relationship between overall student evaluations of teachers, classes, and ratings of teacher behaviors, and (3) the relationship between student evaluations of teachers, ratings of teacher behaviors, and student achievement. Method. Two teacher evaluation instruments were administered to students in undergraduate classes at a Christian college and a Christian university. The Student Evaluation of Educational Quality (SEEQ) was used as a high-inference evaluation form and the Teacher Behavior Inventory (TBT) was used as a low-inference rating form. The sample included 414 students from one college with a multicultural population and 67 students from one college with a homogeneous ethnic population. Results. In both the college and the university, no relationship was found between ethnicity and student evaluations of teachers. In the multiethnic setting, differences were found between the ratings of teacher behaviors by Caucasian students and the students from the remaining ethnic groups (p <). The Caucasian students tended to rate teachers lower in the areas of structuring and interaction, and higher in the areas of interest and pacing than the students from the other ethnic groups represented. Student ratings of teacher behaviors were significantly related to students' overall evaluation of teachers and classes. The behaviors that were significantly related to the evaluations differed for each ethnic group. Student evaluations of teachers and ratings of teacher behaviors were significantly, though weakly, related to achievement. The areas of evaluations and ratings that were related to achievement were different for each ethnic group. Conclusions. Students in general tend to give teachers positive evaluations and there were no significant differences among evaluations of teachers done (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: ethnicity & student achievement, student evaluations of teachers & student ratings of teacher behavior, undergraduates in colleges with multicultural population vs homogenous population

AU:
Hiatt, Robert A

Pasick, Rena J

Perez-Stable, Eliseo J

McPhee, Stephen J

et al
IN: Hiatt, Robert A.: Northern California Cancer Ctr, Union City, CA, US
SO: Health Education Quarterly. Vol.23(Suppl), Dec 1996, pp. S10-S27.
OL: Health Education & Behavior, Health Education Monographs
AB: Describes the background, conceptual framework, approach, and initial results from an integrated program of breast and cervical cancer screening studies among Latinas, Chinese, Vietnamese, and African Americans. The studies compose Pathways to Early Cancer Detection in Four Ethnic Groups, a 4-yr National Cancer Institute funded program project. The Pathways project studied the relationship of race/ethnicity, SES, and culture to breast and cervical cancer screening. A multidisciplinary, multicultural team of investigators assessed the knowledge, attitudes, and practices of 4,228 women from 5 race/ethnic groups and their barriers to screening utilization. A planning framework guided the development of interventions and analyses of the similarities and differences in screening behaviors across race/ethnic groups. Baseline data for women ages 18 to 74 yrs showed that levels of screening were higher than national averages for Latina, White, and Black women but lower for Chinese and Vietnamese women. Analyses revealed the importance of education and insurance in obtaining recommended screening regardless of race/ethnicity. However, race, ethnicity, and culture are important to the tailoring of effective interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Assessed the relationships of ethnicity, gender, and previous and intended condom use to perceived attributes of the condom and the contraceptive pill in a multiethnic sample of 197 college students (aged 18-48 yrs). Ss completed a contraceptive attributes questionnaire. Results show attitudes toward the condom and the pill included prevention of health problems, peer acceptance, sexual pleasure and spontaneity, convenience, embarrassment, and effectiveness in preventing HIV and sexually transmitted diseases. African American Ss viewed the condom more positively than did Ss from other ethnic groups and were more likely to use condoms than White Ss were. African Americans appeared to know less about the pill and were less likely to use it than were the White Ss. Intended condom use was associated with a perception of oral contraceptives as a less convenient method of birth control (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Tested self-labels used by multiethnic and monoethnic youths in relation to their parents' ethnicity and explored the relationship of these self-labels to self-esteem and ethnic identity in 2 studies. In Study 1, 47 multiethnic and 345 monoethnic university students (aged 17-24 yrs) completed a questionnaire on spontaneous ethnic self-labels, parents' ethnicity and self esteem. In Study 2, 194 multiethnic and 696 monoethnic school students (aged 14-19 yrs) completed questions on selected self-labels, ethnic identity, and other-group attitudes. Although more than 10% of the Ss were multiethnic, less than one third of the Ss labeled themselves as such. Self-labels used by the monoethnic Ss were either the label of one parent or a label that incorporated both parents' ethnicities. The 2 groups did not differ in self esteem. AU:

Walker, Lenore
IN: Mays, Vickie M.: U California, Dept of Psychology, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO: American Psychologist. Vol.51(5), May 1996, pp. 485-487.
AB: Increasingly, the United States is becoming internationalized as a result of sophisticated communication technologies that put us in touch with countries known previously to only a few, through economic development and multinational investment, and by the immigration of people who are sometimes fleeing hostile homelands. US citizens, like others abroad, will need to be responsive to the demands of a multiethnic, multiracial, and multinational society. The challenges of this changing world can and will range from such dilemmas as ethical decisions of who can and will have access to expensive technology that saves and prolongs life; to the development of conflict management strategies for peaceful coexistence with neighbors whose behaviors, beliefs, and values are strongly shaped by their religious, cultural, and ethnic backgrounds and socioeconomic circumstances. With the inauguration of this section, US psychology is invited to consider its contribution to meeting the needs of a changing society. TI: The role of concrete-abstract thinking levels in teachers' multiethnic beliefs.
AU:
Johnson, Patsy E

Johnson, Robert E
IN: Johnson, Patsy E.: U Kentucky, Lexington, KY, US
SO: Journal of Research & Development in Education. Vol.29(3), Spr 1996, pp. 134-140.
AB: Examined the relationship of abstract-concrete thinking levels (TLs) to the multiethnic beliefs of 123 inservice middle-school teachers (Whites and African-Americans). It was reasoned that such a relationship, depending on the TLs of the faculty and administrators, could influence any plan to change and improve the multiethnic climate in schools. Ss were given a modified Belief Systems Test and Multiethnic Climate Inventory (MCI). A multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and univariate analysis showed significant differences in MCI scores for abstract, middle level, and concrete thinkers, revealing that concrete thinkers tend to resist changes that clash with their beliefs against multiethnic interaction, and that abstract thinkers were more likely to consider and adopt change. These imply that teachers' TLs must be considered when designing multiethnic training programs and that diverse experiences be provided to move all teachers toward abstract TLs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Anxiety, productivity, performance, and culture in the Rorschachs of a multiethnic group of adolescents. [References].
IN: Vaz, Cicero Emidio: Pontificial Catholic University of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil
SO: Rorschachiana. Vol.20(1), 1995, pp. 93-111.
AB: In this work we are concerned with productivity and performance capacities as related to levels of anxiety and rational control in adolescents from different ethnic groups in southern Brazil. This research had its start in a project that we have been carrying out since 1900 on the capacity for productiveness. We were then seeking to verify whether the level of situational anxiety was higher in Tukuna Indians or in non-Tukuna white people who live in Alto Solimoes, State of Amazonas, in the north of Brazil. Thirty-six subjects of both sexes, including 21 with a diagnosis of hypertension, were administered the Rorschach and Spielberger's Trait-State Anxiety Inventory (STAI). Data collected with the Rorschach among adolescents of the South of Brazil allow us to conclude the following: 1. Afro-Brazilian adolescents resemble Tukuna adolescents tested in the interior of Amazonas with respect to low capacity for productivity. 2. Contrary to adolescents of Portuguese origin tested in the interior of Amazonas, Portuguese adolescents of Rio Grande do Sul did not show low capacity for productivity. 3. There is a positive correlation between situational anxiety and concern with performance and productivity in Brazilian adolescents of German, Israelite, Italian, and Portuguese origin.That is, these ethnic groups presented anxiety directly related to concerns with performance and productivity. 4. Adolescents of Afro-Brazilian origin, on the other hand, did not give evidence of anxiety and concern about performance and production capacity. It is discussed whether this finding is related to accommodation and dependence originating in the acceptance, without due resistance, of the acculturation of dependency since the slavery period in Brazil. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: cross-cultural differences, anxiety, productivity, performance, Rorschach, culture

TI: Language and the institutionalization of ethnic inequality: Malay and English in Malaysia.
IN: Lowenberg, Peter: San Jose State U, Dept of Linguistics & Language Development, San Jose, CA, US
SO: Schaffner, Christina [Ed]; Wenden, Anita L [Ed]. (1995). Language and peace.  (pp. 161-172). xxv, 253 pp. Amsterdam, Netherlands: Harwood Academic Publishers; Netherlands.
AB: (from the chapter) This chapter begins by tracing how, during Malaysia's often turbulent colonial and postcolonial history, the ethnic Malays and their Malay language have gained political dominance over the almost 50 percent of Malaysia's population of Chinese, South Asian, or other ethnic backgrounds. Examples are provided from Malaysia's leading English-language newspapers of how the English-speaking ethnic Malay elites are institutionalizing their dominance through English, which is the native language of very few Malaysians but is still the principal code for communication among Malaysia's multiethnic elites. Analysis of this primary journalistic data demonstrates that a major way that this occurs is by replacement of English words with denotatively (but not connotatively) equivalent terms from Malay, resulting in the covert expression of racism and the institutionalization of inequality. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: use of Malay vs English language to institutionalize inequality of ethnic minorities, Malaysia

TI: Development of the ethnic unconscious. [References].
IN: Herron, William G.: St John's U, US
SO: Psychoanalytic Psychology. Vol.12(4), Fal 1995, pp. 521-532.
AB: Describes the concepts of the unconscious, ethnicity, the ethnic unconscious, and the analytic process in relation to a multicultural, multiethnic society. The ethnic unconscious is conceptualized as repressed material shared by each generation with the next and with most people of that ethnic group. The material is derived from identifications that form ethnic character. Given limited attention in the past, the concept is gaining increased visibility and vitality as part of the total self to be analyzed. Attention is drawn to the role of the ethnic unconscious in the analytic process and its value for understanding transference, countertransference, and resistance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Suicide in the multiethnic elderly population of Australia, 1979-1990.
IN: Burvill, Peter Walter: U Western Australia, Dept of Psychiatry & Behavioural Science, Nedlands, Australia
SO: International Psychogeriatrics. Vol.7(2), Sum 1995, pp. 319-333.
AB: Studies rates, methods, gender, and country of birth (COB) for all suicides of individuals aged 65 yrs and over in Australia during the 12-yr period of 1979-1990. Rates of suicide in the COB were used as comparison figures. Results show marked heterogeneity in rates and methods of suicide among the various migrant groups, and more particularly in the rates in individual COB within those groups. The most common suicide method for males was use of a firearm, specially among the Australian and American groups. Women's most common suicide method was overdosage, but hanging was more common among the Asian-born. Only the European-born had appreciably higher suicide rates in both sexes. The data also showed that the suicide rates of migrants were mostly higher than in their COB. Migrants born in countries with high suicide rates generally had high rates in Australia and vice versa. Possible reasons for these findings are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Sexually-transmitted disease in female adolescents: Effects of psychosocial factors and high risk behaviors.
IN: Millstein, Susan G.: U California, Dept of Pediatrics, Division of Adolescent Medicine, San Francisco, US
SO: Journal of Adolescent Health. Vol.17(2), Aug 1995, pp. 83-90.
AB: Examined the effects of 5 psychosocial factors on risky sexual behavior (RSB) and substance use, and their direct and indirect effects on sexually transmitted disease (STD) acquisition. A multiethnic sample of 571 sexually-active 13-19 yr old females was recruited from family planning clinics. Ss completed questionnaires prior to their gynecologic examination and STD testing. Female adolescents who were heavy substance users, who felt little control over their sexual behavior, and had a greater number of friends who engaged in RSB were themselves more likely to engage in RSB. RSB was associated with positive STD status. Ss who used psychoactive substances during sex reported higher numbers of sexual partners and were more likely to have an STD. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: American mixed race: The culture of microdiversity.
IN: Zack, Naomi: State U New York, Albany, NY, US
SO: (1995). American mixed race: The culture of microdiversity. xxv, 379 pp. Lanham, MD, England: Rowman & Littlefield; England.
AB: (from the publicity materials) This . . . multidisciplinary collection brings together 22 original essays by scholars . . . of racial theory, who address both the American concept of race and the specific problems experienced by those who do not fit neatly into the boxes society requires them to check. Through identity theory, autobiography, art, social science, and public policy, the contributors to "American Mixed Race" explore this position of "microdiversity," or diversity within individuals. While they share a consensus that the biological concept of race is false, some contributors want to identify as mixed race while others opt for a reclaimed version of traditional racial and ethnic identities. Still others are skeptical of all identifications. "American Mixed Race" will be useful for undergraduate and graduate courses in multiculturalism, racial identity, American Studies, African-American Studies, Latino and Native American studies, Asian-American Studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Children's conceptions of school-based competence.
IN: Delaune, Michelle Suzanne Idoux: U Texas at Austin, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(6-B), Dec 1995, pp. 3473.
AB: The purpose of this study was to describe and compare children's and teacher's conceptions of school-based competence and incompetence, including factors that facilitate or inhibit competence development. Fifty-nine fourth grade children and their three classroom teachers from a multiethnic low income elementary school were interviewed regarding their views of competence and incompetence in the school setting. Children were interviewed in groups of three to four, divided by their teacher-rated competence level and gender. The interview format used was the same for the teachers and for the children and included questions addressing competence and incompetence in general as well as specific domains such as academic, behavioral, social and emotional competence. A reliable coding system was developed to describe the children's perceptions of competence and incompetence and a separate reliable system was developed for the teachers' ideas. Results of the study indicate that a core group of constructs about competence and incompetence are salient for all or most of the children, regardless of competence level or gender. Within this core group of constructs, there are a few ideas about competence and incompetence that were emphasized by children in the high and/or medium competence groups that were not emphasized by children in the low competence group. There were no gender differences found amongst these constructs cited by most of the children. Differences in the perceptions of children of different competence level groups and genders were found amongst some of the constructs that were less frequently mentioned and not common to all of the children. Most of the children's salient constructs are also significant to the teachers, although the teachers had additional constructs, often more abstract, that were highly relevant to them. No one competence level or gender group of children had perceptions that more closely matched the teachers' ideas about both competence a (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

IN: Larson, Leslie Ann: California School of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(6-B), Dec 1995, pp. 3477.
AB: The purpose of this study was to examine the strength of Black-White biracial adolescents' ethnic identity; whether the strength of identity contributes to adolescents' functioning; and whether the strength of ethnic identity and/or racial composition of neighborhood contributes to how adolescents self-label. Thirty-one Black-White biracial adolescents between the ages of 14 and 18 served as subjects in this within-group design. The variables assessed were: (a) the strength of biracial ethnic identity, (b) the self-label the adolescent used for ethnic identification, (c) the level of adaptive functioning, and (d) the racial composition of the adolescent's environment. The two predictor variables for the dependent variable of adaptive functioning were the strength of biracial ethnic identity and the self-label of the adolescents. The predictor variable for the dependent variable of ethnic self-label was the racial composition of the biracial adolescent's environment. Adaptive functioning was assessed by the Roberts Apperception Test for Children, ethnic identity and self-label were assessed by the Multiethnic Identity Measure, and the racial composition of the adolescent's environment was assessed by the questionnaire. Prior to hypothesis testing, intercorrelations found that no significant relationships existed between SES, age, the Biracial Multiethnic Identity Measure (MEIM), and the Roberts Apperception Test for Children (RATC) data at the.05 level of significance. The results of the simple Pearson correlation between the data from the Biracial MEIM and the RATC adaptive scales were not significant. In a post hoc analysis of the 3 MEIM's (Black, White and Biracial) it was found that the Black MEIM and the White MEIM significantly correlated with the RATC subscale, Resolution, and the total RATC adaptive scale. The results of a t-test found that a significant difference was not found between the Black and Biracial MEIM on the adolescent's self-label. The re (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: strength of ethnic identity & racial composition of environment, ethnic self-labeling & adaptive functioning, 14-18 yr old Black-White biracial adolescents

TI: A multiethnic study of urban stress, family environment, and child physical abuse.
IN: Grant, Patrice Mclurkin: California School of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(4-B), Oct 1995, pp. 2326.
AB: Sociocultural factors that may impact child physical abuse have not been widely investigated. Such factors may contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of abusive behavior within ethnically diverse families. A model is offered to provide a theoretical framework that includes sociocultural factors in the prediction of child physical abuse and that guides this research. The present study examined the impact of sociodemographic factors (ethnicity and education), abuse history, chronic urban stress, perceived racism, and family environment (cohesion, expressiveness, conflict, active-recreational orientation, and moral-religious emphasis) on abusive behavior in eighty-eight (N = 88) female caretakers. Data was collected in three settings, two mental health centers and one public school. Fifty-four percent (N = 46) of the participants were African-American, thirty-seven percent (N = 31) were Latina, and nine percent (N = 8) were Caucasian. The design of the study was correlational. The investigator hypothesized that ethnicity and education would be significantly related to stress; that the five family environment subscales would mediate the relationship between stress and abusive behavior; and that after accounting for sociodemographic factors and abuse history, urban life stress, perceived racism, and family environment would account for a significant portion of the explained variance in abusive behavior. Two-way ANOVAS and a hierarchical multiple regression were used to test the research hypotheses. The research hypotheses were partially supported by the data. However, additional analyses were conducted which yielded significant results. The results of these analyses note that sociodemographics and abuse history were not strong predictors of abusive behavior. Urban life stress had consistent main effects on abusive behavior. The active-recreational orientation subscale of family environment also had a significant main effect on abusive behavior after controlling (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: sociodemographic factors & abuse history & urban stress & perceived racism & family environment, child physical abuse, African-American vs Latina vs Caucasian female caretakers

TI: A multidimensional conceptualization of body image: The validation of the body image questionnaire within a population of adolescents.
IN: Micelle, Regina Dawn: California School of Professional Psychology - Fresno, US
SO: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(1-B), Jul 1995, pp. 0530.
AB: The present study was designed to provide validation for the English version of Bruchon-Schweitzer's Body Image Questionnaire using a multidimensional conceptualization. A total of 336 students, 110 males and 224 females, from a large multiethnic school district in Central California were administered the Body Image Questionnaire. Convergent and divergent validation was attempted using the Body Cathexis Scale and the Homonym Test. A principal component analysis with varimax rotations was completed with the 190 valid female questionnaires. Four factors were identified using 13 of the original 19 items. Only one of the factors resembled one of Bruchon-Schweitzer's factors. The study confirmed divergent validation with the Body Cathexis Scale and Homonym Test. The results continued to highlight the elusive nature of body image and the difficulty in defining it. The interpretation of the factors suggests the need for further research to identify the dimensions of body image and to establish a reliable and valid way to measure it. The results also suggest that feminist writings, poetry, and literature might be helpful in clarifying the underpinnings of body image. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: validation of English version of Bruchon-Sweitzer's Body Image Questionnaire, adolescent students
MH:
*Body Image

AU:

AB: Examined 3 factors that were hypothesized to increase risk for aggression among urban children: economic disadvantage, stressful events, and individual beliefs. Ss were 1,935 African American, Hispanic, and White elementary-school boys and girls assessed over a 2-yr period. Individual poverty (INP) and aggression were only significant for the White Ss, with significant interactions between individual and community poverty for the other 2 ethnic groups. A linear structural model to predict aggression from the stress and beliefs variables, INP predicted stress for African American Ss and predicted beliefs supporting aggression for Hispanic Ss. For all ethnic groups, both stress and beliefs contributed significantly to the synchronous prediction of aggression, and for the Hispanic children, the longitudinal predictions were also significant. Findings are discussed in terms of their implications for preventive interventions in multiethnic, inner-city communities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Multicultural literature and multiethnic readers: Examining aesthetic involvement and preferences for text.
IN: Altieri, Jennifer L.: Arkansas State U, US
SO: Reading Psychology. Vol.16(1), Jan-Mar 1995, pp. 43-70.
AB: Examined the role of culture in a reader's aesthetic response to a text. Ss were 226 White, African-American, and Hispanic students in 6 5th-grade and 6 7th-grade classes from a rural school district. Four short stories representative of the African-American, White, and Hispanic cultures were read to each class, and Ss then wrote their own comments and rated each story on a scale of 1-5. Responses were analyzed for aesthetic involvement using an instrument developed by D. Wiseman et al (1992). Fifth-grade Ss preferred White stories, while 7th-grade Ss preferred African-American stories. Minority Ss preferred stories about their own culture, but preference did not inhibit the Ss' ability to become aesthetically involved in the stories. It was also revealed that those of the majority culture were much more homogeneous in their preference for stories. The study emphasizes the importance of using multicultural literature in the classroom. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: culture, aesthetic involvement & preferences for text, White vs African American vs Hispanic 5th vs 7th graders

TI: Multiple sexual partners and their psychosocial correlates: The population-based AIDS in Multiethnic Neighborhoods (AMEN) Study. [References].
AU:
Dolcini, M. Margaret

Coates, Thomas J

Catania, Joseph A

Kegeles, Susan M

Hauck, Walter W
IN: Dolcini, M. Margaret: U California, Ctr for AIDS Prevention Studies, San Francisco, US
SO: Health Psychology. Vol.14(1), Jan 1995, pp. 22-31.
AB: In this study we examined multiple partners in a household probability sample of heterosexuals. Thirty-seven percent reported 2 or more partners in the past year, and 6% reported 5 or more partners. Significant interactions among gender, ethnicity, and relationship status revealed complex relations. African American men without a primary partner were the most likely to have multiple partners; ethnic minority women with primary partners were the least likely. Psychosocial factors associated with multiple partners were examined with the AIDS Risk Reduction Model (ARRM). Situational factors influenced how ARRM variables related to multiple partners. Perceived risk, commitment to monogamy, and communication were all important correlates. Prevention efforts must focus on increasing awareness of the risks of heterosexual transmission of HIV for people in dating relationships and on strengthening sexual communication skills with new partners. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: psychosocial correlates of multiple sexual partners, heterosexual adults

TI: Child sexual abuse and adult revictimization with women of color.
AU:
Urquiza, Anthony J

Goodlin-Jones, Beth L
IN: Urquiza, Anthony J.: U California-Davis Medical Ctr, Dept of Pediatrics, Child Protection Ctr, Sacramento, US
SO: Violence and Victims. Vol.9(3), Fal 1994, pp. 223-232.
AB: Examined the long-term consequences of child sexual abuse (CSA) and the rates of sexual revictimization of women of color. A multiethnic (White, African-American, Latina, and Asian-American) sample of 243 female undergraduates was administered extensive clinical interviews. Nearly two-thirds of the Ss who reported rape as an adult had a history of CSA, while approximately one-third of the nonvictimized Ss had a CSA history. An examination of the rates of adult rape within each ethnic group revealed differences between the Ss with and without a history of CSA. Significant differences (i.e., higher rates of rape associated with a prior history of CSA) were found for White, African-American, and Latina Ss, but not for Asian-American Ss. Data highlight the relationship between CSA and adult rape and suggest the need for researchers to take a broader cultural context in which to view sexual victimization. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: long term consequences of & sexual revictimization rates following child sexual abuse, 18-40 yr old White vs Latino vs Asian vs African American females

TI: The meaning of truancy: Organizational culture as multicultures.
IN: Enomoto, Ernestine K.: U Maryland, Coll of Education, College Park, US
SO: The Urban Review. Vol.26(3), Sep 1994, pp. 187-207.
AB: Investigated a multiethnic high school's truancy policy, examining how the school identifies and deals with truants. The author proposes using 3 discrete lenses of organizational culture to highlight the complexity of a school culture at work: the school as a whole, as subcultures, and as fragmented and ambiguous. Data were obtained through school documentation and group and individual interviews with students, faculty, and staff. Findings suggest that institutional realities at the organizational level unify members, but there are inconsistencies that can be detected at the subcultural and individual levels. Meanings are multiple and individually interpreted. Thus, members are able to exercise greater flexibility within the organization while demonstrating the greater autonomous action necessary in multiethnic urban settings. Further, the multiplicity of cultures suggests cultures other than race or ethnicity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: school culture, truancy policy, multiethnic urban high school
MH:
*High Schools

*School Environment

*School Truancy

Racial and Ethnic Groups

Urban Environments
PO: Human

TI: Ethnic categorization among children in multi-ethnic schools in the Netherlands.
IN: Verkuyten, Maykel: Utrecht U, Dept of General Social Sciences, Netherlands
SO: Journal of Community & Applied Social Psychology. Vol.4(3), Aug 1994, pp. 167-179.
AB: Explored the use and importance of ethnic categories among 149 children (aged 10-12 yrs) in 4 multi-ethnic schools in the Netherlands. Ss wrote a short essay on 1 of 2 topics: "The children at my school are different" and "With which children do you play and do you not play, and why?" The social categories spontaneously used in written essays were analyzed. Results show that ethnic categories should not be taken for granted. Categorical constructs were not the only ones used, as many particular descriptions were given. Although most Ss did use ethnicity in describing differences between schoolmates, many other social categories were used. There were few references to ethnicity when the Ss described patterns of playing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: use & importance of ethnic categories, 10-12 yr olds in multiethnic schools, Netherlands

*Racial and Ethnic Groups

TI: Perceived competencies, peer group affiliation, and risk behavior among early adolescents. [References].
AU:
Dolcini, M. Margaret

Adler, Nancy E
IN: Dolcini, M. Margaret: U California, Ctr for AIDS Prevention Studies, San Francisco, US
SO: Health Psychology. Vol.13(6), Nov 1994, pp. 496-506.
AB: This study examined the role of self-esteem and peer group membership in risk behavior among 183 8th graders in a multiethnic school. The hypothesis was that domain-specific rather than global self-esteem would be associated with "crowd" membership that in turn would be related to risk behavior. Data were gathered through informant interviews and individual surveys. Domain-specific self-esteem was related to crowd affiliation as well as to alcohol and cigarette use; global self-esteem was not related. Crowd affiliation related to alcohol use and sexual behavior after controlling for the effects of demographic and self-esteem variables, but crowd membership did not fully mediate the relationship between self-esteem and risk behavior. Availability of alcohol and cigarettes mediated the relationship between crowd affiliation and use of these substances. Findings support growing evidence that multiple adolescent peer groups exist and that group membership is closely tied to behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: global & domain specific self esteem, peer group affiliation & subsequent risky alcohol & cigarette use & sexual behavior, 8th graders
MH:
*Drug Usage

*Health Behavior

*Peer Relations

*Psychosexual Behavior

*Self Esteem

TI: The impact of race and ethnicity on transference and countertransference in combined individual/group therapy.
IN: White, Judith C.: Postgraduate Ctr for Mental Health, Adult Psychoanalytic Inst, Group Therapy Dept, New York, NY, US
AB: Interracial group psychotherapy is workable. Psychodynamics get cathected onto race; as this paper will show, the group process elicits feelings about racial and ethnic differences with greater intensity than in individual therapy. Analysis of race/ethnicity can be both problematic and growth enhancing for treatment. The process of identifying conscious and unconscious feelings and thoughts of race/ethnicity can stimulate major resistance, which can engender difficulties in maintenance of a working alliance. However, the working through of these feelings/thoughts may have a catalytic effect and lead to a more rapid unfolding of core psychodynamic issues. Case material from a multi-racial/multi-ethnic therapy group illustrate these issues. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Social support and achievement in childhood and early adolescence: A multicultural study.
AU:
Levitt, Mary J

Guacci-Franco, Nathalie

Levitt, Jerome L
IN: Levitt, Mary J.: Florida International U, Dept of Psychology, North Miami, US
SO: Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology. Vol.15(2), Apr-Jun 1994, pp. 207-222.
AB: Explored the relationship between support and school achievement in students at 3 grade levels (1st-2nd, 4th-5th, 8th-9th) from a multiethnic public school population. Personal interviews were conducted with 120 African-American, 101 Anglo/European-American, and 112 Hispanic-American students. Measures of social support, life stress, loneliness, and academic self-concept were included. Achievement indices were grades, Stanford Achievement Test scores, and teacher ratings. Support was related to achievement both directly and indirectly through self-appraisal, but specific effects varied by grade level. Support effects strengthened and stress effects declined in significance at adolescence, suggesting increased ability to utilize support resources in coping with stress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: In this feminist narrative study, a multiethnic, socioeconomically diverse sample of 45 lesbians recounted their actions in health care in a total of 332 health care stories. Findings suggest that Ss experienced compounded vulnerability in health care environments. A repertoire of protective strategies intended to meet needs for safety characterized their actions in health care, including rallying support, screening providers, seeking mirrors of one's experience, maintaining vigilance, controlling information, bringing a witness, challenging mistreatment, and escaping danger. TI: Culture and Family: A Guide for Psychotherapists. [References].
IN: True, Reiko Homma: San Francisco Community Mental Health Services, San Francisco, CA, US
SO: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.38(3), Mar,  1993
AB: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1993, Vol 38(3), 277-279. Reviews the book, Culture and Family: Problems and Therapy by Wen-Shing Tseng and Jing Hsu (see record 1991-98996-000). Written by a husband-and-wife team of Chinese-American psychiatrists, this book provides a rich source of reference for cross-cultural psychology researchers, teachers, and practicing psychotherapists. They integrate their own clinical experience with multiethnic families into their exhaustive review of the cross-cultural literature on families and offer helpful advice on assessing and treating culturally diverse families. Their work is particularly timely as we face an explosive increase in minority populations in the United States. Psychologists are now beginning to recognize that current knowledge, theories, and clinical practices based primarily on Western tradition are incomplete and in need of significant revisions. Although there are a number of publications dealing with selected cultural groups, this book is an ambitious attempt to review the data available on a far greater number of such groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Teachers' and deaf students' perceptions of communication ease and engagement. [References].
AU:
Braeges, Judith

Stinson, Michael S

Long, Gary
IN: Braeges, Judith: U California, Santa Barbara, US
SO: Rehabilitation Psychology. Vol.38(4), Win 1993, pp. 235-246.
OC: American Psychological Association, US; Division 22 of the American Psychological Association, US; Educational Publishing Foundation, US
AB: Collected ratings of communication ease and of engagement for 95 deaf junior and senior high school students (aged 12-21 yrs) in a large, urban, multiethnic school for the deaf. Ratings were made by the students' English teachers and by the students themselves. High teacher ratings for communication ease and engagement were associated with high academic achievement as measured by the Stanford Achievement Test. High student ratings for communication ease were also associated with academic achievement. The 2 best predictors of academic achievement were student-rated communication ease and teacher-rated engagement. Findings suggest that it is important for teachers to be sensitive to the level of communication comfort of their students because students who enjoy easier communication may be more likely to be engaged, or more actively involved, in classroom learning and to demonstrate higher academic achievement. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Ethnicity and training marital and family therapists.
IN: Arnold, Mary S.: Kent State U, Counseling & Human Development Services Program, OH, US
SO: Counselor Education and Supervision. Vol.33(2), Dec 1993, pp. 139-147.
AB: Reviews studies that focus on ethnicity and training in the family training and supervision literature and identifies 3 dominant themes. First, an ecological perspective should be used, combining didactic and experiential exercises with basic family theory. Second, training programs must encourage ethnic self-awareness in counselors-in-training. Finally, educators must understand the saliency of oppression in the lives of particular ethnic and racial groups. Recommendations to strengthen marital and family counselor training include using a developmental perspective to evaluate the conflict over universalism vs culturally relative approaches, implementing multiethnic awareness training programs, reducing student resistance to learning about cultural differences, and developing research that focuses on the importance of ethnicity as a training dimension. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Studied the effects of the development and implementation of a cross-cultural (English, Spanish, and Chinese) group of clients within a multiethnic day psychiatric hospital serving clients aged 55-95 yrs. The group was established to provide an opportunity for clients to interact beyond the daily elementary greetings and hand gestures imposed by the language barriers. The group was established for 6 mo and was aided by bilingual staff. Findings indicate that the bilingual staff acted as a language and cultural bridge for the clients. The group showed promise in bringing about greater mutual understanding and acceptance, and perhaps greater cohesion. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Some problems in establishing equality of treatment in multi-ethnic schools.
IN: Foster, Peter: Manchester Metropolitan U, Crewe & Alsager Faculty, England
SO: British Journal of Sociology. Vol.44(3), Sep 1993, pp. 519-535.
AB: There has been concern about what many parents and educationalists feel has been unequal treatment of students from ethnic minority backgrounds in British schools. This article attempts to clarify what is meant by equal and unequal treatment. It discusses the type of evidence that might be required to demonstrate equality or inequality and raises methodological problems concerned with the collection of such evidence. Two case studies are discussed. One found significant differences in interaction patterns in the classrooms of teachers who were classified as ethnically highly tolerant or highly intolerant. The 2nd study used a different methodology and concluded that, in the classrooms studied, students from 2 ethnic groups were, for the most part, treated equally. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Inspiring literacy: Literature for children and young adults.
IN: Sebesta, Sam: U Washington, Professor of Reading & Children's Literature, Seattle, WA, US
SO: (1993). Inspiring literacy: Literature for children and young adults. 192 pp. Piscataway, NJ, US: Transaction Publishers; US.
AB: (from the cover) Over the past ten years, heightened concern about literacy and reading has inspired public and private exploration of what children read, and what makes them want to read. This volume describes research into these questions. Besides showing how best to evoke students' interest in reading, it calls for more interaction between students and teachers as to what books are particularly significant reading. "Inspiring Literacy" covers important issues in both children's and adolescent literature. It includes first-hand perspectives of teachers, librarians, editors, and authors. The articles review trends in children's book publishing and book selling; explore revolutionary changes in methods and materials used to teach reading; examine the status of multicultural children's literature; and suggest intriguing nonfiction and poetry books for youths. "Inspiring Literacy" is essential reading for elementary and secondary teachers, authors of children's and adolescent literature, students and faculty in book publishing courses, publishers, and librarians. This book may be used as an up-to-date state-of-the-art text for courses in children's and young adult literature. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: discusses the issue of inspiring reading in children's & adolescent literature

TI: Education and instruction in the heterogeneous class.
IN: Rich, Yisrael: Bar-Ilan U, Graduate Program in Guidance & Counseling, Chairman, Ramat Gan, Israel
SO: (1993). Education and instruction in the heterogeneous class. xv, 175 pp. Springfield, IL, England: Charles C Thomas, Publisher; England.
AB: (from the preface) This volume is intended for teachers, their educators and supervisors, and researchers interested in teaching and classroom life. It focuses on the heterogeneous class, a school setting that has achieved some prominence in the recent scientific and professional literature. Upon entering a classroom we are no longer surprised to find extraordinary diversity of student attributes. Immediately apparent in many classes are the different hues of skin and other physical features of students. Observers of the educational scene employ a variety of terms to describe this kind of class. Some refer to it as a mixed-ability class emphasizing the diversity in student academic ability and achievement. Some speak of the multicultural or multiethnic class highlighting differences in the cultural or ethnic traditions and predispositions of children. Others use still different terminology, such as the heterogeneous class, as I have done in this book. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Tested propositions from a model of vulnerability and protective factors with a multiethnic sample of 1,289 urban adolescents (aged 11-13 yrs). The criterion variable was a composite score for cigarette, alcohol, and marijuana use. The primary vulnerability factor (negative life events) was related to higher levels of substance use, and rates of substance use were elevated among Ss with high negative affect and low positive affect. Supportive relationships with parents were inversely related to substance use. Personal competence in the domains of academic performance and adult relationships was inversely related to adolescents' substance use. Protective factors were most important for Ss with a high level of vulnerability. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Building a multi-ethnic, family-school-community partnership: Coalition for PRIDE.
IN:
Brown, Karen: Richter Institute of Social Work, Southwest Texas State University, TX, US
Chavkin, Nancy Feyl: Richter Institute of Social Work, Southwest Texas State University, TX, US
SO: The School Community Journal. Vol.1(2), Fal-Win 1991, pp. 33-36.
AB: Like many schools across the country, the San Marcos Consolidated Independent School District (SMCISD) is a multi-ethnic school district (59% Hispanic, 37% white, and 4% African-American) with an alarming school dropout rate. For example, the class of 1990 alone lost 225 students (40 percent) throughout its four high school years (1986-90). Despite numerous problems including poverty, lack of achievement, language difficulties, substance abuse, juvenile delinquency, and teenage pregnancy, SMCISD is a district that recognizes it has natural resources within the school, the home, and the community, and this district is restructuring its approach to education so that all students can be successful learners. Two key programs are crucial to this restructuring effort: the PRIDE Center and Coalition for PRIDE. While the PRIDE center's focus is on dropouts and potential dropouts at the high school level. Coalition for PRIDE focuses on prevention, intervention, and recovery of at-risk students from pre-kindergarten through high school. Education has been restructured in San Marcos. In a little more than a year, 20 would-be dropouts have received regular high school diplomas, and 75 former dropouts are now in the classroom. The school has broad support from community organizations who provide mentors and scholarships for students. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Examined the salience of ethnicity at an urban high school from the students' perspective. Data were derived from extensive observations of students by a participant-observer whose fieldwork extended over the course of 1 academic year and included interviews of about 50 students. The relevancy of ethnicity tended to be variable, depending on the social situation and the individual's interpretation of the event. The judgment resulting from this interpretation was linked to structural factors in the society. For the students at this multiethnic school, the articulation of ethnicity stemmed from issues of ritual, conflict, interest, and values. AB: (from the cover) This book raises important questions concerning the "shame" of illiteracy. What does it mean to students to be drawn into a world where family and friends cannot follow? Can the same person appear literate and illiterate at the same time? Is literacy, for that matter, an either/or condition? Does it "hurt" to be illiterate in more than one language, more than one culture? To whom can literacy education be a threat instead of a promise? TI: Education for democratic citizenship: A challenge for multi-ethnic societies.
IN: Sigel, Roberta S.: Rutgers U, Professor Emerita, NJ, US
SO: (1991). Education for democratic citizenship: A challenge for multi-ethnic societies. vi, 226 pp. Hillsdale, NJ, England: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc; England.
AB: (from the book) It is becoming increasingly clear that hosts and newcomers alike have to learn what it means to live democratically in a multi-ethnic world and, to accept diversity without fear or rancor. This book will illustrate how six post-industrial nations (Canada, The Federal Republic of Germany, Israel, The Netherlands, The United Kingdom, and The United States) have met, or failed to meet, this challenge. What they have done, or need to do, in the near future in order to promote the practice of democratic living and citzenship for the people in their midst-newcomers and hosts alike. Each of the six countries-as Koskin's next chapter relates-is experiencing a large influx of new populations, some permanent immigrants, others guest workers, refugees, or nationals of former colonial holdings. This volume is based on the contributions made by scholars from the above countries to a conference funded by the Spencer Foundation, and held in the fall of 1988 on the campus of Rutgers University. The conferees were given the charge to ask themselves, and to ask each other: What can we as educational researchers or practitioners do to prepare our youth for cooperative, constructive living in a democracy? How can we meet that challenge? (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: A nursery teacher and a nursery nurse were introduced to and instructed in the use of "Incidental Teaching" (IT) procedures (including contingent access to materials) designed to encourage child-initiated language interactions in the natural nursery classroom environment. The effects of these procedures were monitored over the course of a school year on a target group of 8 2nd language learning children (aged 3 yrs 3 mo to 3 yrs 11 mo) from Panjabi-speaking homes. After the initial training session, use of IT procedures increased markedly and in both classes children initiated more frequently as a consequence. TI: Culture and Somatization.
IN: Steele, David J.: University of Wisconsin Medical School, WI, US
SO: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.34(10), Oct,  1989
AB: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1989, Vol 34(10), 921-922. Reviews the book, Silent Boundaries: Cultural Constraints on Sickness and Diagnosis of Iranians in Israel by Karen L. Pliskin (see record 1987-98221-000). The "silent boundaries" from which this book takes its title refer to the unrecognized, unacknowledged, and misunderstood cultural differences that render communications difficult and strain interpersonal relations. This book examines the roots and consequences of recurrent misunderstandings between Iranian Jewish immigrant patients and western-trained physicians in multiethnic Israel. The focal point of Pliskin's analysis is the phenomenon known as "Parsitis." Parsitis is a pejorative label applied to Iranian patients who seek care for vague somatic concerns that the physician is unable to explain objectively. Although Pliskin's account is interesting and insightful, it could have been strengthened by a more thorough-going comparative perspective. Somatization is familiar to anyone working in a primary health care arena, yet there is relatively little mention of the extensive literature on this phenomenon. Moreover, Pliskin's analysis of the dynamics of the physician-patient relationship in the "natural history" of Parsitis would have benefited from a discussion of the social psychology of expectancy effects. Finally, Pliskin teaches exclusively by negative example. Pliskin's book will be of interest to students of emotion, practitioners in multiethnic settings, and medical educators. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Reviews data concerning the regional and ethnic distribution of psychoses and suicides in the multiethnic province of Voivodina in Yugoslavia. Data concerning the province's ethnic composition and the regional allocation of these ethnic groups are provided. The geographical distribution of psychoses and suicides corresponds to the ethnic and cultural distribution in the province. Psychoses and suicides are high primarily in regions where the original inhabitants-mostly ethnic Hungarians-comprise the majority of the population. While the incidence of psychoses and suicides is lower among Serbs, Rumanians, Slovaks, Ruthenians, and Montenegrins than the proportions of these ethnic groups in the total population would suggest, the incidence of these disorders is much higher among Hungarians than their proportion in the total population would indicate. Thus, ethnicity is a significant factor in such studies. (English & Russian abstracts) (0 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Evaluated the effectiveness of the Pediatric Symptom Checklist (PSC) as a psychosocial screening instrument administered to 212 patients (aged 6-12 yrs) at a military outpatient pediatric clinic. 21 Ss with scores in the high-risk range were randomly selected and matched with children scoring in the normal, not-high-risk range. Two trained interviewers, blind to individual PSC scores, independently interviewed and rated each S's levels of psychosocial functioning on the Children's Global Assessment Scale (CGAS). The Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL), a standardized psychosocial measure, was also completed by each S's mother. PSC scores were compared to the CGAS and CBCL scores in terms of sensitivity and specificity. Results suggest that the PSC is a valid pediatric psychosocial screening instrument for multiethnic patient populations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Who benefits from ethnic income redistribution? A cross-cultural analysis.
IN: Grove, D. John: U Denver Graduate School of International Studies, CO, US
SO: Social Science Research. Vol.18(1), Mar 1989, pp. 70-87.
AB: Examined income gains and losses due to changes in ethnic income distribution in 5 multiethnic countries (Canada, Israel, New Zealand, Sri Lanka, and the US). Time series ethnic income data was collected from census and government publications. Results show signs of interethnic equalization for 7 out of the 10 ethnic groups examined. In most cases, the dispersion of gains within the upwardly mobile groups was skewed in favor of the richest income groups; however, in some cases, the dispersion of gains was relatively even between top and bottom income groups. Upper-income groups also prospered within the downwardly mobile groups. Data do not support either the Marxian contention that group progress is due to workers usurping the economic privileges of the rich, or the neoclassical position that ethnic equalization is inversely related to within group inequalities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: income gains & losses, ethnic group members, 1951-84, Canada vs Israel vs New Zealand vs Sri Lanka vs US

IN: Bell, Lee A.: State U New York, Coll at New Paltz, US
SO: Journal for the Education of the Gifted. Vol.12(2), Win 1989, pp. 118-130.
AB: Explored 5 core dilemmas that block girls' success in school through discussions with 26 4th-6th graders in a multiethnic program for girls with high academic potential. The core dilemmas were smart vs social, silence vs bragging, failure vs perfection, "beauty" vs marginality, passive vs aggressive, and conforming vs being punished. Examples illustrate how girls can learn to externalize situational conflict and create options that express their own values and preferences. TI: Effects of gender, ethnicity, and school equity on students' leadership behaviors in a group game.
IN: Moore, Helen A.: U Nebraska, Lincoln, US
SO: The Elementary School Journal. Vol.88(5), May 1988, pp. 515-527.
AB: Examined leadership skills and perceptions of leadership by students and teachers in 10 desegregated elementary schools. Schools were divided into high- and low-equity schools based on the extent to which they met integrative educational criteria. 202 Hispanic and Anglo students in Grades 3 and 6 completed a cooperative task in multiethnic groups. Trained observers found gender differences in nonverbal and verbal leadership behaviors among students across schools, including higher activity levels in Hispanic and Anglo males and females from high-equity schools. Teachers and students rated Hispanic students lower on leadership, particularly Hispanic students in low-equity schools. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Investigated smoking and tobacco-chewing habits of 433 White, Black, Mexican-American, and Oriental 6th and 7th graders, who self-reported their tobacco use and perceptions of use among peers and friends, parental socioeconomic status (SES), and other variables. One-third of the Ss had used some form of tobacco at least once, with cigarette smoking more common than chewing. Norm perceptions and best friend's habits predicted both smoking and chewing experimentation and prevalence. White males were more frequent chewers; Blacks and Mexican-Americans were more frequent smokers. Significant associations between the 2 types of tobacco use were found. TI: Language and learning in the cooperative classroom.
IN: Sharan, Shlomo: Tel Aviv U, School of Education, Associate Professor of Educational Psychology, Ramat Aviv, Israel
SO: (1988). Language and learning in the cooperative classroom. xv, 176 pp. New York, NY, US: Springer-Verlag Publishing; US.
AB: (from the abstract) The Group-Investigation method was implemented in 5 eighth-grade classrooms in a junior high school where two-thirds of the student body consisted of pupils from Jewish families who came to Israel from Western countries, and one-third came from countries of the Middle-East. Four other 8th-grade classes in the same school were taught with the traditional Whole-Class method. All eleven teachers of History and Geography in the school participated in this experiment and they were assigned at random to one or the other of the two instructional methods. Teachers of the Group-Investigated classes took part in a series of workshops during the first year of the study, until they acquired an acceptable degree of competence in applying the Group-Investigation method in their classrooms. The experiment proper, encompassing 197 pupils in the classes taught with the Group-Investigation method and 154 pupils in classes conducted with the Whole-Class method, was carried out during the second year of the study. Two tests of academic achievement (one in Geography, one in History) were administered both before and after the experiment period. Also, 27 groups, of 6 pupils each, were selected at random from the nine classrooms, i.e. 3 groups from each class. There were 3 pupils of Western and 3 of Middle-Eastern background in each group. These groups engaged in two 15-minute discussions (one in Geography, one in History), and the discussions were videotaped. Data about the pupils' interethnic interactions, and about their verbal and intellectual behavior, were obtained from the analysis by two judges of the videotaped discussions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

*Language

*Learning

TI: Family variables and physical activity in preschool children.
AU:
Sallis, James F

Patterson, Thomas L

McKenzie, Thomas L

Nader, Philip R
IN: Sallis, James F.: U California-San Diego, La Jolla, US
SO: Journal of Developmental and Behavioral Pediatrics. Vol.9(2), Apr 1988, pp. 57-61.
AB: Studied the physical activity habits of 33 3-5 yr olds of low income families in a multiethnic sample, during free-play periods at preschool. Ss spent 58% of free-play time in sedentary activities and were vigorously active only 11% of the time. Independent variables studied were child body mass index (BMI); teacher-rated Type A behavior; and parent-reported mother BMI, father BMI, parent vigorous activity, and family cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk. The multiple regression of moderate-intensity activity was significant, with family CVD risk, parent vigorous activity, and father BMI accounting for significant amounts of variance. Results suggest that the effects of parental role modeling on child physical activity levels may extend to free-play settings beyond the confines of the home environment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Pitfalls in providing health care for international students.
IN: Char, Donald F.: U Hawaii, Student Health Service, US
SO: International Journal of Adolescent Medicine and Health. Vol.3(1), Jan-Mar 1987, pp. 13-22.
AB: Presents several pitfalls in providing cross cultural health care to multiethnic international students. In post industrialized society it is necessary to expand the vision of normal health care where more options and choices are available that are not limited to the professional provider. Western physicians over emphasize the measurements and evaluation of disturbances that brought about the illness to the ultimate neglect of the person having the illness. It is important to realize that international students are not well served by attempts to manage their problems using Western notions of personality and behavior. The final pitfall involves the great tendency to discuss disorders or maladies as a somatization process in international students. The author notes that somatization disorders are all too common a diagnosis in foreign students. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Ethnic group interaction in a multiethnic society.
AU:
Tucker, G. Richard

Taylor, Donald M

Reyes, Esther
IN: Tucker, G. Richard: McGill U., Montreal, Quebec, Canada
SO: International Journal of Psychology. Vol.6(3), 1971, pp. 217-222.
AB: 120 male Manilan Ss (average age, 11.5), who said their native language was Tagalog and identified themselves as members of the Tagalog regional group, watched a videotape skit of the same scene repeated 4 times with different combinations of Tagalog and Chinese boys. The skit portrayed a discussion about how to spend a free afternoon. 2 boys (actors) consistently overruled a 3rd who suggested a game of table tennis in preference to swimming. In the mixed ethnic-group conditions, the actor different in ethnic affiliation was also the one overruled in the skit. Before watching the skit, Ss rated on a 7-point scale how well they anticipated the actors would "get along" and were asked to select the language they expected them to use in the dialogue. 12 test sessions corresponded to each of the experimental conditions. Results reveal that Ss perceived that members of homogeneously composed groups would get along better than heterogeneous groups, especially for all-Chinese groups. While Ss almost unanimously correctly identified the language spoken, they showed much less accuracy in deciding which actors were Tagalog and which Chinese. This technique may be appropriate to study changes in ethnic group relations due to changes in language policy. (French abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: videotaped social interaction skit with Chinese & Tagalog actor tyrads, pre- & postratings of actors' "getting along" & language usage & ethnic affiliation, male Manilans of Tagalog groups

TI: Depression in mothers in a multi-ethnic urban industrial municipality in Melbourne: Aetiological factors and effects on infants and preschool children.
IN: Williams, Howard E.: U Melbourne, Royal Children's Hosp, Australia
SO: Child Psychology & Psychiatry & Allied Disciplines. Vol.26(2), Mar 1985, pp. 277-288.
OL: Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry
OC: Blackwell Publishing, United Kingdom; Cambridge University Press, United Kingdom; Elsevier Science, Netherlands; Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd., United Kingdom
AB: Investigated depression in mothers in a cohort of 99 families with a newborn infant in a multi-ethnic poor socioeconomic municipality in Australia. 35 mothers were native Australians, and 64 were immigrants. 35 mothers were depressed during the 1st yr after the baby's birth. While the clinical manifestations of depression in Australian-born and immigrant Ss were similar, there were differences in some etiological factors. Immigrant Ss who had recently arrived in Australia, were unable to speak English, and did not have a supporting social network had a significantly higher rate of depression. Depressed Australian-born Ss often had unhappy, unstable, and insecure childhoods, having been reared in families with marital disruption, violence, alcoholism, and desertion. Some also had previous depressive episodes. A strong supporting social network, especially by the father, and also by the extended family and friends, was significant in preventing depression. Behavioral problems in infants and preschool children were more common in families with depressed mothers. (23 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Misdiagnosis of schizophrenia in bipolar patients: A multiethnic comparison.
AU:
Mukherjee, Sukdeb

Shukla, Sashi

Woodle, Joanne

Rosen, Arnold M

Olarte, Silvia
IN: Mukherjee, Sukdeb: Columbia U, New York State Psychiatric Inst
SO: The American Journal of Psychiatry. Vol.140(12), Dec 1983, pp. 1571-1574.
AB: Reviewed the records of 76 bipolar (DSM-III) patients (mean age 41.03 yrs) for a history of previous misdiagnosis of schizophrenia. Multivariate analyses identified 3 variables significantly associated with previous misdiagnosis-auditory hallucinations, early age at onset, and ethnicity. Ethnicity remained significantly associated with misdiagnosis of bipolar patients as schizophrenic even after all other significant variables were partialled out of the equation. It appears from these data that Black and Hispanic (Puerto Rican) bipolar patients may be at a higher risk than Whites for misdiagnosis as schizophrenic, particularly if they are young and experience auditory hallucinations during affective episodes. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Psychosocial correlates of sexual attitudes and behaviors in urban early adolescent females: Implications for intervention.
IN: Gibbs, Jewelle T.: U California, School of Social Welfare, Berkeley, US
SO: Journal of Social Work & Human Sexuality. Vol.5(1), Fal-Win 1986, pp. 81-97.
AB: Studied demographic and psychosocial correlates of sexual attitudes and behaviors in a multiethnic urban sample of 387 12-16 yr old junior high school girls. 47% were involved in heterosexual dating and social activities. While only 17.5% were sexually active, they comprised 38.4% of those involved in dating. The average age of initiating sexual activity was 14.2 yrs. Active Ss had an average of 3.5 sexual partners, although 38% had only 1 partner. 51.3% of the sexually active Ss practiced no birth control. Sexual activity was related to ethnicity of school and neighborhood (Black and racially mixed), residential mobility, depression or unhappiness, other disruptive and deviant behaviors, earlier onset of menarche, lower grade point average (GPA) and greater academic problems, and aspirations toward being a working wife and mother. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

IN: Walkling, Philip H.: City of Birmingham Polytechnic, England
SO: Journal of Moral Education. Vol.15(1), Jan 1986, pp. 16-25.
AB: Illustrates the indecision that can affect persons in a multiethnic educational context when confronted by apparently conflicting demands for education that satisfies the requirement for equal opportunities for women and the due recognition of the special status accorded to the moral education of women in some cultures. The example of the Muslim population in parts of the UK requesting separate schools for males and females in accordance with their religious practices is discussed. It is concluded that the dilemma arises from a mistaken attribution of rights to entities rather than individuals and that teachers should adopt a positive attitude toward the protection of individual freedoms. TI: Dealing with Racism in Children--and Adults.
IN: Phinney, Jean S.: California State University, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.30(3), Mar,  1985
AB: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1985, Vol 30(3), 201-202. Reviews the book, Children and Race by David Milner (1983). Race, in this book, means essentially black and white. Although this focus accurately reflects the current research emphasis, it is unfortunate that there is so little attention paid to other racial and ethnic groups. The author reviews recent research showing that black children are much more likely to show a preference or liking for their own race now than was the case in earlier research. The author provides a thorough, research based discussion of important and often controversial issues such as the development of racial attitudes and identity, race and school achievement, and multicultural education. The author ends with a strong statement of the possible role of schools in facing and dealing with racism, based on British experience. Multicultural education should not consist of an occasional unit on ethnic food, dances, or customs, as is often the case, the entire curriculum needs to include multiethnic materials. This book is a good starting point to achieve that goal. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

SO: SAGE: A Scholarly Journal on Black Women. Vol.2(2), Fal 1985, pp. 28-36.
PU: Sage Women's Educational Press, Inc.; US
AB: Compared, in a multiethnic sample of 387 urban 7th- to 9th-grade female adolescents, the data on the 204 Black and 116 White Ss in the sample to study their psychosocial adjustment (PA)-self-esteem and educational-vocational expectations-and psychological functioning. Ss' responses to the Offer Self-Image Questionnaire by D. Offer et al (1981) and the Adolescent Biographical Questionnaire were analyzed. The results indicate that the Black and White Ss were more similar than different in their attitudes and aspirations, Black Ss were as well or better adjusted that were their White peers, the Black Ss were generally satisfied with themselves, and the Black Ss had high educational and vocational aspirations and expectations. Socioeconomic status (SES) was a more significant correlate than ethnicity of PA and educational expectations. Recommendations are made for promoting healthy PA in Black female adolescents and children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Ethnicity and cancer prevention in a tri-ethnic urban community.
IN: Coreil, Jeannine: U Texas Medical Branch, Galveston
SO: Journal of the National Medical Association. Vol.76(10), Oct 1984, pp. 1013-1019.
AB: Examined knowledge and behavior regarding primary cancer prevention among 24 White, 20 Black, and 20 Mexican-American community residents (mean age 43 yrs). Knowledge of smoking and dietary risk factors was substantial, but awareness of cancer safeguards involving reduced sun exposure and mouth and proctological examinations was low. Approximately 20% of the Ss had taken measures to prevent cancer, and these Ss tended to rate their own risk higher than those who made no lifestyle changes. Self-motivated behavior change focused on avoidance of cancer-promoting food. Blacks differed from Whites and Mexican-Americans in awareness of cancer cause and prevention, particularly regarding dietary factors and behavior modification. Findings have implications for the design of cancer control measures in multiethnic communities. (25 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
