TI: A sociobiological examination of management Theory Z.
IN: Glassman, Robert B.: Lake Forest Coll
SO: Human Relations. Vol.37(5), May 1984, pp. 367-392.
AB: W. Ouchi's (1981) management Theory Z, aimed at reducing the emphasis in the American economy on short-range interests, assumes that learning is the only source of human socialization. However, the theory's aims of individual worker fulfillment and increased aggregate productivity in a pluralistic society may be enhanced if possible instinctual contributions to behavior patterns are considered. Ideological snares in genetic determinism and cultural determinism are described, and an attempt is made to depolarize these alternatives. Basic ideas about evolution and inheritance are explained briefly, with evidences from familial studies, interspecies studies, and brain research. Because societies as pluralistic as those in the US are historically unusual, achieving a dynamic equilibrium of multiethnic integration that spans generations requires an unusually creative and predictive effort. Ouchi's notion of the natural mentoring relationship is a possible seed of such creative evolutionary change, suggesting a need for greater general dissemination of occupational information to help individual teachers and learners to discover each other. (66 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: genetics & sociobiology, management Theory Z

*Management

SO: Applied Social Psychology Annual. Vol.4 1983, pp. 165-197.
AB: Following a discussion of the author's background and the influences on his subsequent work in the area of the educational achievement process (specifically, equality of educational opportunity and school desegregation), theories, methodologies, and research relevant to educational achievement are reviewed. The author's early work, particularly that examining social influence, led to the formulation of a multivariate model that takes into consideration background characteristics (e.g., SES, race), social influence variables, and personality. While much research into scholastic achievement has utilized causal modeling approaches, maximum likelihood analysis of structural equations provides a general approach that handles models that are not unidirectional, as well as random and nonrandom measurement errors. This methodology was used to examine the effect of social influence variables, cross-sectionally and longitudinally, in a multiethnic sample of 1,700 children from kindergarten through 6th grade. Contrary to expectations, results suggest that school variables exerted little if any influence on achievement. Rather, findings support a view of the schools as transmitting status differences developed early in life, in effect, perpetuating preexisting status and ability differences. (39 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: SES & race & social influence variables & personality, academic achievement, kindergartners through 6th graders, implications for multivariate model of educational achievement

TI: Patterns of public drinking in a multiethnic society: A systematic observational study.
AU:
Graves, Theodore D

Graves, Nancy B

Semu, Vineta N

Sam, Iulai A
SO: Journal of Studies on Alcohol. Vol.43(9), Sep 1982, pp. 990-1009.
OL: Journal of Studies on Alcohol and Drugs, Quarterly Journal of Studies on Alcohol
AB: Reported systematic observations of 216 New Zealand men, equally divided among Maoris, Pacific Islanders, and Europeans, in 12 public bars throughout the Auckland metropolitan area. Alcohol consumption and the size, sex, and ethnic composition of their drinking groups were recorded at 5-min intervals from arrival to departure. Significant ethnic differences in consumption were documented. An alternative causal model to account for these differences, replicated within all 3 ethnic groups, emerged: Initial drinking group size determines subsequent group size, which determines time spent in the pub, which determines glasses of beer consumed. Drinking group size and time spent accounted for 69% of ethnic differences in consumption. Social rituals and cultural predispositions account for the relationships found in patterns of ethnic drinking. The more moderate levels of alcohol consumption observed among European drinkers are not the result of normal virtue but of learned patterns of interpersonal behavior that limit their participation in group drinking and limit the behavior of all drinkers who participate in such groups regardless of ethnic background. Also emphasized are the primary social-recreational role of the pub as a working man's club and the positive functions of drinking groups in a patron's total life adaptation. (24 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: public alcohol drinking patterns, Maoris vs Pacific Islanders vs Europeans, New Zealand

AB: Examined the relationships among pupils' classroom status, pupil participation in classroom discussions, and students' perceptions of teacher praise. Classroom status included academic and teacher- and peer-perceived status. Relationships between students' cultural background and the 3 variables were also examined. Ss were 165 2nd-4th graders in a school located in a lower socioeconomic, multiethnic community. The methodology included naturalistic observation, an analysis of the social meanings Ss attached to classroom language, and a comparison of Ss' classroom discourse with their sociolinguistic behavior in other settings (e.g., home and play). AB: Investigated the relationship of self-reported foot problems to health, mental health, and functional mobility in 111 50-87 yr olds living in a multiethnic urban area. One-third of the respondents reported having problems with their feet. Analyses supported the prediction that foot complaints were significantly related to greater psychological distress and that for most individuals, this relationship was mediated by limited mobility. TI: Depression and suicidal behavior among delinquent females.

AB: Evaluated depressive symptomatology and suicidal behavior in a multiethnic sample of 48 delinquent females (13-18 yrs old) through ratings on self-reports and probation officers' reports. Psychological functioning of Ss was evaluated through the Diagnostic Interview for Borderlines, Rorschach, and WAIS or WISC-R to identify delinquent personality patterns. Four patterns were identified: borderline, antisocial, neurotic, and socialized delinquent personalities. A chi-square analysis of the data demonstrated that level of depression and frequency of suicidal behavior were both significantly related to personality patterns. Level of depression was also significantly related to ethnicity, but not to socioeconomic status. Results have implications for assessment and treatment of delinquent females and also raise issues concerning the interaction of personality, cultural factors, and delinquent behavior. AB: Bilingual-bicultural adaptation is a function of individual characteristics and those of people representing the majority group in the environment. AB: Guided by J. K. Hemphill's (1964) concept of polarization, the present study explored the shared organizational goals of 9 clubs in a multi-ethnic senior center. The 3 organizational objectives that received the highest ratings by officers of the clubs were (a) to promote fellowship and welfare for the members; (b) to generate harmony, love, and compassion for everyone; and (c) to communicate and cooperate with other clubs. The 3 with the lowest ratings were (a) to educate the public about the needs of senior citizens, (b) to learn new skills and hobbies, and (c) to learn about traditional (ethnic) cultures. Results indicate that many multipurpose senior centers ascribe to an activity (vs a disengagement) approach to aging. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: A multiethnic approach to peer counseling. [References].
IN: Gravitz, Herbert L.: U California Counseling Ctr, Santa Barbara
SO: Professional Psychology. Vol.7(2), May 1976, pp. 229-235.
AB: Describes multiethnic peer counseling on a college campus as a model of service for those students who tend to be missed by the more traditional counseling approaches. A successful program at the University of California is described. It has as its goals the following: increasing the availability of counseling services to all students, particularly those who may need but do not avail themselves of these services (e.g., minority students); extending the reach and delivery of services, taking them directly to the students in the communities where they live and study and also acquainting them with the counseling center's resources; increasing the range of services offered by the center; and increasing opportunites for inter- and intraethnic communication. The approach is seen as an answer to immediate needs for counseling which cannot be met otherwise because of tightened university budgets which preclude the hiring of adequate professional counseling staff. It is also pointed out that most currently employed counselors were hired before college and universities developed a heightened ethnic awareness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: Blacks in a multiethnic social studies curriculum: A critical assessment.
IN: Banks, Samuel L.: Baltimore City Public Schools, Workshop for Teachers & Administrators on a Multiethnic Social Studies Curriculum, MD
SO: Journal of Negro Education. Vol.44(1), Win 1975, pp. 82-89.
PU: Assn of American University Presses/Howard University Press; US
AB: Discusses the negative effect on the self-concept of Black children of the continuing neglect of Black history and culture in multi-ethnic curricula. It is argued that textbooks convey fallacious images. Curriculum guides suggest that Black history is separate from American history. Schools and colleges do not seriously consider the culture and history of Blacks. It is proposed that administrators, curriculum workers, the mass media, and teachers attempt to correct fallacies related to identity problems of Blacks. Essentials for a multi-ethnic curriculum are (a) sensitization and training of various personnel with respect to minorities, (b) multi-ethnic materials, (c) biracial staffs, and (d) cooperation between the school and the entire community. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: neglect of black history & culture in multiethnic social studies curriculum, negative effect on self concept, black children

TI: Measuring consumer satisfaction in a community outpost.
IN: Denner, Bruce: Illinois Mental Health Inst, Community Mental Health Program, Chicago
SO: American Journal of Community Psychology. Vol.2(1), Mar 1974, pp. 13-22.
OC: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers, US; Springer, Germany
AB: 66 terminated clients from an inner-city, multiethnic community mental health center outpost responded to 3 questions in a consumer evaluation telephone interview. Results show that, in general, the ex-clients (1) were satisfied with services, (2) reported high degrees of problem resolution, and (3) tended to give the credit for this change to the clinic. Client satisfaction was not correlated with problem resolution. Most clients reported getting better, but the satisfied ones saw the clinic as responsible for the change. Greater change was reported when the clinic was seen as responsible. The 3 evaluation measures did not vary as a function of age, sex, ethnicity, or termination point. Clients who terminated without therapist agreement were relatively dissatisfied and inclined to attribute change to nontherapy factors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: measurement of consumer satisfaction, terminated clients of inner city community mental health center outpost
MH:
*Clients

*Satisfaction

TI: The effect of a motor development program on selected factors in motor ability, personality, self-awareness and vision.
AU:
Arnheim, Daniel D

Sinclair, William A
IN: Arnheim, Daniel D.: California State U, Long Beach
SO: American Corrective Therapy Journal. Vol.28(6), Nov-Dec 1974, pp. 167-171.
OL: Clinical Kinesiology: Journal of the American Kinesiotherapy Association
AB: Primary pupils at an elementary school having a multiethnic population with a predominance of Anglo-and Mexican-Americans were given a daily 30 min sensorimotor program during fall and spring semesters, lasting about 36 wks. Primary pupils at another elementary school (in the same district) with a predominance of middle class Anglos were controls. Results of analysis of pre- and posttest scores of the 76 Ss showed that experimental Ss had significant improvement in (a) 10 of 12 subtests on the Frostig Movement Skills Test Battery, (b) the total score on the California Test of Personality, (c) the Draw-a-Man test, and (d) all factors measured by the Reading Eye III. A correlation matrix demonstrated relationships between factors; included was a close relationship between personality scores and measures of static and dynamic balance, fine muscle coordination for dexterity and motor sequencing. It is concluded that a motor development program for primary school pupils can effect positive changes in personality, self-awareness, motor ability, and visual skills necessary for reading. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

TI: The socio-cultural expressions and implications of death, mourning and bereavement arising out of the war situation in Israel.
IN: Palgi, P.: Ministry of Health, Mental Health Div., Tel-Aviv, Israel
SO: Israel Annals of Psychiatry & Related Disciplines. Vol.11(4), Dec 1973, pp. 301-329.
AB: Notes that the increasing number of war deaths, combined with the multiethnic nature of Israel's population, has led to a growing need for a systematic analysis of bereavement as a psychocultural phenomenon in Israel. A theoretical approach and research data are presented concerning the functions and relativity of mourning customs. Specific problems that arise from the effect of acculturation on traditional mourning customs are considered. The implications of war deaths on different family types and on children are stressed as they apply to the present Israeli context. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

AB: Used social studies multiethnic materials with 7-7.5 yr old white children in an urban and a rural school to establish what attitude changes would occur, if any, toward black Americans. TI: New dimensions in basal readers.
SO: Reading Teacher. Vol.25(4), Jan 1972, pp. 310-315.
AB: Discusses recent trends in materials used for teaching fundamental reading skills. A number of innovations in basal readers have appeared in the past decade, but relatively few of them have become widely adopted. Content shows a trend toward a multiethnic, multicultural scope. The recent trend in enrichment is to provide in convenient packages the kinds of materials formerly just mentioned in the teachers' guides. Visual and audio supplements exist, but combined audiovisual accessories are not available for most basal series. Illustrations have become more varied and readers tend to be numbered consecutively by levels rather than identified with specific grades. 3 recent trends in regard to objectives are noted: (a) some support for stressing decoding and de-emphasizing comprehension in early reading stages, (b) increased attention to critical and creative reading, and (c) a very recent interest in behaviorally stated objectives. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: basal readers, trend toward multiethnic & multicultural scope & inclusion of enrichment materials
MH:
*Culture (Anthropological)

*Drugs

*Instructional Media

*Teaching Methods

TI: Changes in attitudes toward Negroes of white elementary school students after use of multiethnic readers. [References].
AU:
Litcher, John H

Johnson, David W
IN: Litcher, John H.: U. Minnesota
SO: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.60(2), Apr 1969, pp. 148-152.
AB: Investigated the effect of curriculum materials which portray Negroes in a way which is contradictory to prevailing prejudices and stereotypes upon the attitudes toward Negroes of white 2nd-grade school children in a Midwestern city. A pretest-posttest design controlling for the teacher, the classroom, the school, and the reading ability of Ss was used. The 34 children in the experimental groups used a multiethnic reader which included characters from several different racial and ethnic groups for 4 mo., while the 34 children in the control groups used the regular reader which included only whites. Use of the multiethnic reader resulted in marked positive change in Ss' attitudes toward Negroes, supporting the counter-conditioning hypothesis. (23 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
ID: attitude change toward Negroes after use of multiethnic readers, elementary school, white students

*Attitude Change

*Blacks

*Student Attitudes
